question_text: A 6-week-old male infant is brought to the physician by his mother because of a 2-day history of recurrent nonbilious vomiting. Vomiting occurs almost immediately after most feeds. Each time, he becomes irritable while feeding and refuses to finish the bottle. He was born at 37 weeks' gestation and weighed 3300 g (7 lb 4 oz); he currently weighs 4000 g (8 lb 13 oz). He has Down syndrome. His vaccinations are up-to-date. He appears agitated and cries during the examination. His temperature is 37.2°C (99°F), pulse is 156/min, respirations are 32/min, and blood pressure is 100/49 mm Hg. Examination shows upward slanting of the eyelids, a broad and flat nasal bridge, and a single transverse palmar crease on both hands. The abdomen is soft and nontender. A 2.5-cm (1-in) epigastric mass is palpated. Cardiac examination shows no abnormalities. Arterial blood gas analysis is within normal limits. Further diagnostic evaluation of the patient is most likely to show which of the following?
content_preview: A 6-week-old male infant is brought to the physician by his mother because of a 2-day history of recurrent nonbilious vomiting. Vomiting occurs almost immediately after most feeds. Each time, he becomes irritable while feeding and refuses to finish the bottle. He was born at 37 weeks' gestation and weighed 3300 g (7 lb 4 oz); he currently weighs 4000 g (8 lb 13 oz). He has Down syndrome. His vaccinations are up-to-date. He appears agitated and cries during the examination. His temperature is 37.2°C (99°F), pulse is 156/min, respirations are 32/min, and blood pressure is 100/49 mm Hg. Examination shows upward slanting of the eyelids, a broad and flat nasal bridge, and a single transverse palmar crease on both hands. The abdomen is soft and nontender. A 2.5-cm (1-in) epigastric mass is palpated. Cardiac examination shows no abnormalities. Arterial blood gas analysis is within normal limits. Further diagnostic evaluation of the patient is most likely to show which of the following?
hint: The recurrent nonbilious vomiting after meals and the epigastric mass, along with the patient's sex and age, are highly suggestive of hypertrophic pyloric stenosis.
learning_objective: Recognize hypertrophic pyloric stenosis, and recall its diagnostic ultrasound findings.

answers.content: Double bubble sign on abdominal x-ray
answers.explanation_why: A double bubble sign on abdominal x-ray is seen in patients with duodenal atresia. Patients with duodenal atresia typically present with signs of obstruction, including a distended upper abdomen, delayed meconium passage, and vomiting. Almost one-third of duodenal atresia cases are associated with chromosomal abnormalities, especially Down syndrome. This patient has Down syndrome and also presents with vomiting, but he does not have a distended upper abdomen or delayed meconium passage. Instead, he has an epigastric mass, which makes another diagnosis more likely.

images.title: Duodenal atresia in a newborn
images.description: X-ray of the abdomenDilation of the pre-stenotic bowel segments – duodenum (D) and stomach (S) – with an air-fluid level in each dilated segment (double bubble sign). No air is visible in the post-stenotic bowel loops.

answers.content: Corkscrew appearance on upper gastrointestinal contrast series
answers.explanation_why: A corkscrew appearance on an upper gastrointestinal contrast series is seen in patients with volvulus (corkscrew sign) due to twisting of the distal duodenum and proximal jejunum. It is also seen in patients with diffuse esophageal spasm (DES) secondary to multiple contractions in the distal esophagus. Patients with volvulus usually present during the first two months of life with bilious vomiting and feeding intolerance. This patient's presentation of nonbilious vomiting and epigastric mass makes the diagnosis of volvulus unlikely. DES rarely affects children and while it may also present with food refusal and vomiting, it would not be associated with a palpable epigastric mass.

images.title: Corkscrew esophagus
images.description: Barium swallowHelical contractions of the lower esophagus (green overlay), resulting in a corkscrew-like appearance.Seen in patients with diffuse esophageal spasm (DES).

answers.content: Dilated colon segment on abdominal x-ray
answers.explanation_why: A dilated colon segment on abdominal x-ray is seen in patients with Hirschsprung's disease, which often initially presents with failure to pass meconium within 48 hours of birth and/or symptoms of gastrointestinal obstruction (e.g., bilious vomiting and abdominal distention). The condition is more common in patients with Down syndrome, but this patient has nonbilious vomiting and there is no mentioned failure to pass meconium following birth, making Hirschsprung's disease unlikely.

images.title: Hirschsprung disease
images.description: X-ray abdomen (AP view) of a 5-day-old newbornA massively dilated colon (green overlay) is seen proximal to a narrowed distal segment (red overlay). The appearance and location of the narrowing are consistent with short-segment Hirschsprung disease.Yellow overlay: gastric bubble

answers.content: Detection of rotavirus antigen on enzyme immunoassay (EIA)
answers.explanation_why: Patients with rotavirus gastroenteritis typically present with vomiting, watery diarrhea, high-grade fever, and malaise. This patient presents only with vomiting, and has an epigastric mass, which makes the diagnosis of rotavirus gastroenteritis unlikely.

answers.content: Elongated and thickened pylorus on abdominal ultrasound
answers.explanation_why: Hypertrophic pyloric stenosis, which most often occurs between 2–6 weeks of age, is characterized by hypertrophy and hyperplasia of the pyloric sphincter. Male infants are more commonly affected. Projectile, nonbilious vomiting is the most common finding. Abdominal ultrasound is used to confirm the diagnosis and usually shows an elongated and thickened pylorus. The treatment of choice in patients with hypertrophic pyloric stenosis is Ramstedt pyloromyotomy, in which a longitudinal muscle-splitting incision is made in the hypertrophic sphincter, without injury to the mucosa.

images.title: Infantile hypertrophic pyloric stenosis
images.description: Ultrasound abdomen (pylorus; longitudinal plane) of an 8-week-old male infantThe single wall thickness of the muscular layer measures 6.5 mm (normal cutoff: 3 mm). The pyloric channel measures 17 mm (normal cutoff: 14 mm). No fluid was seen to pass through the pylorus into the duodenum during real-time evaluation when the infant was fed.The imaging findings confirmed the diagnosis of pyloric stenosis.

answers.content: Episodes of decreased pH on esophageal pH monitoring
answers.explanation_why: Episodes of decreased pH on esophageal pH monitoring are seen in patients with gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD). Although GERD may affect infants and is also associated with vomiting, the patient in the vignette presents with an epigastric mass, which makes another diagnosis more likely.

answers.content: Triple bubble sign on abdominal x-ray
answers.explanation_why: A triple bubble sign on abdominal x-ray is seen in patients with jejunal atresia, which is associated with signs of obstruction, including a distended upper abdomen and bilious vomiting. This patient does present with vomiting, but it is nonbilious and he has an epigastric mass rather than a distended upper abdomen, making jejunal atresia unlikely.

images.title: Triple bubble sign in jejunal atresia
images.description: X-ray abdomen (A and B: supine) of two neonates with abdominal distension and bilious vomitingDilatation of the stomach, duodenum, and proximal jejunum (A) is characteristic of the triple bubble sign of jejunal atresia. Multiple dilated bowel loops (B) may alternatively be seen in jejunal atresia, and the number of loops may increase in conjunction with a more distal location of the atresia.1: gastric air-fluid level; 2: duodenal air-fluid level; 3: jejunal air-fluid level

question_text: A 5-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of a 5-week history of pain in his left thigh. The mother reports that her son fell from a ladder while playing with friends about a month and a half ago. He had a runny nose 3 weeks ago. He has no history of serious illness. He has reached all developmental milestones for his age. His immunizations are up-to-date. His 7-year-old brother has asthma. The patient is at 60^th percentile for height and 65^th percentile for weight. He appears healthy. His temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 88/min, respirations are 17/min, and blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg. Examination shows a mild left-sided antalgic gait. The left groin is tender to palpation; abduction and internal rotation are limited by pain. The remainder of the physical examination shows no abnormalities. His hemoglobin concentration is 13.3 g/dL, leukocyte count is 8,800/mm^3, and platelet count is 230,000/mm^3. An x-ray of the pelvis shows a left femoral epiphysis that is smaller than the right with widening of the medial joint space on the left. The femoral head shows little discernible damage. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 5-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of a 5-week history of pain in his left thigh. The mother reports that her son fell from a ladder while playing with friends about a month and a half ago. He had a runny nose 3 weeks ago. He has no history of serious illness. He has reached all developmental milestones for his age. His immunizations are up-to-date. His 7-year-old brother has asthma. The patient is at 60th percentile for height and 65th percentile for weight. He appears healthy. His temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 88/min, respirations are 17/min, and blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg. Examination shows a mild left-sided antalgic gait. The left groin is tender to palpation; abduction and internal rotation are limited by pain. The remainder of the physical examination shows no abnormalities. His hemoglobin concentration is 13.3 g/dL, leukocyte count is 8,800/mm3, and platelet count is 230,000/mm3. An x-ray of the pelvis shows a left femoral epiphysis that is smaller than the right with widening of the medial joint space on the left. The femoral head shows little discernible damage. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: Antalgic gait and hip pain with limited internal rotation and abduction of the hip should raise concern for Legg-Calvé-Perthes disease, which most commonly affects boys aged 4–10 years. This patient's x-ray shows erosion of the femoral epiphysis with minimal damage to the femoral head.
learning_objective: Recognize Legg-Calvé-Perthes disease, and choose the most appropriate initial management.

answers.explanation_why: Femoral osteotomy is performed to realign the femoral head and keep it within the acetabulum. This procedure is indicated for the treatment of patients with Legg-Calvé-Perthes disease who are older than 8 years of age and/or those with severe disease (e.g., extensive damage to the femoral head, lateral pillar classification B or B/C). In older children, surgery is more beneficial because bone formation capacity is often too limited to repair femoral head damage.

Casting and bracing to keep the femoral head contained within the acetabulum is sometimes used in the conservative management of Legg-Calvé-Perthes disease in patients < 8 years of age. However, the benefits of these methods have not been clearly established.

Femoral head pinning is a surgical procedure in which internal fixation of the femoral head is achieved through the placement of one or two cannulated screws. This procedure is indicated for treating slipped capital femoral epiphysis (SCFE). Although SCFE also causes thigh pain, limping is only seen in late stages and the condition most commonly affects boys aged 10–16 years with obesity. Typical hip x-ray findings include a widened femoral epiphyseal plate with increased lucency and/or posteroinferior displacement of the femoral head in relation to the femoral neck.

answers.content: Limited weight bearing and physical therapy
answers.explanation_why: Conservative management with limited weight-bearing and individualized physical therapy is recommended for patients  ≤ 8 years of age with mild Legg-Calvé-Perthes disease (e.g., preserved range of motion of the hip). This condition is self-limited and typically resolves within 2–5 years. Management aims to preserve the shape of the femoral head and the integrity of the affected hip joint during healing.

images.title: Legg-Calvé-Perthes disease
images.description: X-ray pelvis of an 8-year-old girl (AP view; frog-leg position)The right femoral epiphysis (E) is smaller than the left and its contour is flattened (arrow). The appearance is compatible with Legg-Calvé-Perthes disease. No sclerosis or cystic lucencies are seen. The acetabulum is not deformed.

answers.explanation_why: Nafcillin is a beta-lactam antibiotic with activity against gram-positive bacteria, especially S. aureus, the most common cause of osteomyelitis. Although osteomyelitis causes thigh pain, it also manifests with tenderness at the site of infection, malaise, fever, and chills, which are absent in this patient.

question_text: A 15-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his mother because of a 2-month history of pain in his left hip. The pain started suddenly and has worsened over the past 2 weeks. The pain radiates down the thigh and is aggravated by movement. He had a fall while cycling around a month ago. He had a urinary tract infection 3 months ago that resolved with trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole. There is no family history of serious illness. His immunizations are up-to-date. He is 165 cm (5 ft 5 in) tall and weighs 85 kg (187 lb); BMI is 31 kg/m^2. His temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), pulse is 65/min, and blood pressure is 104/70 mm Hg. Examination shows an antalgic gait. The left groin is tender to palpation, and internal rotation is limited due to pain. Flexing the hip causes external rotation and abduction. His leukocyte count is 9800/mm^3, and his erythrocyte sedimentation rate is 12 mm/h. An x-ray of the pelvis is shown. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 15-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his mother because of a 2-month history of pain in his left hip. The pain started suddenly and has worsened over the past 2 weeks. The pain radiates down the thigh and is aggravated by movement. He had a fall while cycling around a month ago. He had a urinary tract infection 3 months ago that resolved with trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole. There is no family history of serious illness. His immunizations are up-to-date. He is 165 cm (5 ft 5 in) tall and weighs 85 kg (187 lb); BMI is 31 kg/m2. His temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), pulse is 65/min, and blood pressure is 104/70 mm Hg. Examination shows an antalgic gait. The left groin is tender to palpation, and internal rotation is limited due to pain. Flexing the hip causes external rotation and abduction. His leukocyte count is 9800/mm3, and his erythrocyte sedimentation rate is 12 mm/h. An x-ray of the pelvis is shown. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: This adolescent boy with obesity has left hip pain, a positive Drehmann sign (passive flexion causes external rotation and abduction), and x-ray findings (widening of the left hip joint, cranial displacement of the femoral neck in relation to the femoral head) suggestive of a slipped capital femoral epiphysis (SCFE).
learning_objective: Recognize slipped capital femoral epiphysis, and choose the most appropriate next step in management.

answers.explanation_why: Conservative management in orthopedics consists of protection, optimal loading, ice, compression, and elevation (POLICE principle), along with NSAIDs for analgesia. This patient has a stable SCFE because he can bear weight without crutches. Conservative management alone will not suffice because weight-bearing may lead to an unstable SCFE, which is associated with a high risk of avascular necrosis of the femoral head.

The localization of pain and reduced range of motion indicates that this patient has a hip condition. A long cast alone is not useful to treat hip pathologies. A hip spica cast with a long leg cast may be used to immobilize the hip and prevent further slipping in patients with a stable SCFE. However, this treatment modality is associated with a higher rate of complications than the preferred treatment.

Intravenous antibiotic therapy is indicated when septic arthritis is suspected, which also manifests with joint pain and restricted movement. However, a lack of fever, a normal ESR and leukocyte count, as well as pain for a period of 2 months make a diagnosis of septic arthritis unlikely.

Surgical pinning of the femoral head refers to the placement of 1–2 pins through the femoral neck into the epiphysis and is used to treat SCFE to prevent further slipping of the epiphysis and promote closure of the epiphyseal plate. Surgical pinning is indicated for both stable and unstable SCFE. Prior to surgery, patients should avoid weight-bearing.
Intraarticular injection of lidocaine is used to treat severe pain in the knee, hip, elbow, and shoulder joint, but it is not indicated to treat SCFE.

Proximal femoral osteotomy is used to surgically treat Legg-Calvé-Perthes disease (LCPD) in children > 8 years of age or those with advanced disease. LCPD manifests with hip pain and a decreased range of motion. However, LCPD most commonly affects children between the ages of 4 and 10 years, and the onset of symptoms is usually insidious, with hip pain gradually worsening over months. Additionally, the x-ray in LCPD is either unremarkable or shows a dense, proximal femoral epiphysis that has a thinned-out, irregular surface and subchondral lucencies (indicating subchondral fractures).

images.title: Legg-Calvé-Perthes disease
images.description: X-ray pelvis (AP view) of a childThe left femoral epiphysis (green overlay) is small, flattened (coxa plana), and sclerotic. The hip joint space is widened.This appearance is consistent with Legg-Calvé-Perthes disease. Early radiographic findings may include medial joint space widening and reduced bone density. Later, the femoral head may become small, fragmented, flattened, and sclerotic.

images.title: Slipped capital femoral epiphysis on the left side
images.description: Pelvic x-ray (AP)Slipped epiphysis with femoral neck displaced in relation to the femoral head (green overlay) and widened physis on the left side. The right femoral head and epiphyseal plate show no pathology.

question_text: A 2-week old newborn is brought to the physician for a follow-up examination after the initial newborn examination showed asymmetry of the legs. She was born at term to a 26-year-old woman, gravida 3, para 2. Pregnancy was complicated by a breech presentation for which she underwent an emergency lower segment transverse cesarean section. The newborn's head circumference is 35 cm (13.7 in). She is at the 60th percentile for length and 75th percentile for weight. Cardiac examination shows no abnormalities. The spine is normal. Abduction of the right hip after cupping the pelvis and flexing the right hip and knee causes a palpable clunk. The feet have no deformities. Ultrasonography of the hip determines the angle between lines along the bone acetabulum and the ilium is 50°. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 2-week old newborn is brought to the physician for a follow-up examination after the initial newborn examination showed asymmetry of the legs. She was born at term to a 26-year-old woman, gravida 3, para 2. Pregnancy was complicated by a breech presentation for which she underwent an emergency lower segment transverse cesarean section. The newborn's head circumference is 35 cm (13.7 in). She is at the 60th percentile for length and 75th percentile for weight. Cardiac examination shows no abnormalities. The spine is normal. Abduction of the right hip after cupping the pelvis and flexing the right hip and knee causes a palpable clunk. The feet have no deformities. Ultrasonography of the hip determines the angle between lines along the bone acetabulum and the ilium is 50°. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: This newborn has a positive Ortolani sign (the clunk heard and felt on abducting her flexed hip), which suggests developmental dysplasia of the hip (DDH). The sex of the child (female) and a breech presentation are risk factors for DDH. An alpha angle (angle between lines along the bone acetabulum and the ilium) of less than 60° on ultrasound also indicates DDH.
learning_objective: Recognize developmental dysplasia of the hip, and choose the most appropriate initial management for a newborn.

answers.content: Reassure the mother and schedule follow-up appointment in 4 weeks
answers.explanation_why: In most infants, mild hip instability (e.g., the femoral head is subluxable) resolves spontaneously within the first 6–8 weeks of life, as growth of the femoral head and acetabulum reduces hip laxity. If mild hip instability is detected at neonatal screening, close observation, and repeat examination after 2–6 weeks are appropriate. However, in infants with clinical evidence of hip instability (e.g., the femoral head is dislocatable) and abnormal ultrasound findings, DDH is unlikely to resolve without treatment. These infants are at high risk of developing a functional disability and accelerated osteoarthritis in the course of their lives. Expectant management would therefore not be appropriate.

answers.content: Immobilize the hips with a spica cast
answers.explanation_why: In the case of DDH, a hip spica cast is indicated only after an open or closed reduction of the femoral head or following a pelvic or femoral osteotomy. Since none of these procedures were performed in this infant, a hip spica cast would not be appropriate.

answers.content: Obtain an x-ray of the right hip
answers.explanation_why: An x-ray of the hip is not useful for assessing the hip joint at birth because the head of the femur is unossified for the first 4 months and cartilaginous structures do not appear on an x-ray. A hip x-ray would be appropriate (instead of an ultrasound) if the child were older than 4 months.

answers.content: Perform closed reduction of the right hip
answers.explanation_why: The clunk heard during the Ortolani maneuver (abduction of a flexed hip) indicates reduction of the dislocated hip. Therefore, further maneuvers to reduce the hip are not needed. In infants with DDH older than 6 months, contractures develop around the hip joint and make hip abduction difficult. Closed reduction of the hip joint under general anesthesia would be indicated in such a scenario.

A harness that keeps the hips abducted to 50° and flexed to 90–100° to achieve concentric reduction of the femoral head is the treatment of choice for DDH in infants who are less than 6 months old. The harness should be worn for at least 23 hours/day for 6–8 weeks. The type of abduction harness (rigid vs. nonrigid harness) used varies by region and institutional protocols.

Nonrigid harnesses (e.g., the Pavlik harness) are the most commonly used orthotic among patients with DDH, although recent evidence suggests rigid harnesses (e.g., von Rosen harness) are associated with better outcomes.

answers.content: Perform open reduction of the right hip
answers.explanation_why: Open reduction of the dislocated femoral head is the treatment of choice for DDH in patients 12–18 months of age. In individuals > 18 months of age, pelvic and/or femoral osteotomy may also be performed. This patient is 2 weeks old and therefore requires a different step in management.

question_text:
A 13-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his mother because of left groin pain for 1 month. The pain radiates to his left knee and is aggravated on walking. He fell during soccer practice 5 weeks ago but did not see a doctor about it and does not recall any immediate and persistent pain after the event. He has hypothyroidism. His only medication is levothyroxine. His immunizations are up-to-date. He appears uncomfortable. He is at the 50^th percentile for height and at the 95^th percentile for weight. His temperature is 37.1°C (98.9°F), pulse is 77/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 100/70 mm Hg. The patient has a left-sided, antalgic gait. The left lower extremity is externally rotated. The left hip is tender to palpation and internal rotation is limited by pain. Laboratory studies show:

Hemoglobin
13.1 g/dL

Leukocyte count
9,100/mm^3

Platelet count
250,000/mm^3

Serum

 TSH
3.6 μU/mL

Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
content_preview: A 13-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his mother because of left groin pain for 1 month. The pain radiates to his left knee and is aggravated on walking. He fell during soccer practice 5 weeks ago but did not see a doctor about it and does not recall any immediate and persistent pain after the event. He has hypothyroidism. His only medication is levothyroxine. His immunizations are up-to-date. He appears uncomfortable. He is at the 50th percentile for height and at the 95th percentile for weight. His temperature is 37.1°C (98.9°F), pulse is 77/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 100/70 mm Hg. The patient has a left-sided, antalgic gait. The left lower extremity is externally rotated. The left hip is tender to palpation and internal rotation is limited by pain. Laboratory studies show: Hemoglobin 13.1 g/dL Leukocyte count 9,100/mm3 Platelet count 250,000/mm3 Serum TSH 3.6 μU/mL Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
hint: An x-ray of this patient's left hip would show widening of the joint space and a femoral head that is displaced posteriorly and inferiorly in relation to the femoral neck.
learning_objective: Recognize slipped capital femoral epiphysis.

answers.explanation_why: Legg-Calvé-Perthes disease would also cause antalgic gait with groin pain that is aggravated by walking and impaired internal rotation of the affected hip. However, this patient's age makes this diagnosis unlikely, as this condition is most common in children between 4–10 years of age. Furthermore, this condition tends to have a slower and more gradual symptom onset.

answers.content: Septic arthritis of the left hip
answers.explanation_why: Although this patient has manifestations consistent with septic arthritis, such as joint pain and reduced range of motion, he is missing several key findings, such as fever, joint swelling, and abnormal lab values (e.g., increased ESR).

The cause of slipped capital femoral epiphysis is not fully understood, but it occurs most often in obese children between 10–16 years of age. There also appears to be an association with endocrine disorders, such as hypothyroidism. Hip pain and an externally rotated thigh (internal rotation is very painful) are typical of this condition. The next step would be to confirm the diagnosis through an x-ray of the left hip. Surgical pinning of the femoral head is indicated for both stable and unstable slipped capital femoral epiphysis.

See “Common causes of hip pain in children” table.

This patient has some features consistent with osteomyelitis, such as groin pain that aggravates with walking and reduced range of motion. However, osteomyelitis is extremely unlikely because he is missing key findings such as malaise, fever, chills, leukocytosis, and elevated inflammation markers (e.g., ESR).

Although transient synovitis can manifest with unilateral groin pain and antalgic gait, this patient has no history of viral infection, which usually precedes the onset of this condition. Moreover, his age makes the disorder unlikely, as transient synovitis most commonly affects children 3–8 years of age.

answers.content: Developmental dysplasia of the left hip
answers.explanation_why: Developmental dysplasia of the hip is an unlikely diagnosis in this patient because it is most frequently seen in girls and usually becomes symptomatic in the first year of life. Additionally, at this age, this condition would have caused a discrepancy in leg length, unless it was bilateral, in which case it would manifest with a waddling gait and hyperlordosis, none of which is seen in this patient.

question_text: A 7-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his mother because of a limp for the last 3 weeks. He has also had right hip pain during this period. The pain is aggravated when he runs. He had a runny nose and fever around a month ago that resolved with over-the-counter medications. He has no history of serious illness. His development is adequate for his age. His immunizations are up-to-date. He appears healthy. He is at the 60^th percentile for height and at 65^th percentile for weight. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows an antalgic gait. The right groin is tender to palpation. Internal rotation and abduction of the right hip is limited by pain. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. His hemoglobin concentration is 13.6 g/dL, leukocyte count is 8,900/mm^3, and platelet count is 170,000/mm^3. An x-ray of the pelvis is shown. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's condition?
content_preview: A 7-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his mother because of a limp for the last 3 weeks. He has also had right hip pain during this period. The pain is aggravated when he runs. He had a runny nose and fever around a month ago that resolved with over-the-counter medications. He has no history of serious illness. His development is adequate for his age. His immunizations are up-to-date. He appears healthy. He is at the 60th percentile for height and at 65th percentile for weight. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows an antalgic gait. The right groin is tender to palpation. Internal rotation and abduction of the right hip is limited by pain. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. His hemoglobin concentration is 13.6 g/dL, leukocyte count is 8,900/mm3, and platelet count is 170,000/mm3. An x-ray of the pelvis is shown. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's condition?
hint: Hip pain with limited internal rotation and abduction in addition to x-ray findings of joint space widening and femoral head flattening are consistent with Legg-Calvé-Perthes disease, which most commonly affects boys aged 4–10 years.
learning_objective: Recognize avascular necrosis of the femoral head (Legg-Calvé-Perthes disease).

answers.explanation_why: An unstable proximal femoral growth plate is the underlying cause of slipped capital femoral epiphysis (SCFE). A hip x-ray would show a widened femoral epiphyseal plate with increased lucency, and/or femoral head posteroinferior displacement in relation to the femoral neck. Additionally, SCFE most commonly affects obese males between 10–16 years of age, making a diagnosis of SCFE in this 7-year-old patient unlikely.

images.title: Slipped capital femoral epiphysis (slipped upper femoral epiphysis)
images.description: X-ray pelvis ( AP view) of a 14-year-old boyWidening of the right femoral growth plate (physis; blue overlay) is accompanied by inferior and medial displacement of the epiphysis (green overlay) on the femoral neck (red overlay), which is cranially positioned relative to the acetabulum. Widening of the right hip joint is also seen (indicated by double-arrows). The left femur is also abnormal, with a widened neck. A line (Klein line; dashed lines) along the lateral edge of the superior femoral neck on either side does not intersect the respective epiphysis.GS: gonad shield

answers.explanation_why: Septic arthritis is caused by bacterial infection of a joint, and manifests with joint pain and a restricted range of motion. However, patients with septic arthritis usually have fever, an elevated leukocyte count, and a more acute disease course than seen in this patient. Additionally, septic arthritis is typically more painful than Legg-Calvé-Perthes disease. While this child has a limp and pain while running, a patient with septic arthritis of the hip would typically avoid bearing weight on the affected side because of pain.

Transient synovitis of the hip may occur following a viral process such as an upper respiratory tract infection. The pain from transient synovitis of the hip usually resolves within approx. 7 days and is unlikely to persist for 3 weeks. Moreover, unlike this child, patients with transient synovitis often have normal x-ray findings; ultrasound or MRI of the hip may show joint effusions in some patients.

Juvenile idiopathic arthritis (JIA) is associated with immune-mediated synovial inflammation. Hip involvement occurs in 35–60% of patients with JIA and may manifest with hip pain and a limp that is characteristically worse early in the morning and improves with activity during the day. In this child, however, the pain is exacerbated by running. In addition, hip x-ray findings in the early stage of JIA are usually normal. Most importantly, this patient has had symptoms for about 3 weeks, and a diagnosis of JIA cannot be considered unless symptoms are present for more than 6 weeks.

answers.content: Avascular necrosis of the femoral head
answers.explanation_why:
Legg-Calvé-Perthes disease is characterized by necrosis of the femoral head due to poor vascular perfusion, which leads to hip pain and decreased ability to bear weight in the affected hip joint, as well as x-ray findings of joint space widening and femoral head flattening. The underlying pathophysiology is multifactorial, poorly understood, and often described as idiopathic avascular necrosis. Legg-Calvé-Perthes disease likely results from a combination of repetitive mechanical stress, microtrauma, and genetic predisposition. This patient should be treated nonsurgically with NSAIDs, physical therapy, and restriction of weight-bearing. Surgical treatment should be considered for children with extensive damage to the femoral head.

See “Common causes of hip pain in children” table.

images.title: Displacement of femoral head and hinge abduction in Legg-Calvé-Perthes disease
images.description:
A. Normal anatomy: The femoral head is located in the center of the acetabulum.
B. Femoral head necrosis leads to lateral subluxation and displacement of the femoral head in the acetabulum.
C. Fractures and subsequent bone resorption result in an unstable femoral head. Lateral displacement puts a pathological strain on the femoral head when weight-bearing, which leads to deformities.
D. Hinge abduction: On hip abduction, the deformed lateral pillar of the femoral head impinges on the acetabular rim, preventing the femoral head from entering the acetabulum. This results in a hinge joint articulation instead of a ball-and-socket joint articulation at the hip.

images.title: Legg-Calvé-Perthes disease
images.description: X-ray pelvis (AP view) of a 7-year-old child with atraumatic right hip pain and limpThe right femoral epiphysis (green overlay) is fragmented (red lines) and smaller than the left epiphysis. There is flattening of its articular surface.The appearance is consistent with avascular necrosis.Dashed line: normal shape of femoral articular surface; GS: gonad shield

question_text: An 11-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department 1 hour after falling from her bicycle. The girl was racing with her cousin when she lost control and fell onto her right side. She has nausea and severe pain in the right shoulder. She is in acute distress. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 85/min, respirations are 15/min, and blood pressure is 135/85 mm Hg. Examination shows swelling and tenderness over the right clavicle and pain exacerbated by movement; range of motion is limited. The skin over the clavicle is intact. The radial pulse in the right arm is intact. Sensory examination of the right upper limb shows no abnormalities. An x‑ray of the chest is shown. In addition to analgesia, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management for this patient's shoulder?
content_preview: An 11-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department 1 hour after falling from her bicycle. The girl was racing with her cousin when she lost control and fell onto her right side. She has nausea and severe pain in the right shoulder. She is in acute distress. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 85/min, respirations are 15/min, and blood pressure is 135/85 mm Hg. Examination shows swelling and tenderness over the right clavicle and pain exacerbated by movement; range of motion is limited. The skin over the clavicle is intact. The radial pulse in the right arm is intact. Sensory examination of the right upper limb shows no abnormalities. An x‑ray of the chest is shown. In addition to analgesia, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management for this patient's shoulder?
hint: This patient has shoulder pain, limited range of motion, and tenderness and swelling over the clavicle. The skin is intact, and there is no evidence of neurovascular damage. The x-ray shows a nondisplaced midshaft fracture of the clavicle.
learning_objective: Recognize a nondisplaced midshaft fracture of the clavicle, and choose the most appropriate management.

answers.explanation_why: Tension band wiring using K-wires is performed for unstable lateral clavicle fractures, which have an increased risk of nonunion. Tension band wiring is not the treatment of choice for midshaft fractures.

In a patient with a midclavicular fracture, open reduction and internal fixation (ORIF) with a clavicular plate is indicated only in the presence of one of the following: tenting and blanching of the overlying skin, open fracture, severe displacement or > 2 cm of shortening, neurovascular injury, floating shoulder injury, or established nonunion. For nondisplaced midclavicular fractures, ORIF is not indicated; these fractures typically heal well, and surgery might actually increase the incidence of delayed union or nonunion.

A shoulder spica cast is not the technique of choice for shoulder immobilization in a patient with a clavicular fracture. This cast is bulky, difficult to apply, does not allow early physiotherapy, and is associated with an increased risk of adhesive capsulitis (frozen shoulder).

Conservative treatment with a simple shoulder sling for 4–8 weeks is the treatment of choice for nondisplaced midshaft fractures of the clavicle because these fractures typically heal very well without significant intervention. After 2–4 weeks, physiotherapy should be initiated. Excessively shortened or displaced fractures require surgery.

images.title: Broad arm sling using triangular bandage

answers.content: Obtain an MRI of the right shoulder
answers.explanation_why: For unstable clavicular fractures, a plain MRI of the shoulder is used to assess the conoid and trapezoid ligaments (coracoclavicular ligaments), the acromioclavicular joint, and the sternoclavicular joint. However, injury to these structures is unlikely in this patient, since she has an isolated midclavicular fracture from low-energy trauma.

Arteriography is only indicated if injury to the subclavian vessels is suspected (e.g., if radial or brachial pulses are weak or a bruit over the fracture site is heard). Since peripheral pulses are intact in this patient, arteriography is not required. In addition, injury to subclavian vessels following a clavicular fracture due to blunt trauma is extremely rare.

images.title: Acute nondisplaced fracture of the right clavicle
images.description: X-ray right clavicle (AP view) of a child after a recent fall on an outstretched armA subtle nondisplaced fracture (green overlay) is seen at the mid to medial third of the right clavicle. There is no callus formation.Arrowheads: overlying artefact; red overlay: growth plate

question_text: A 4-hour-old male newborn has perioral discoloration for the past several minutes. Oxygen by nasal cannula does not improve the cyanosis. He was delivered by cesarean delivery at 37 weeks' gestation to a 38-year-old woman, gravida 3, para 2. Apgar scores were 8 and 9 at 1 and 5 minutes, respectively. The mother has type 2 diabetes mellitus that was well-controlled during the pregnancy. She has not received any immunizations since her childhood. The newborn's temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 170/min, respirations are 55/min, and blood pressure is 80/60 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry shows an oxygen saturation of 85%. Cardiopulmonary examination shows a 2/6 holosystolic murmur along the lower left sternal border. The abdomen is soft and non-tender. Echocardiography shows pulmonary arteries arising from the posterior left ventricle, and the aorta rising anteriorly from the right ventricle. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 4-hour-old male newborn has perioral discoloration for the past several minutes. Oxygen by nasal cannula does not improve the cyanosis. He was delivered by cesarean delivery at 37 weeks' gestation to a 38-year-old woman, gravida 3, para 2. Apgar scores were 8 and 9 at 1 and 5 minutes, respectively. The mother has type 2 diabetes mellitus that was well-controlled during the pregnancy. She has not received any immunizations since her childhood. The newborn's temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 170/min, respirations are 55/min, and blood pressure is 80/60 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry shows an oxygen saturation of 85%. Cardiopulmonary examination shows a 2/6 holosystolic murmur along the lower left sternal border. The abdomen is soft and non-tender. Echocardiography shows pulmonary arteries arising from the posterior left ventricle, and the aorta rising anteriorly from the right ventricle. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: Echocardiography findings are consistent with the diagnosis of transposition of the great arteries (TGA): In TGA, the systemic circulation is disconnected from pulmonary circulation and venous blood that is received by the right ventricle is pumped to the rest of the body without being oxygenated. TGA is more commonly associated with infants born to diabetic mothers.
learning_objective: Recognize transposition of the great arteries, and choose the most appropriate initial management.

answers.explanation_why: Without treatment, transposition of the great vessels is fatal. If the disease is allowed to follow its natural course, the mortality rate within the first year alone is about 90%.

TGA results in rapidly worsening hypoxemia and cyanosis shortly after birth, and relies on a patent ductus arteriosus. The ductus arteriosus is kept patent in fetal circulation by the effect of low partial pressure of oxygen in fetal circulation, as well as by endogenously produced prostaglandin E. After birth, the ductus arteriosus begins to close in response to an increase in the partial pressure of oxygen. Intravenously administered prostaglandin E1 keeps the ductus arteriosus open and allows mixing of blood between the pulmonary and systemic circulation. This effect is crucial for initial survival of infants with TGA because it is the only way to maintain oxygenation of the arterial blood until surgical repair can be performed.

images.title: Intracardiac shunt in the transposition of the great vessels
images.description: In transposition of the great vessels, deoxygenated blood enters the systemic circulation. Survival after birth is only possible via an intracardiac shunt (e.g., across a patent ductus arteriosus and/or a patent foramen ovale). The shunt diverts oxygenated blood from the pulmonary circulation into the systemic circulation (white arrows).

answers.explanation_why: The ductus arteriosus is kept patent in fetal circulation by the low partial pressure of oxygen in fetal circulation, as well as by endogenously produced prostaglandin E. Indomethacin, a nonselective cyclooxygenase inhibitor, closes the ductus arteriosus by decreasing prostaglandin synthesis. Because a patent ductus arteriosus is vital for this newborn's survival, administering indomethacin would be a grave mistake.

An arterial switch operation is required in all neonates with transposition of the great arteries. This procedure is usually delayed for 2–3 days until the high pulmonary vascular resistance of fetal circulation decreases. A different therapeutic measure is required immediately to maintain a patent ductus arteriosus while preparations for surgery are made.
A CT angiography is not indicated in this newborn with transposition of the great vessels because it would not alter the clinical management and echocardiography has already confirmed the diagnosis.

question_text: A 2-day-old male newborn is brought to the emergency department by his mother because of irritability and vomiting for 2 hours. During this period, he has vomited bilious fluid three times. He has not yet passed stool. The mother has breastfed the newborn every 2 hours. He has wet two diapers during the last 2 days. He was born at term and was delivered at home. Pregnancy and delivery were uncomplicated. The mother had no prenatal care during pregnancy. The patient currently weighs 3100 g (6 lb 13 oz) and is 50 cm (19.6 in) in length. The newborn appears restless. His temperature is 37.3°C (99.14°F), pulse is 166/min, respirations are 60/min, and blood pressure is 70/45 mm Hg. There is no redness or warmth around the umbilical cord stump. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. Bowel sounds are sparse. The abdomen is distended. Digital rectal examination shows no abnormalities. An x-ray of the abdomen with contrast shows dilated small bowel loops, a microcolon, and a mixture of gas and meconium located in the right lower quadrant. A nasogastric tube is placed and fluid resuscitation is begun. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?
content_preview: A 2-day-old male newborn is brought to the emergency department by his mother because of irritability and vomiting for 2 hours. During this period, he has vomited bilious fluid three times. He has not yet passed stool. The mother has breastfed the newborn every 2 hours. He has wet two diapers during the last 2 days. He was born at term and was delivered at home. Pregnancy and delivery were uncomplicated. The mother had no prenatal care during pregnancy. The patient currently weighs 3100 g (6 lb 13 oz) and is 50 cm (19.6 in) in length. The newborn appears restless. His temperature is 37.3°C (99.14°F), pulse is 166/min, respirations are 60/min, and blood pressure is 70/45 mm Hg. There is no redness or warmth around the umbilical cord stump. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. Bowel sounds are sparse. The abdomen is distended. Digital rectal examination shows no abnormalities. An x-ray of the abdomen with contrast shows dilated small bowel loops, a microcolon, and a mixture of gas and meconium located in the right lower quadrant. A nasogastric tube is placed and fluid resuscitation is begun. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?
hint: This newborn presents with bilious vomiting, a distended abdomen, and sparse bowel sounds, all of which are consistent with bowel obstruction. The findings of dilated small bowel loops on abdominal x-ray and a microcolon indicate meconium ileus as the cause for obstruction and explains why he has not yet passed stool.
learning_objective: Recognize meconium ileus as a cause of bowel obstruction in a newborn, and choose the most appropriate initial management.

answers.explanation_why: Reassurance with later follow-up would not be appropriate management for this infant who has several concerning symptoms including vomiting and inability to pass stool. Delayed treatment in an infant with symptoms of bowel obstruction may lead to dehydration, intestinal perforation, or meconium peritonitis. In this newborn, urgent management is warranted to prevent such complications.

Gastrografin enema is both diagnostic and therapeutic for meconium ileus. A gastrografin enema will allow visualization of the rectum and bowel to rule out other anatomical causes for bowel obstruction (e.g., intestinal atresia or volvulus) and, in the case of meconium ileus, can reveal the Neuhauser sign, microcolon, or meconium pellets. The contrast agent can also induce a laxative effect as the increase of osmolarity within the lumen of the bowel results in the breakdown and passage of the meconium obstruction.

More than 90% of patients with meconium ileus will have cystic fibrosis (CF). For unknown reasons, newborn screens for CF in patients with meconium ileus are often initially negative and require additional testing. Infants with meconium ileus should undergo diagnostic testing for CF through a sweat test or, if sufficient amounts of sweat cannot be obtained, through genotyping.

images.title: Management of bilious vomiting in the newborn

answers.explanation_why: Exploratory laparotomy should be considered in patients presenting with symptoms of obstruction when there is concern for bowel perforation, peritonitis, or volvulus and associated bowel ischemia. This newborn does not have any free air on x-ray nor contrast leak that would suggest bowel perforation. He is hemodynamically stable and afebrile and his abdomen is distended, but there is no guarding or abdominal rigidity, which would suggest peritonitis, although these findings are unreliable in a newborn. This newborn should undergo nonsurgical management. Surgery would be considered only when meconium ileus is complicated or if nonsurgical treatment fails.

A rectal suction biopsy is the gold standard confirmatory test for Hirschsprung's disease. Newborns with Hirschsprung's disease also present with symptoms of bowel obstruction and inability to pass stool, but rectal examination often reveals a tight anal sphincter and explosive discharge of stool and gas. This patient had a normal rectal exam with x-ray showing evidence of obstruction in the terminal ileum instead of the colon and no signs of reduced caliber of the rectum, making Hirschsprung's disease an unlikely diagnosis.

Colonoscopy can be used to visualize the rectum and colon in patients presenting with symptoms of bowel obstruction. Colonoscopy is an invasive procedure that requires sedating the newborn; less invasive diagnostic modalities should be considered first.

answers.content: CT scan of the abdomen with contrast
answers.explanation_why: A CT scan of the abdomen with contrast can be used to assess the level and severity of intestinal blockage in patients in whom bowel obstruction is suspected, especially in adults. In a newborn presenting with symptoms of bowel obstruction, anatomic causes for obstruction (e.g., duodenal stenosis, ileal atresia) need to be investigated via imaging. However, in children, and especially in a 2-day-old newborn, a CT scan should be avoided whenever possible to minimize radiation exposure and associated long-term complications.

question_text: A 7-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his mother 1 hour after falling off his bike and landing head-first on the pavement. His mother says that he did not lose consciousness but has been agitated and complaining about a headache since the event. He has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. His temperature is 37.1°C (98.7°F), pulse is 115/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 100/65 mm Hg. There is a large bruise on the anterior scalp and several superficial abrasions on both hands and knees. Examination, including neurologic examination, shows no other abnormalities. A noncontrast CT scan of the head shows a nondepressed linear skull fracture with a 2-mm separation. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 7-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his mother 1 hour after falling off his bike and landing head-first on the pavement. His mother says that he did not lose consciousness but has been agitated and complaining about a headache since the event. He has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. His temperature is 37.1°C (98.7°F), pulse is 115/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 100/65 mm Hg. There is a large bruise on the anterior scalp and several superficial abrasions on both hands and knees. Examination, including neurologic examination, shows no other abnormalities. A noncontrast CT scan of the head shows a nondepressed linear skull fracture with a 2-mm separation. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: This patient presents with agitation and headache, both of which can be signs of elevated intracranial pressure (ICP).
learning_objective: Choose the most appropriate management for a child with a skull fracture and signs of potentially elevated intracranial pressure.

answers.explanation_why: Although asymptomatic patients with relatively small (< 3 mm) linear, nondepressed skull fractures may be sent home without further management, those with signs of potentially elevated ICP require further inpatient observation. Other indications for inpatient observation include evidence of traumatic brain injury on imaging (e.g., intracranial hemorrhage), signs of physical abuse, or caregivers who are unreliable or unable to return if neurological deficits develop within 24 hours after release.

Asymptomatic patients with relatively small, linear skull fractures (< 3 mm) without depression may be sent home if a caregiver is able to properly monitor the patient for signs of altered consciousness or other new neurological symptoms for 24 hours. This patient exhibits signs of potential elevated ICP (e.g., headache, agitated state), which requires another action at this time.

Contacting child protective services is not necessary because this patient does not have identifiable signs of physical abuse (e.g., subdural hemorrhages, buckle fractures, fractures showing different states of healing on x-ray) and thus his injury was most likely accidental.

A brain MRI is a costly imaging modality that would not provide additional useful information for the management of this patient based on his current presentation. It may be indicated for patients in which the clinical picture is inconsistent with the CT scan findings (e.g., a patient with a worsening condition despite a normal CT scan), or if diffuse axonal injury may be suspected (acceleration/deceleration injuries or rotational injuries). The primary clinical manifestation of diffuse axonal injury is loss of consciousness; an MRI may be indicated in this child if he develops any deficits in consciousness.
CT angiography would be indicated for the evaluation of patients with cerebral aneurysms or arteriovenous malformations but does not play a role in the management of patients with acute head trauma.

question_text: A 6-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of right hip pain that started that afternoon. His mother reports that he has also been limping since the pain developed. He says that the pain worsens when he moves or walks. He participated in a dance recital yesterday, but his mother believes that he was not injured at the time. He was born at term and has been healthy except for an episode of nasal congestion and mild cough 10 days ago. His mother has rheumatoid arthritis and his grandmother has osteoporosis. He is at the 50^th percentile for height and 50^th percentile for weight. His temperature is 37.5°C (99.6°F), pulse is 105/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 90/78 mm Hg. His right hip is slightly abducted and externally rotated. Examination shows no tenderness, warmth, or erythema. He is able to bear weight. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show a hemoglobin concentration of 12.3 g/dL, a leukocyte count of 8500/mm^3, and an erythrocyte sedimentation rate of 12 mm/h. Ultrasonography of the right hip shows increased fluid within the joint. X-ray of the hips shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
content_preview: A 6-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of right hip pain that started that afternoon. His mother reports that he has also been limping since the pain developed. He says that the pain worsens when he moves or walks. He participated in a dance recital yesterday, but his mother believes that he was not injured at the time. He was born at term and has been healthy except for an episode of nasal congestion and mild cough 10 days ago. His mother has rheumatoid arthritis and his grandmother has osteoporosis. He is at the 50th percentile for height and 50th percentile for weight. His temperature is 37.5°C (99.6°F), pulse is 105/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 90/78 mm Hg. His right hip is slightly abducted and externally rotated. Examination shows no tenderness, warmth, or erythema. He is able to bear weight. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show a hemoglobin concentration of 12.3 g/dL, a leukocyte count of 8500/mm3, and an erythrocyte sedimentation rate of 12 mm/h. Ultrasonography of the right hip shows increased fluid within the joint. X-ray of the hips shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
hint: This patient's effusion will likely improve over the next couple of weeks.
learning_objective: Recognize transient synovitis.

answers.explanation_why: Patients with slipped capital femoral epiphysis (SCFE) are typically older than this patient, presenting at about 10–16 years of age. Additionally, SCFE occurs most often in obese boys, and this patient is at the 50^th percentile for height and 50^th percentile for weight. Exam findings would also likely reveal external rotation along with flexion at the hip, not just external rotation and abduction. X-ray would show sclerotic epiphysis with joint widening when radiographic changes begin, but might be normal for the initial 4–6 months, meaning imaging alone is not enough to exclude SCFE in this patient.

This otherwise healthy child presents with a recent history of upper respiratory tract infection as well as hip pain and a limp for the past 24 hours, the combination of which suggests transient synovitis (TS). On exam, the right hip is slightly abducted and externally rotated, a common finding in patients with hip pain as this position decreases joint capsule tension and the resulting pain. Patients with TS typically present with no (or low-grade) fever and normal laboratory findings (e.g., normal WBC count and ESR). TS can manifest with unilateral or bilateral joint effusion on ultrasonography, unlike septic arthritis, in which joint effusion is almost always a unilateral finding.

TS is a mild, self-limited disease and treatment is conservative with NSAIDs (e.g., ibuprofen) and rest. If the effusion and/or the hip pain fails to resolve, follow-up imaging should be obtained to reassess for other conditions (e.g., Legg-Calvé-Perthes disease).

Legg-Calvé-Perthes disease (LCPD) is commonly seen in young patients who present with insidious-onset hip pain that may fluctuate with activity and a limp. X-ray findings may be normal in early disease and in later disease show medial joint space widening and an area of radiolucency around the femoral head indicative of subchondral fracture (crescent sign). While early LCPD cannot be entirely excluded, the patient's recent upper respiratory tract infection and the acute onset of symptoms make another diagnosis more likely.

images.title: Legg-Calvé-Perthes disease
images.description: X-ray pelvis (AP view) of a childThe left femoral epiphysis (green overlay) is small, flattened (coxa plana), and sclerotic. The hip joint space is widened.This appearance is consistent with Legg-Calvé-Perthes disease. Early radiographic findings may include medial joint space widening and reduced bone density. Later, the femoral head may become small, fragmented, flattened, and sclerotic.

answers.explanation_why: Developmental dysplasia of the hip (DDH) is usually detected in newborns. Risk factors are female sex, breech delivery, and a family history of DDH. If not identified at birth, DDH can lead to progressive hip pain and difficulty walking very early in life. This patient has a normal birth history and has not had hip pain until this point. Moreover, unlike in this patient, an x-ray of a patient with DDH would likely be abnormal, with potential findings of acetabular dysplasia or femoral head dysplasia.

This patient has a recent infection, making him susceptible to septic arthritis of the hip. However, the index of suspicion for septic arthritis should be low in this case because the patient is able to bear weight and has normal vital signs and laboratory studies. Furthermore, a patient with septic arthritis of the hip would present with exquisite hip pain on palpation and the skin over the affected joint would be warm and erythematous.

Although osteomyelitis of the hip or femur can manifest with pain and limping, the affected area is typically tender and warm to palpation. In children, osteomyelitis also usually affects the long-bone metaphysis rather than the joints, which would be more likely affected in infants. Laboratory findings usually include an elevated WBC count and ESR. X-ray often shows no abnormalities during the first few days of infection but may reveal periosteal bone deposition.

question_text: A 3-year-old girl is brought to the physician for the evaluation of a 1-month history of episodes of irritability and occasional vomiting. The parents report that she has been drowsy during much of the day and has not engaged in her usual activities during this period. She was born at term and has been healthy. She is at the 60^th percentile for height, 40^th percentile for weight, and 90^th percentile for head circumference. The patient is irritable and listless. Her vital signs are within normal limits. Ophthalmic examination shows bilateral optic disc swelling. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. A cranial CT scan with contrast shows enlargement of the ventricular spaces as well as a 4-cm enhancing solid mass with scattered calcifications within the 4^th ventricle. Which of the following is the most likely underlying mechanism for this patient's symptoms?
content_preview: A 3-year-old girl is brought to the physician for the evaluation of a 1-month history of episodes of irritability and occasional vomiting. The parents report that she has been drowsy during much of the day and has not engaged in her usual activities during this period. She was born at term and has been healthy. She is at the 60th percentile for height, 40th percentile for weight, and 90th percentile for head circumference. The patient is irritable and listless. Her vital signs are within normal limits. Ophthalmic examination shows bilateral optic disc swelling. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. A cranial CT scan with contrast shows enlargement of the ventricular spaces as well as a 4-cm enhancing solid mass with scattered calcifications within the 4th ventricle. Which of the following is the most likely underlying mechanism for this patient's symptoms?
hint: Dilation of the ventricles and signs of increased intracranial pressure (ICP), such as vomiting, papilledema, and irritability, indicate hydrocephalus. Hydrocephalus in a 3-year-old child with a mass in the 4^th ventricle suggests an ependymoma.
learning_objective: Recognize obstructive hydrocephalus, and recall its causes.

answers.explanation_why:
Cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) overproduction is a rare cause of hydrocephalus and only occurs due to choroid plexus tumors. A choroid plexus papilloma may manifest with communicating hydrocephalus and a solid mass that may be calcified. However, pediatric choroid plexus papillomas are typically seen in the lateral ventricles and are relatively rare, accounting for < 6% of intracranial tumors in this age group.

Unlike in the pediatric population, the most common site of a choroid plexus papilloma among adults is the fourth ventricle.

Cerebral edema is a complication of a variety of central nervous system diseases (e.g., stroke, infection, trauma), and often results in raised ICP, which manifests with headache, vomiting, and papilledema. Brain tumors may have surrounding parenchymal edema that can exacerbate raised ICP symptoms. However, cerebral edema does not result in enlarged ventricles. While some of this patient's symptoms can be attributed to edema, the majority are likely due to hydrocephalus.

A congenital failure of the foramen of Magendie to open is the underlying cause of Dandy-Walker malformation (DWM). DWM is characterized by cystic dilation of the fourth ventricle, cerebellar vermis hypoplasia, and hydrocephalus. This patient has no symptoms of cerebellar disease (e.g., ataxia), and there is no evidence of cerebellar hypoplasia on her CT scan. Moreover, symptoms of DWM usually appear within the first year of life, unlike this patient who presents at 3 years of age.

images.title: Dandy-Walker syndrome
images.description: Cranial MRI of a young child (T2 weighted, sagittal view)The posterior fossa and the pons appear cystic and hyperintense. The cerebellum also appears hypoplastic and the posterior fossa is enlarged.This radiographic appearance suggests Dandy-Walker syndrome.

answers.explanation_why: Impaired CSF reabsorption by the arachnoid granulations is seen in conditions associated with increased pressure in the dural venous sinuses (e.g., dural venous thrombosis). Dural venous sinus thrombosis in children may produce symptoms that are similar to this patient's, such as irritability, vomiting, and communicating hydrocephalus (dilation of all ventricles). However, dural venous thrombosis usually occurs in patients with pericranial infections (e.g., sinusitis, mastoiditis), hypercoagulable states, or following trauma. Moreover, patients have a cord-like hyperdensity within the dural sinus on CT scan.

Ependymomas usually develop from the lining of the ventricular system and, if they grow large enough, will cause obstruction of CSF flow and consequent dilation of the ventricles proximal to the obstruction (obstructive hydrocephalus). This patient's tumor is in the fourth ventricle, which is the most common location for ependymoma in children and the last ventricle along the CSF pathway; as such, all ventricles become dilated with trapped CSF. Ependymomas typically appear as homogeneous enhancing masses on CT neuroimaging, often with cysts and calcifications. Ependymomas have a poor prognosis, especially when located in the posterior fossa. The next step in management for this patient would be a brain MRI to provide better images of the tumor. Treatment would likely involve surgical resection and possibly radiation therapy.

question_text: A 17-year-old girl comes to the physician for a scheduled colonoscopy. She was diagnosed with familial adenomatous polyposis at the age of 13 years. Last year, flexible sigmoidoscopy showed 12 adenomatous polyps (< 6 mm) that were removed endoscopically. Her father and her paternal grandmother were diagnosed with colon cancer at the age of 37 and 39 years, respectively. The patient appears nervous but otherwise well. Her vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows no abnormalities. A complete blood count and serum concentrations of electrolytes, urea nitrogen, and creatinine are within the reference range. A colonoscopy shows hundreds of diffuse 4–9 mm adenomatous polyps covering the colon and > 30 rectal adenomas. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 17-year-old girl comes to the physician for a scheduled colonoscopy. She was diagnosed with familial adenomatous polyposis at the age of 13 years. Last year, flexible sigmoidoscopy showed 12 adenomatous polyps (< 6 mm) that were removed endoscopically. Her father and her paternal grandmother were diagnosed with colon cancer at the age of 37 and 39 years, respectively. The patient appears nervous but otherwise well. Her vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows no abnormalities. A complete blood count and serum concentrations of electrolytes, urea nitrogen, and creatinine are within the reference range. A colonoscopy shows hundreds of diffuse 4–9 mm adenomatous polyps covering the colon and > 30 rectal adenomas. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: The patient's diagnosis of familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP) significantly increases her risk of early colorectal cancer.
learning_objective: Recognize the progression of familial adenomatous polyposis, and choose the most appropriate surgical management.

answers.explanation_why: Patients with a diagnosis of FAP or who are at risk for developing FAP based on family history are generally screened with yearly colonoscopies. Because this patient has experienced a dramatic increase in the number of colonic polyps in the past year, conducting another colonoscopy in 6 months would be inappropriate given her risk of developing colorectal cancer.
Although an endoscopic biopsy would help differentiate between grades of dysplasia, the sheer number of polyps in this patient puts her at high risk of cancer development.

Sulindac may cause polyp regression in patients with FAP but does not decrease the risk of cancer. It is generally used as an adjunct for patients whose disease development is being monitored via colonoscopies. Given the patient's dramatic increase in the number of colonic polyps in the past year, medical therapy alone is no longer sufficient.

A marked increase in polyps from the previous colonoscopy in a patient with FAP is an indication for proctocolectomy with ileoanal anastomosis. Other indications for proctocolectomy with ileoanal anastomosis are colorectal cancer, high-grade dysplasia, and inability to survey the colon because of polyps. This patient requires continuous follow-up after surgery because cancer can occur in the ileum or the remaining rectum.

This chemotherapeutic regimen is one that is used as adjuvant therapy for colon cancer. The patient does not have biopsy-proven colon cancer and will have to await pathology results before considering further medical therapy.

answers.content: CT scan of the abdomen with contrast
answers.explanation_why: Imaging would be an option if extraintestinal disease were suspected (e.g., Gardner syndrome). The patient has vital signs within normal limits, no significant findings on exam, and laboratory values including CBC that are within reference ranges; her disease is most likely localized to the colon and rectum.

question_text: An 11-month-old boy is brought to the emergency department because of intermittent episodes of inconsolable crying for 4 hours. The parents report that the patient does not appear to be in discomfort between episodes, and moves and plays normally. The episodes have occurred at roughly 15-minute intervals and have each lasted a few minutes before subsiding. He has also vomited 3 times since these episodes began. The first vomitus appeared to contain food while the second and third appeared pale green in color. The patient was born at term and has been healthy. His immunizations are up-to-date. He has no history of recent travel. His older brother has Crohn disease. The patient is at 50^th percentile for height and 60^th percentile for weight. He does not appear to be in acute distress. His temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 125/min, respirations are 36/min, and blood pressure is 85/40 mm Hg. During the examination, the patient begins to cry and draws his knees up to his chest. Shortly thereafter, he passes stool with a mixture of blood and mucus; the patient's discomfort appears to resolve. Abdominal examination shows a sausage-shaped abdominal mass in the right upper quadrant. Abdominal ultrasound shows concentric rings of bowel in transverse view. Intravenous fluid resuscitation with normal saline is begun. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?
content_preview: An 11-month-old boy is brought to the emergency department because of intermittent episodes of inconsolable crying for 4 hours. The parents report that the patient does not appear to be in discomfort between episodes, and moves and plays normally. The episodes have occurred at roughly 15-minute intervals and have each lasted a few minutes before subsiding. He has also vomited 3 times since these episodes began. The first vomitus appeared to contain food while the second and third appeared pale green in color. The patient was born at term and has been healthy. His immunizations are up-to-date. He has no history of recent travel. His older brother has Crohn disease. The patient is at 50th percentile for height and 60th percentile for weight. He does not appear to be in acute distress. His temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 125/min, respirations are 36/min, and blood pressure is 85/40 mm Hg. During the examination, the patient begins to cry and draws his knees up to his chest. Shortly thereafter, he passes stool with a mixture of blood and mucus; the patient's discomfort appears to resolve. Abdominal examination shows a sausage-shaped abdominal mass in the right upper quadrant. Abdominal ultrasound shows concentric rings of bowel in transverse view. Intravenous fluid resuscitation with normal saline is begun. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?
hint: Acute cyclical abdominal pain with asymptomatic periods, vomiting (initially nonbilious), and currant jelly stool (composed of blood and mucus), together with a sausage-shaped mass in the right upper quadrant and target sign on abdominal ultrasound is consistent with intussusception. This condition is the most common cause of bowel obstruction in the first two years of life.
learning_objective: Recognize intussusception in a child, and choose the most appropriate initial intervention.

answers.explanation_why: A CT scan of the abdomen can be used to better visualize intraabdominal structures and masses, including possible tumors. Moreover, a CT scan may show a target sign and help identify pathological lead points in patients with intussusception. Although this patient has a palpable abdominal mass, his young age and acute onset of symptoms make an intraabdominal tumor an unlikely diagnosis. Moreover, a CT scan should only be performed in patients with suspected intussusception if the diagnosis is unclear and other diagnostic procedures are inconclusive because radiation exposure in children should be avoided whenever possible.

An exploratory laparotomy allows direct visualization of intraabdominal structures and is generally only indicated in certain cases of trauma or when other diagnostic modalities have failed. This patient has none of the traumatic indications needed for exploratory laparotomy and there are less invasive diagnostic methods available.

Abdominal x-ray in a patient with intussusception may reveal an inhomogeneous distribution of gas with absence of air at the site of invagination (usually right upper and lower quadrants). These x-ray findings are nonspecific and not helpful in establishing a definitive diagnosis. Also, radiation exposure in children should be avoided whenever possible.

An abdominal MRI can be used to better visualize intraabdominal structures or masses and possible tumors. Despite the exam findings, this patient's young age and acute onset of symptoms make an intraabdominal mass or tumor an unlikely diagnosis.

An image-guided air enema is both diagnostic and therapeutic for intussusception. An air enema or an enema with water-soluble contrast would show an interruption of contrast at the site of invagination and would likely reduce the intussusception.
