question_text: A 4-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department after a fall from her bed on her outstretched hand 1 hour ago. Her mother says that she has been inconsolable since. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination of the left forearm reveals a mild swelling distally. Her radial arm pulses are strong and symmetric. X-rays of the left forearm and wrist is shown. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 4-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department after a fall from her bed on her outstretched hand 1 hour ago. Her mother says that she has been inconsolable since. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination of the left forearm reveals a mild swelling distally. Her radial arm pulses are strong and symmetric. X-rays of the left forearm and wrist is shown. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: This patient fell onto her outstretched hand, which is a common cause of distal forearm fractures. The x-ray shows disruption of the distal radial cortex and periosteum on the side of tension (convex side) with an intact periosteum and cortex on the side of compression (concave side). This is characteristic of a greenstick fracture.
learning_objective: Recognize a greenstick fracture, and choose the most appropriate management.

answers.explanation_why: Application of a soft elastic bandage or a removable splint alone may be appropriate for a different type of incomplete fracture called torus fracture, which is stable and associated with minimal to no angulation. Greenstick fractures are inherently unstable, and there is a risk of further displacement without adequate immobilization.

Percutaneous pinning is not appropriate for greenstick fractures involving the distal radius because satisfactory fracture healing can be achieved by less invasive methods. Closed reduction followed by percutaneous insertion of intramedullary Kirschner wires is usually performed for mid-forearm fractures involving both the radius and the ulna, a radial neck fractures, or supracondylar fractures of the humerus.

Although open reduction and internal fixation (ORIF) achieves perfect anatomical reduction of the fracture, it is rarely required in children because any mild deformity that persists after non-surgical treatment is eventually corrected by bone remodeling as the child grows. Pediatric fractures that almost always require open reduction and internal fixation (i.e., fractures of necessity) include lateral humeral condyle fractures, Galeazzi fractures, displaced scaphoid fractures, displaced femoral neck fractures, distal tibial epiphysis fractures, displaced talar neck fractures, and type III or IV Salter-Harris fractures.

Immobilization with a cast is indicated for nondisplaced or only mildly displaced greenstick fractures, as in this patient. Additionally, physical activity should be restricted to enable healing. Closed reduction is required if there is significant angulation or displacement. Greenstick fractures are inherently unstable, and there is a risk of further displacement without adequate immobilization. After initial care, follow-up with an orthopedic surgeon is indicated to assess for complications (e.g., refracture) and to ensure complete reunion. Nondisplaced greenstick fractures usually heal without long-term complications within 4–6 weeks.

images.title: Complete vs. incomplete fractures
images.description: In a complete fracture, there is a discontinuity between the bone fragments, whereas in incomplete fractures, the fracture line is either absent or does not completely traverse the entire bone. Incomplete fractures are more common in children due to their thicker, stronger periosteum and the greater elasticity of growing bones. Types of incomplete fractures include:Buckle (torus) fracture: A compressive force results in bulging, i.e., buckling of the cortex. More specifically, a buckle fracture is characterized by bulging of only one side of the cortex (the concave side), while a fracture in which the bulge is circumferential is referred to more precisely as a “torus fracture.” However, the terms are frequently used interchangeably.Greenstick fracture: There is discontinuity of the cortex and periosteum on the convex (tension) side of the fracture, but bending occurs only on the concave (compression) side.Bowing fracture: There is angulation but no discontinuity of the cortex or periosteum.

answers.explanation_why: Closed reduction is indicated for displaced fractures or if there is significant angulation (> 10° in children aged 0–5 years). Minor angulations in pediatric fractures do not require manual reduction because they are often compensated during remodeling and growth. Greenstick fractures are inherently unstable, and there is a risk of further displacement without adequate immobilization. Splinting does not provide sufficient immobilization for greenstick fractures.

images.title: Greenstick fracture of the distal radius
images.description: X-ray distal left forearm (left: lateral view; right: PA view) of an adolescentA greenstick fracture of the distal radius is seen. The cortex on the radial (lateral) side of the fracture is disrupted and buckled (green overlay). However, the fracture line has not traversed the bone. The ulnar (medial) side of the radius is bowed, but the cortex is intact (black dotted line).Greenstick fractures are incomplete fractures. Typical locations are the shafts of the bones of the forearm and lower leg.Red overlay: growth plate

question_text: A 3-year-old boy is brought to the physician for a well-child examination. He feels well. He was born at 38 weeks' gestation and weighed 2766 g (6 lb 2 oz). He now weighs 14 kg (31 lb). There is no personal or family history of serious illness. His immunizations are up-to-date. He is at 60th percentile for height and 55th percentile for weight. Vital signs are within normal limits. The lungs are clear to auscultation. A grade 3/6 systolic ejection murmur is heard at the left upper sternal border and a grade 2/6 mid-diastolic murmur is heard at the left lower sternal border. S_2 is widely split and does not vary with respiration. The abdomen is soft and nontender; there is no organomegaly. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
content_preview: A 3-year-old boy is brought to the physician for a well-child examination. He feels well. He was born at 38 weeks' gestation and weighed 2766 g (6 lb 2 oz). He now weighs 14 kg (31 lb). There is no personal or family history of serious illness. His immunizations are up-to-date. He is at 60th percentile for height and 55th percentile for weight. Vital signs are within normal limits. The lungs are clear to auscultation. A grade 3/6 systolic ejection murmur is heard at the left upper sternal border and a grade 2/6 mid-diastolic murmur is heard at the left lower sternal border. S2 is widely split and does not vary with respiration. The abdomen is soft and nontender; there is no organomegaly. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
hint: This patient presents with a congenital heart defect that may lead to paradoxical embolism and stroke if not surgically corrected.
learning_objective: Recognize an atrial septal defect.

answers.explanation_why: A patent ductus arteriosus is often discovered incidentally in asymptomatic children. However, cardiac auscultation would usually show a loud continuous machine-like murmur (due to the constant left-to-right shunt) that is best heard in the left infraclavicular region.

A systolic murmur at the left upper sternal border may be a benign flow murmur. While benign (innocent) systolic murmurs are a common finding in children, they are usually soft (grade ≤ 2). The patient's findings of a diastolic murmur and a fixed split S_2 are also not consistent with a benign murmur and warrant further investigation.

This child presents with typical auscultation findings of an atrial septal defect (ASD) with the fixed (no change with respiration), widely split S_2 being the most specific. Right ventricular volume overload due to the left-to-right shunt across the ASD causes a delayed closure of the pulmonary valve relative to the aortic valve. Since the right and left sides of the heart communicate, the pressure difference that normally exists during respiration evens out; therefore, the duration of the split does not change with inspiration or expiration. The increased blood flow through the right side of the heart also causes a pulmonary flow murmur, which explains the patient's systolic ejection murmur at the left upper sternal border. Some patients with ASD can also have a soft, mid-diastolic murmur at the left lower sternal border secondary to increased flow across the tricuspid valve.

While a mid-diastolic murmur may be appreciated in patients with a ventricular septal defect (VSD) as a result of increased flow through the mitral valve, this murmur would usually be best heard at the cardiac apex (mitral area) rather than the left lower sternal border (tricuspid area). The classic auscultatory finding at the left lower sternal border in patients with a VSD would be a harsh holosystolic murmur.

Isolated pulmonary valve stenosis can cause a systolic ejection murmur at the left upper sternal border and a wide S_2 split but would not explain the mid-diastolic murmur at the left lower sternal border or the fixed split in S_2 (i.e., no variation with respiration).

Coarctation of the aorta usually presents a systolic ejection murmur in the paravertebral region due to blood flow through the aortic narrowing. It would not explain the fixed split in S_2 or the mid-diastolic murmur at the left lower sternal border.

question_text:
An 8-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his parents for short stature. Neither his clothing nor his shoe size has changed over the past year. He also frequently bumps into obstacles such as furniture and has headaches at night. He is always thirsty for cold water and has been urinating more frequently. Three years ago, he had an asthma attack that was treated with albuterol and a one-week course of steroids. His mother has Hashimoto's thyroiditis and had precocious puberty. His mother's height is 147 cm (4 ft 10 in) and his father's height is 160 cm (5 ft 3 in). He is at the 5^th percentile for height and 5^th percentile for weight. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 98/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 100/64 mm Hg. Examination shows a soft and nontender abdomen. The genitals and pubic hair are both Tanner stage 1. Axillary hair is absent. Patellar reflexes are 1+ bilaterally. Laboratory studies show:

Na^+

145 mEq/L

K^+

4.1 mEq/L

Cl^-

102 mEq/L

HCO_3^-

25 mEq/L

Ca^2+

9.4 mg/dL

Glucose
98 mg/dL

Thyroid-stimulating hormone
0.2 μU/mL

Thyroxine
3.9 μg/dL

Insulin-like growth factor 1

24 ng/mL (N= 61–356)

Insulin-like growth factor-binding protein 3
2.1 μg/mL (N = 1.6–6.5)

Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
content_preview: An 8-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his parents for short stature. Neither his clothing nor his shoe size has changed over the past year. He also frequently bumps into obstacles such as furniture and has headaches at night. He is always thirsty for cold water and has been urinating more frequently. Three years ago, he had an asthma attack that was treated with albuterol and a one-week course of steroids. His mother has Hashimoto's thyroiditis and had precocious puberty. His mother's height is 147 cm (4 ft 10 in) and his father's height is 160 cm (5 ft 3 in). He is at the 5th percentile for height and 5th percentile for weight. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 98/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 100/64 mm Hg. Examination shows a soft and nontender abdomen. The genitals and pubic hair are both Tanner stage 1. Axillary hair is absent. Patellar reflexes are 1+ bilaterally. Laboratory studies show: Na+ 145 mEq/L K+ 4.1 mEq/L Cl- 102 mEq/L HCO3- 25 mEq/L Ca2+ 9.4 mg/dL Glucose 98 mg/dL Thyroid-stimulating hormone 0.2 μU/mL Thyroxine 3.9 μg/dL Insulin-like growth factor 1 24 ng/mL (N= 61–356) Insulin-like growth factor-binding protein 3 2.1 μg/mL (N = 1.6–6.5) Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
hint: This boy has symptoms and laboratory findings suggestive of multiple hormonal deficiencies (diabetes insipidus, secondary hypothyroidism, and growth hormone deficiency). The fact that the child frequently bumps into obstacles suggests that the child has a peripheral visual field defect.
learning_objective: Recognize craniopharyngioma.

answers.explanation_why: Long-term corticosteroid therapy (e.g., for children with nephrotic syndrome) is known to cause short stature. However, children undergoing long-term steroid therapy would have a Cushingoid appearance characterized by obesity (unlike this child with a weight at the 5^th percentile) and a moon-like facies. This child was only on a week-long course of corticosteroids, which would not result in a short stature.
An expanding Rathke cleft cyst can cause headaches, visual field defects, and multiple hormone deficiencies due to hypopituitarism. However, symptoms usually occur between the ages of 30–50 years.

Schmidt syndrome, the most common form of autoimmune polyendocrine syndrome, can manifest with decreased thyroxine levels (due to hypothyroidism) as well as polyuria and polydipsia (due to type 1 diabetes mellitus). However, Schmidt syndrome is more common among women between 20–60 years of age and is associated with elevated TSH levels (primary hypothyroidism). GH deficiency (suggested by decreased IGF-1 levels) and short stature would be unexpected. Moreover, normal serum glucose along with headache and visual field defects suggest that polyuria and polydipsia in this patient are caused by central diabetes insipidus rather than diabetes mellitus.

Constitutional growth delay is a diagnosis of exclusion that is made once other causes of short stature have been ruled out. A different cause for short stature is more likely on account of the presence of multiple hormone deficiencies, headache, and visual field defects.

Although a low mid-parental height suggests a diagnosis of familial short stature, which is one of the most common causes of short stature, the presence of multiple hormone deficiencies, headache, and visual field defects indicates a different diagnosis.

Craniopharyngiomas are the most common cause of acquired hypopituitarism among children. This child presents with features of hypopituitarism such as growth hormone deficiency (as indicated by a low insulin-like growth factor 1 and short stature), diabetes insipidus (as indicated by polyuria and polydipsia), and secondary hypothyroidism (as indicated by hyporeflexia, low thyroid-stimulating hormone, and low thyroxine levels). Headache is caused by compression of the adjacent brain parenchyma and/or stretching of the dura mater, while visual field defects are the result of compression of the optic chiasm. A craniopharyngioma can be diagnosed by an MRI of the brain, which typically reveals a suprasellar mass that extends into the sella turcica. Craniopharyngiomas are excised surgically using a transfrontal approach.

Patients with multiple endocrine neoplasia type 1 (MEN 1) may develop pituitary adenomas, which can result in headaches, visual field defects, and multiple hormone deficiencies (due to destruction of the normal pituitary gland). However, pituitary adenomas in patients with MEN 1 usually develop during adulthood. In addition, by the time pituitary adenomas become symptomatic, patients almost always have increased serum calcium levels due to primary hyperparathyroidism, which is usually the earliest endocrine manifestation of MEN 1.

A large, nonsecretory pituitary adenoma may result in headaches, visual field defects, and multiple hormone deficiencies due to hypopituitarism. However, symptoms usually occur between the ages of 30–60 years. A different diagnosis is more likely in this 8-year-old boy.

question_text: A 2-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his parents because of difficulty walking and cold feet for the past 2 months. His parents report that he tires quickly from walking. The patient was born at 37 weeks' gestation and has met all developmental milestones. There is no personal or family history of serious illness. He is at the 50^th percentile for height and 40^th percentile for weight. His temperature is 36.9°C (98.4°F), pulse is 119/min, respirations are 32/min, and blood pressure is 140/85 mm Hg in the right arm. A grade 2/6 systolic murmur is heard in the left paravertebral region. At this time, further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following findings?
content_preview: A 2-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his parents because of difficulty walking and cold feet for the past 2 months. His parents report that he tires quickly from walking. The patient was born at 37 weeks' gestation and has met all developmental milestones. There is no personal or family history of serious illness. He is at the 50th percentile for height and 40th percentile for weight. His temperature is 36.9°C (98.4°F), pulse is 119/min, respirations are 32/min, and blood pressure is 140/85 mm Hg in the right arm. A grade 2/6 systolic murmur is heard in the left paravertebral region. At this time, further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following findings?
hint: Cold feet and potential lower-extremity claudication with physical exertion combined with high blood pressure in the upper extremities and a left paravertebral systolic murmur should raise concern for coarctation of the aorta (CoA).

answers.explanation_why: Rib notching can be seen on x-ray in patients with CoA, if compensatory collateral blood flow involves the intercostal vessels. The vessels may dilate to bypass the left ventricular outflow tract obstruction. While this patient may eventually develop visible rib notching, it is generally a sign of chronic disease and usually is not apparent in children before 5 years of age.

images.title: Coarctation of the aorta
images.description: X-ray chest (PA view)Focal indentation of the distal aortic arch is seen at the location of aortic coarctation (illustration). An additional finding is inferior rib notching (Roesler sign; examples indicated by arrowheads), which is produced by dilated intercostal arteries.The figure-3 sign of coarctation (indicated by red line) is seen in this patient. It is produced by prestenotic dilatation of the aortic arch and left subclavian artery in combination with post-stenotic dilatation of the descending aorta. The presence of bilateral rib notching indicates that the coarctation is distal to the origin of both subclavian arteries.

answers.explanation_why:
CoA is most commonly located at the aortic isthmus, resulting in increased blood flow to the upper body and decreased blood flow to the lower body. Patients with noncritical CoA (i.e., mild-to-moderate CoA) typically present later in life (e.g., during childhood) with features of upper body hyperperfusion (e.g., high blood pressure in the upper extremities) and features of lower body hypoperfusion (e.g., cold feet, claudication upon exertion, brachial-femoral delay). In noncritical CoA, the left ventricular outflow obstruction leads to myocardial hypertrophy and increased collateral blood flow (e.g., to the intercostal arteries); rib notching occurs as a consequence of the collateral circulation between the internal thoracic and intercostal arteries and is usually a late finding (typically after 5 years of age).

Doppler echocardiography is the confirmatory test of choice and should be performed in all patients with suspected CoA. It can identify the location and extent of the stenosis and show concurrent anomalies, such as a bicuspid aortic valve (present in ∼ 60% of patients).

images.title: Coarctation of the aorta (hypoplastic type)
images.description: (1) Hypoplasia of aorta can lead to hypertension (↑ BP) in the head and upper limbs as well as poststenotic hypoperfusion. In patent ductus arteriosus, this can be compensated by a right-to-left-shunt of blood from the pulmonary arteries into the aorta, resulting in the flow of mixed blood with decreased oxygen saturation (↓ SaO_2) to the general circulation.(2) After closure of the ductus arteriosus, the right-to-left shunt is absent (~ SaO_2) and there is hypoperfusion (↓ BP) of the abdominal organs and lower extremities with oxygenated blood.

answers.explanation_why: Interarm differences in blood pressure can be a finding of CoA in the rare case that the narrowing is proximal to the left subclavian artery. In such patients, blood pressure in the right arm would be higher than in the left arm. In most infants and children with aortic coarctation, we would instead expect differences in blood pressure between the upper and the lower extremities.

images.title: Coarctation of the aorta
images.description: (1) Stenosis distal to the left subclavian artery results in hypertension (↑ BP) in the upper extremities and the head, and hypotension (↓ BP) in the lower extremities and abdomen.(2) If coarctation involves the origin of the left subclavian artery, BP in the right arm and head will be higher than in the left arm, lower extremities, and abdomen.

answers.explanation_why: A right ventricular outflow tract obstruction (RVOTO) is typically seen in patients with tetralogy of Fallot. While patients with tetralogy of Fallot can also have a systolic ejection murmur, it is usually best heard at the left sternal border, rather than the left paravertebral region, as is the case in this patient. Furthermore, such patients usually present with (mild) cyanosis and intermittent hypoxic episodes that improve with squatting, none of which is present in this patient. CoA is characterized by a fixed supravalvular left ventricular outflow tract obstruction.

answers.content: Low tissue oxygenation in the legs
answers.explanation_why: Low tissue oxygenation in the legs is typically seen in patients with ductal-dependent CoA (i.e., critical CoA and concomitant patent ductus arteriosus). These patients typically have differential cyanosis, as deoxygenated blood flows across the patent ductus arteriosus into the postductal systemic circulation. This patient most likely has noncritical, non-ductal-dependent CoA as there is no history of differential cyanosis. In patients with noncritical CoA, the blood flow to the lower extremities, although reduced, is typically enough to maintain normal arterial oxygen saturation and, therefore, tissue oxygenation. Additionally, the oxygen extraction fraction may increase to compensate for the hypoperfusion, contributing to normal tissue oxygenation.

question_text: A 5-week-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his mother because of shortness of breath and noisy breathing for the past 2 weeks. She reports that the episodes are worse when he is agitated and better when he sleeps in supine position. During this period he has had frequent regurgitation of his feeds. He was born at 37 weeks' gestation. The neonatal period was complicated by transient tachypnea. His immunizations are up-to-date. His temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 160/min, respirations are 52/min, and blood pressure is 94/56 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 98%. Physical examination shows subcostal retractions. Stridor and diffuse wheezing are heard in the thorax. Anteroposterior and lateral x-rays of the chest show anterior tracheal bowing and narrowing. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 5-week-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his mother because of shortness of breath and noisy breathing for the past 2 weeks. She reports that the episodes are worse when he is agitated and better when he sleeps in supine position. During this period he has had frequent regurgitation of his feeds. He was born at 37 weeks' gestation. The neonatal period was complicated by transient tachypnea. His immunizations are up-to-date. His temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 160/min, respirations are 52/min, and blood pressure is 94/56 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 98%. Physical examination shows subcostal retractions. Stridor and diffuse wheezing are heard in the thorax. Anteroposterior and lateral x-rays of the chest show anterior tracheal bowing and narrowing. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: This patient's underlying condition is a rare but important cause of respiratory symptoms in infants. The presence of stridor (suggesting upper airway obstruction) and regurgitation of feeds (due to esophageal compression) are important clues.
learning_objective: Recognize a vascular ring causing respiratory symptoms in an infant, and choose the most appropriate next step in management.

answers.explanation_why: Racemic epinephrine is used to treat upper airway obstruction caused by severe croup, which is a common cause of respiratory symptoms in young children (although uncommon in children < 3 months of age). Croup manifests with hoarseness and a barking cough; fever and rhinorrhea may also be seen. This patient has stridor but no fever or rhinorrhea. Moreover, in croup, x-ray shows a steeple sign, not tracheal bowing.

images.title: Steeple sign
images.description: X-ray neck of a young child (AP view)The upper tracheal air column, which normally appears with a square-shouldered configuration, has assumed a conical shape (green overlay) reminiscent of a church steeple (steeple sign; cf. illustration).The steeple sign indicates subglottic airway narrowing and is most commonly seen in croup. However, it may also appear in other conditions (e.g., bacterial tracheitis, tumors). An accompanying lateral radiograph might additionally show inspiratory overdistention of the hypopharynx.

answers.explanation_why: Tracheoesophageal fistula (TEF) causes respiratory distress, drooling, choking, and an inability to feed in newborns; it is unlikely to present in a 5-week-old infant. In addition, the majority of patients with TEF have a history of polyhydramnios due to the inability of the fetus to swallow amniotic fluid. Furthermore, TEF does not explain this patient's stridor or x-ray findings.

images.title: Gross classification of esophageal atresia
images.description: Gross type A: esophageal atresia without tracheoesophageal fistulaGross type B: esophageal atresia with an upper tracheoesophageal fistulaGross type C: esophageal atresia with a lower tracheoesophageal fistulaGross type D: esophageal atresia with upper and lower tracheoesophageal fistulaGross type E: tracheoesophageal fistula without atresia

answers.explanation_why: Nebulized albuterol is used to treat acute asthma, which typically manifests with sudden shortness of breath, wheezing, and a dry cough that usually worsens at night. This patient presents with shortness of breath and wheezing, but his symptoms improve at night. In addition, chest x-ray findings in acute asthma exacerbation are expected to show hyperinflation of the lungs, not tracheal changes.

answers.content: Surgical division of a vascular ring
answers.explanation_why: A vascular ring is a rare cause of respiratory symptoms in infants that is treated with surgical division. Vascular rings typically manifest with shortness of breath, wheezing, stridor due to tracheal compression, as well as difficulty swallowing, regurgitation of food, and/or unintended weight loss resulting from esophageal compression. The severity of symptoms depends on the degree of tracheal and esophageal compression by the vascular ring. X-ray typically shows tracheal bowing and narrowing, indicating tracheal compression.

images.title: Double aortic arch
images.description: Ventral view of mediastinal structuresThere is constriction of the trachea and esophagus as a result of the additional aortic arch (vascular ring anomaly).

answers.explanation_why: Ceftriaxone is indicated for bacterial airway infection (e.g., epiglottitis), which can manifest with respiratory distress and inspiratory stridor. However, it usually also manifests in older children with sore throat, dysphagia, drooling, and acute onset of high fever, which are absent in this patient. Additionally, x-ray of the epiglottitis often shows a characteristic thumbprint sign (enlarged epiglottis), not the tracheal changes seen here.

images.title: Thumb and vallecula signs (epiglottitis)
images.description: X-ray soft tissue neck (lateral view)The epiglottis is swollen and rounded in appearance (thumb sign; highlighted by green overlay and black arrow) as a result of inflammation and edema. The normal air space between the tongue base and epiglottis has been almost entirely obliterated and is seen only as a shallow V-shaped space (vallecula sign; highlighted by red line).The thumb and vallecula signs are useful in the radiographic evaluation of epiglottitis.

answers.explanation_why: Supraglottoplasty is performed in severe cases of laryngomalacia. This condition typically manifests with low-pitched inspiratory stridor that worsens in the supine position and during sleeping or feeding. Other symptoms of laryngomalacia include reflux, swallowing dysfunction, and, in severe cases, failure to thrive. This patient presents with stridor that improves in the supine position and during sleeping. In addition, chest x-ray findings suggest involvement of the trachea rather than the larynx.

question_text: A 5-month-old male infant is brought to the physician by his parents for the evaluation of progressive enlargement of his head circumference. His parents report that he has been healthy except for an episode of tonsillitis 3 months ago treated with penicillin. The patient was born at term by a lower segment transverse cesarean delivery because of a transverse lie. He has met all developmental milestones. His immunizations are up-to-date. The patient is at the 50^th percentile for length, 50^th percentile for weight, and 95^th percentile for head circumference. He appears well-nourished. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 120/min, and blood pressure is 90/60 mm Hg. Physical examination shows a tense anterior fontanelle. The eyes deviate inferiorly and the eyelids are retracted. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?
content_preview: A 5-month-old male infant is brought to the physician by his parents for the evaluation of progressive enlargement of his head circumference. His parents report that he has been healthy except for an episode of tonsillitis 3 months ago treated with penicillin. The patient was born at term by a lower segment transverse cesarean delivery because of a transverse lie. He has met all developmental milestones. His immunizations are up-to-date. The patient is at the 50th percentile for length, 50th percentile for weight, and 95th percentile for head circumference. He appears well-nourished. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 120/min, and blood pressure is 90/60 mm Hg. Physical examination shows a tense anterior fontanelle. The eyes deviate inferiorly and the eyelids are retracted. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?
hint: This patient presents with macrocephaly, tense fontanelle, and a sunset eye sign, all of which suggest hydrocephalus.
learning_objective: Recognize hydrocephalus in an infant, and choose the initial neuroimaging modality.

answers.explanation_why: Diuretics such as furosemide decrease CSF production and are sometimes used as temporary therapy in patients too unstable to undergo surgery. However, imaging is first required to confirm the diagnosis and determine the underlying cause.

Although serial lumbar punctures were used in the past as a temporary measure in preterm infants with posthemorrhagic hydrocephalus as a complication of intraventricular hemorrhage, the procedure is no longer recommended. Imaging is first required to confirm the diagnosis and determine the underlying cause.

Although imaging is necessary to confirm the diagnosis, CT would expose this young patient to unnecessary radiation. CT scan may be indicated in older children in an acute setting to quickly identify the cause of increased intracranial pressure and in adults with suspected hydrocephalus.
CSF shunts are a definitive treatment for hydrocephalus. However, before proceeding with a surgical intervention, neuroimaging is required to confirm the diagnosis and determine the underlying cause.

A patient with hydrocephalus requires neuroimaging to determine the extent of the condition and the underlying cause. Ultrasound is the preferred imaging modality in newborns and young infants in whom the anterior fontanelle is still open because it allows direct visualization of the brain. Moreover, ultrasound does not involve radiation and does not require sedation of the patient.

Although standard MRI is safe for infants, sedation is required, making it less appropriate than ultrasonography. Ultra-fast MRI techniques, however, do not require infant sedation and can be used as an alternative to ultrasonography. MRI is the preferred imaging modality in older children in whom the anterior fontanelle has closed (it usually closes at 12–18 months of age).

question_text: An 18-month-old boy is brought to the physician for a well-child examination. His mother is concerned because he is unable to walk on his own. He has been increasingly irritable over the past month, has been feeding poorly, and has had multiple episodes of vomiting. His immunizations are up-to-date. He is at the 50^th percentile for height, 40^th percentile for weight, and 98^th percentile for head circumference. He appears lethargic. His vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows a bulging anterior fontanelle. The child is unable to stand without support and falls if he attempts to walk. Muscle tone is increased and deep tendon reflexes are 4+ in the lower extremities. Examination of the back is unremarkable. An MRI of the brain shows symmetrical enlargement of all four ventricles. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment for this patient?
content_preview: An 18-month-old boy is brought to the physician for a well-child examination. His mother is concerned because he is unable to walk on his own. He has been increasingly irritable over the past month, has been feeding poorly, and has had multiple episodes of vomiting. His immunizations are up-to-date. He is at the 50th percentile for height, 40th percentile for weight, and 98th percentile for head circumference. He appears lethargic. His vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows a bulging anterior fontanelle. The child is unable to stand without support and falls if he attempts to walk. Muscle tone is increased and deep tendon reflexes are 4+ in the lower extremities. Examination of the back is unremarkable. An MRI of the brain shows symmetrical enlargement of all four ventricles. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment for this patient?
hint: Irritability, poor feeding, vomiting, delayed gross motor milestones, upper motor neuron signs (increased muscle tone and hyperreflexia), macrocephaly, and a bulging anterior fontanelle are consistent with increased intracranial pressure (ICP). An MRI showing symmetrical enlargement of all 4 ventricles indicate a symptomatic, communicating hydrocephalus.
learning_objective: Recognize communicating hydrocephalus, and choose the most appropriate treatment.

answers.explanation_why: Cerebral aqueductoplasty may be used to treat obstructive hydrocephalus caused by stenosis of the aqueduct of Sylvius. Congenital stenosis of the aqueduct of Sylvius would present similarly, but the fourth ventricle would not be dilated with enlargement of all four ventricles.

A ventriculoperitoneal shunt, which diverts excess CSF from the ventricles to the peritoneal cavity, is the standard of care to decrease intracranial pressure in children with communicating hydrocephalus. Although spinal taps and the use of certain diuretics (e.g., furosemide, acetazolamide) may quickly decrease ICP, these measures are not effective in preventing the progression of hydrocephalus over the long term.

Although furosemide may decrease CSF production and intracranial pressure, it is less effective than standard therapy in decreasing ICP. Furosemide may be used temporarily in patients who are too unstable for standard therapy.

Although acetazolamide may decrease CSF production and intracranial pressure, it is less effective than standard therapy in decreasing ICP. Acetazolamide may be used temporarily in patients who are too unstable for the treatment of choice.

Studies have shown that serial lumbar punctures are not effective in preventing the progression of hydrocephalus. Frequent spinal taps also increase the risk of infection. Serial lumbar punctures may be used in preterm infants until they are large enough for the definitive treatment.

question_text: A previously healthy 5-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department 15 minutes after sustaining an injury to his right hand. His mother says that she was cleaning the bathroom when he accidentally knocked over the drain cleaner bottle and spilled the liquid onto his hand. On arrival, he is crying and holding his right hand in a flexed position. His temperature is 37.7°C (99.8°F), pulse is 105/min, respirations are 25/min, and blood pressure is 105/65 mm Hg. Examination of the right hand shows a 4 x 4 cm area of reddened, blistered skin. The area is very tender to light touch. His ability to flex and extend the right hand are diminished. Radial pulses are palpable. Capillary refill time is less than 3 seconds. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A previously healthy 5-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department 15 minutes after sustaining an injury to his right hand. His mother says that she was cleaning the bathroom when he accidentally knocked over the drain cleaner bottle and spilled the liquid onto his hand. On arrival, he is crying and holding his right hand in a flexed position. His temperature is 37.7°C (99.8°F), pulse is 105/min, respirations are 25/min, and blood pressure is 105/65 mm Hg. Examination of the right hand shows a 4 x 4 cm area of reddened, blistered skin. The area is very tender to light touch. His ability to flex and extend the right hand are diminished. Radial pulses are palpable. Capillary refill time is less than 3 seconds. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: The initial treatment for chemical burns is the same regardless of the chemical's pH.
learning_objective: Choose the initial treatment for chemical burns.

answers.explanation_why: Emergency escharotomy is indicated if vascular compromise is suspected (e.g., compartment syndrome), which is especially common in the case of peripheral, circumferential burns with the presence of eschar. Because this patient has good capillary refill and pulses of the affected hand, however, vascular compromise is very unlikely.

Wound debridement is performed to promote wound healing and decrease the risk of infection from the necrotic tissue. While this patient may require wound debridement, the offending agent first has to be removed from the skin to prevent further burn progression.

Mineral oil is the treatment of choice for skin burns caused by elemental metals (e.g., lithium, potassium, sodium, magnesium). These metals cannot be removed through irrigation with water because doing so results in a chemical reaction that would worsen the burn. However, this patient's chemical burn is unlikely to be caused by elemental metals and requires a different intervention.

Silver sulfadiazine is a topical antibiotic that can be considered in cases of severe and/or widespread, full-thickness burns. The absence of eschar in this patient's burn and the fact that it is tender make it more likely that he has a partial-thickness burn. Although he may still require antibiotics eventually, topical antibiotics would not be the most appropriate next step in management.

Split-thickness skin grafts are typically used in the case of injury affecting large areas of skin. Although this patient may benefit from skin grafting in the future, acute management of a chemical burn requires other interventions first.

Copious irrigation with water is the most appropriate initial step in management for the majority of chemical skin burns. It dilutes and removes the offending agent from the skin. Irrigation should be continued until the pH of the affected tissue has become neutral, which may take several hours in case of alkaline burns.

The only exceptions to this rule are burns caused by elemental metals (e.g., potassium, magnesium) and dry lime. In these cases, adding water can cause a chemical reaction that would worsen the burn; mineral oil should be used instead.

images.title: Second-degree burn (2a; superficial partial-thickness burn)
images.description: A singular blister on an erythematous base is visible on the back of the hand.The presence of a blister within the area of erythema differentiates this from a first-degree burn. No deeper tissue injury suggestive of a higher-degree burn is evident, confirming a second-degree burn.

question_text: A 9-year-old girl is brought to her primary care physician because of a 4-month history of early morning headaches and worsening fatigue. The headaches are often accompanied by nausea and sometimes relieved by vomiting. She stopped going to her ballet lessons 2 weeks ago because she was embarrassed about falling frequently and having increasing difficulty performing the steps. Her temperature is 36.8°C (98.2°F), pulse is 98/min, and blood pressure is 105/65 mm Hg. She has a broad-based gait. While standing with both feet together and raising her arms, closing her eyes does not affect her balance. She is unable to perform rapid, alternating movements with her hands. An MRI of the brain is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
content_preview: A 9-year-old girl is brought to her primary care physician because of a 4-month history of early morning headaches and worsening fatigue. The headaches are often accompanied by nausea and sometimes relieved by vomiting. She stopped going to her ballet lessons 2 weeks ago because she was embarrassed about falling frequently and having increasing difficulty performing the steps. Her temperature is 36.8°C (98.2°F), pulse is 98/min, and blood pressure is 105/65 mm Hg. She has a broad-based gait. While standing with both feet together and raising her arms, closing her eyes does not affect her balance. She is unable to perform rapid, alternating movements with her hands. An MRI of the brain is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
hint: The MRI scan shows a large (3.5 cm), well-defined, contrast-enhancing cystic mass in the lateral posterior fossa without ventricular involvement.
learning_objective: Recognize a pilocytic astrocytoma.

answers.explanation_why: Acoustic schwannomas can present with vertigo and/or dizziness that result in falls. However, patients will more commonly present with sensorineural hearing loss, which this patient lacks. More importantly, acoustic neuromas are found within the internal acoustic canal along CN VIII or within the cerebral hemispheres. Imaging for acoustic schwannoma would also show a cystic lesion with nodular parts. Finally, acoustic schwannomas occur rarely in children.

images.title: Vestibularis schwannoma (acoustic neuroma)
images.description:
Cranial MRI
Upper left: T2-weighted image (axial view)
Lower left and right: T1-weighted images after application of contrast agent (axial and coronal views)A tumor is visible on the right side between the brainstem and the cerebellum (green overlay), extending into the porus acousticus (arrow). There is strong contrast enhancement within the lesion and it has a hypointense center (red overlay), suggesting necrosis.

answers.explanation_why:
Pilocytic astrocytoma is the most common brain tumor in children and is usually located within the posterior fossa. Cerebellar compression can cause falls and dysdiadochokinesia, while increased intracranial pressure can result in lethargy, morning headaches, nausea, and vomiting. Imaging typically shows a well-circumscribed, enhancing cystic mass within one of the cerebellar hemispheres, but it can also occur in the cerebral hemispheres. Since pilocytic astrocytomas are low-grade tumors (WHO grade I), patients usually have a favorable prognosis following surgical resection.

Medulloblastoma and pilocytic astrocytoma are the most common posterior cranial fossa tumors in children. Medulloblastoma is the most common malignant brain tumor in children.

Oligodendroglioma can cause signs of increased intracranial pressure. However, these tumors are usually located supratentorial rather than in the posterior fossa, which is why patients with oligodendroglioma tend to also have seizures and/or focal neurological deficits. Furthermore, oligodendrogliomas usually affect adults 40–50 years of age, not children.

images.title: Oligodendroglioma
images.description: Cranial CT scan (axial view)A large hypodense lesion (green overlay) with multiple intralesional hyperdense calcifications (yellow overlay) is visible in the temporal lobe.

answers.explanation_why: Brainstem glioma can cause signs of increased intracranial pressure (i.e., morning headaches, nausea, and vomiting) and cerebellar signs (broad-based gait, dysdiadochokinesia). However, due to brainstem involvement in this condition, cranial nerve deficits are typically seen (e.g., diplopia, facial droop) and symptoms usually develop over the course of a few days, not months. Imaging usually shows minimal contrast enhancement rather than a contrast-enhancing cystic mass.

Craniopharyngiomas can present with signs of increased intracranial pressure (i.e., morning headaches, nausea, and vomiting), but are located within the sellar or suprasellar region, not the posterior fossa. Additionally, this patient lacks other findings of craniopharyngioma, such as vision changes from optic chiasm compression (e.g., bitemporal hemianopsia) and/or hormonal imbalances from pituitary compression (e.g., short stature, delayed puberty). Also, ataxia is not seen with this type of tumor.

Ependymoma can cause signs of increased intracranial pressure (i.e., morning headaches, nausea, and vomiting) and cerebellar signs (broad-based gait, dysdiadochokinesia). However, these tumors typically arise from the floor of the fourth ventricle, adapt to the shape of the ventricle, and extend through the foramina of Luschka and Magendi into the cisterns. It would be unusual for the tumor not to invade the ventricles and have cystic components on imaging. Furthermore, patients with ependymomas tend to be younger than this patient.

images.title: Ependymoma
images.description: MRI brain (FLAIR; sagittal view)A well-defined heterogeneous hyperintense lesion is visible within the expanded 4th ventricle (green overlay). At the superior aspect of the lesion, multiple dark foci are present (arrowheads), representing cysts. They appear dark in this image as the fluid signal is removed on FLAIR sequences. This lesion has obstructed circulation of the cerebrospinal fluid, resulting in ventriculomegaly (indicated by dashed line).Ependymomas commonly arise within the fourth ventricle. They are usually hyperintense on T2 weighted/FLAIR images and can demonstrate cystic change, such as in this case, as well as hemorrhage.

images.title: Cerebellar pilocytic astrocytoma
images.description: MRI head (a: T1-weighted; with contrast; sagittal plane; b: T2-weighted; axial plane) of a childA large lesion in the right cerebellar hemisphere displaces the vermis to the left of midline. It has a large cystic component (T1 hypointense and T2 hyperintense; red overlay) and a heterogeneously enhancing solid nodular component (green overlay).Cerebellar pilocytic astrocytoma frequently manifests as a large cystic lesion with an enhancing mural nodule.

question_text: A 2-year-old girl is brought to the physician because of abdominal distention and twitching of her feet, which her mother noticed a week ago. The patient has also had a low-grade fever for 5 days. She has not had a bowel movement in 3 days. She was born at term and has been healthy since. She is at the 40^th percentile for height and 20^th percentile for weight. Her temperature is 38.1°C (100.6°F), pulse is 128/min, and blood pressure is 135/82 mm Hg. Examination shows an irregular palpable mass that crosses the midline of the abdomen. The liver is palpated 3 cm below the right costal margin. There are erratic movements of the eyes. A 24-hour urine collection shows elevated homovanillic acid and vanillylmandelic acid levels. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
content_preview: A 2-year-old girl is brought to the physician because of abdominal distention and twitching of her feet, which her mother noticed a week ago. The patient has also had a low-grade fever for 5 days. She has not had a bowel movement in 3 days. She was born at term and has been healthy since. She is at the 40th percentile for height and 20th percentile for weight. Her temperature is 38.1°C (100.6°F), pulse is 128/min, and blood pressure is 135/82 mm Hg. Examination shows an irregular palpable mass that crosses the midline of the abdomen. The liver is palpated 3 cm below the right costal margin. There are erratic movements of the eyes. A 24-hour urine collection shows elevated homovanillic acid and vanillylmandelic acid levels. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
hint: This child's condition is associated with amplification and overexpression of the N-myc oncogene.
learning_objective: Recognize neuroblastoma.

answers.explanation_why: Hodgkin lymphoma typically manifests as cervical lymphadenopathy or a mediastinal mass in young adults or older individuals (bimodal age distribution). While it often causes fevers, other B symptoms such as night sweats or weight loss are absent in this patient. Also, a diagnosis of Hodgkin lymphoma would not explain this patient's abdominal mass, elevated urine catecholamine metabolites, or abnormal eye and foot movement.

Pheochromocytoma is a tumor that usually arises on the adrenal medulla and manifests with episodic hypertension, headaches, and diaphoresis secondary to catecholamine release. The suprarenal mass is sometimes palpable and causes increased levels of urine catecholamine metabolites, both of which are seen here. However, pheochromocytomas generally do not occur in children unless there is a family history (e.g., multiple endocrine neoplasia), which makes this tumor less likely.

Acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) is the most common childhood cancer and usually manifests with fatigue, easy bruising, and unexplained weight loss. While it can also cause fevers, ALL would not explain this patient's abdominal mass, elevated urine catecholamine metabolites, or abnormal eye and foot movement, making it an unlikely cause of her symptoms.

Hepatoblastoma is a rare childhood tumor that may also manifest with a large, irregular abdominal mass in a young child. However, hepatoblastoma would not explain this child's abnormal eye and foot movements, and it would not cause an elevation in urine catecholamine metabolites.

Nephroblastoma (i.e., Wilms tumor) is a childhood tumor that may also manifest with hypertension, abdominal distention, and a large abdominal mass. However, in contrast to this patient's abdominal mass, nephroblastomas do not cross midline and tend to be smooth rather than irregular. Additionally, nephroblastoma would not explain the elevated catecholamine metabolite levels seen here, nor would it cause abnormal eye and foot movements.

Neuroblastoma is a malignant neuroendocrine tumor that can manifest with abdominal distention, constipation and a palpable, irregular mass that crosses the midline. Further features include failure to thrive, hypertension, and fever, as well as opsoclonus-myoclonus syndrome, which explains the patient's twitching feet and erratic eye movements. Although neuroblastomas can originate from any aggregation of sympathetic nervous tissue, > 60% arise in the abdomen, as seen in this patient. The characteristic diagnostic finding is elevated urine catecholamine metabolites (homovanillic and vanillylmandelic acid). Treatment is based upon the extent of disease, age at diagnosis, and the presence/absence of N-myc amplification, and usually involves a combination of chemotherapy and surgical excision.

Rhabdomyosarcoma is a rare tumor that usually develops in the head and neck region but can also occur in the genitourinary tract (25% of cases). Although a very large bladder tumor could explain this patient's abdominal mass and constipation, most rhabdomyosarcomas are not palpable and would not cause elevations in urine catecholamine metabolites.

Mesoblastic nephroma is a rare congenital tumor that can also manifest with an abdominal mass. About 90% of these tumors occur within the first year of life, making it an unlikely finding in a 2-year-old. Additionally, a mesoblastic nephroma would not cause elevated urine catecholamine metabolites, nor would it explain this child's abnormal eye and foot movements.

question_text: A previously healthy 1-month-old boy is brought to the physician for a 10-day history of poor feeding. He struggles to breathe and sweats while feeding. He was born at 38 weeks' gestation following spontaneous vaginal delivery. His mother received no prenatal care. He was 51 cm (20 in) in length and weighed 3660 g (8 lb 1 oz) at birth. Apgar scores were 8 and 9 at 1 and 5 minutes, respectively. Examination following delivery showed no abnormalities, and he was discharged at the age of 2 days. Today, he is at the 20th percentile for length and 10th percentile for weight. His temperature is 36°C (96.8°F), pulse is 190/min, respirations are 60/min, and blood pressure is 70/50 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 96% and breathing appears labored. Examination shows no cyanosis, but a grade 2/6 holosystolic murmur is heard at the left lower sternal border. ECG shows left-axis deviation. Chest x-ray shows an enlarged left atrium and ventricle and increased pulmonary vascular markings. Doppler echocardiography confirms the presence of an intracardiac shunt. The development of this patient's current symptoms is most likely a result of which of the following?
content_preview: A previously healthy 1-month-old boy is brought to the physician for a 10-day history of poor feeding. He struggles to breathe and sweats while feeding. He was born at 38 weeks' gestation following spontaneous vaginal delivery. His mother received no prenatal care. He was 51 cm (20 in) in length and weighed 3660 g (8 lb 1 oz) at birth. Apgar scores were 8 and 9 at 1 and 5 minutes, respectively. Examination following delivery showed no abnormalities, and he was discharged at the age of 2 days. Today, he is at the 20th percentile for length and 10th percentile for weight. His temperature is 36°C (96.8°F), pulse is 190/min, respirations are 60/min, and blood pressure is 70/50 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 96% and breathing appears labored. Examination shows no cyanosis, but a grade 2/6 holosystolic murmur is heard at the left lower sternal border. ECG shows left-axis deviation. Chest x-ray shows an enlarged left atrium and ventricle and increased pulmonary vascular markings. Doppler echocardiography confirms the presence of an intracardiac shunt. The development of this patient's current symptoms is most likely a result of which of the following?
hint: Heart failure manifests with dyspnea, easy fatigability, and in children, sweating while feeding and failure to thrive. A faint holosystolic murmur heard at the left lower sternal border is consistent with a large ventricular septal defect (VSD).
learning_objective: Recognize a large ventricular septal defect, and recall the changes in pulmonary vascular resistance postnatally.

answers.explanation_why:
Pulmonary vascular resistance (PVR) is high in utero and decreases over the first few weeks of life. The progressive decrease in PVR and subsequent decrease in right ventricular pressure lead to increased left-to-right blood flow across the VSD. The enhanced shunting increases the overall volume of blood in pulmonary circulation, which causes increased lung perfusion (as evidenced by increased pulmonary vascular markings), increased pulmonary venous return to the left atrium, and left ventricular volume overload (resulting in left ventricular hypertrophy as evidenced on this patient's ECG and chest x-ray). These changes can lead to heart failure without cyanosis within the first few weeks to months of life, as seen in this child.

If the VSD is not repaired and pulmonary blood flow continues to be high, vascular remodeling in later stages will cause PVR to increase again, resulting first in right ventricular hypertrophy and persistent pulmonary hypertension and, eventually, shunt reversal (Eisenmenger syndrome) resulting in heart failure with cyanosis.

images.title: Cardiac hemodynamics in ventricular septal defect
images.description: A defect in the ventricular septum leads to a left-to-right shunt, the volume of which is dependent on the size of the defect. Blood flows from the left ventricle to the right ventricle (white arrow) along the pressure gradient (1). This leads to increased RV and LV preload (due to increased end-diastolic volume), ventricular hypertrophy and dilation (double-headed white arrows), and pulmonary hypertension resulting from excessive pulmonary blood flow (2). In end-stage disease, the pressure gradient is reversed because of Eisenmenger syndrome (shunt reversal), leading to the flow of mixed blood to the systemic circulation (white arrow) and subsequent cyanosis (3).Blue: structures that contain deoxygenated blood; Red: structures that contain oxygenated blood; Purple: structures that contain mixed blood

answers.explanation_why: Persistent pulmonary hypertension in a patient with a VSD (which is initially a left-to-right shunt) could cause a shunt reversal (Eisenmenger reaction). However, Eisenmenger reaction is associated with cyanosis and right ventricular hypertrophy, and typically only occurs after a left-to-right shunt has persisted for an extended amount of time. The patient's age and the presence of only left ventricular hypertrophy indicate that the heart failure is triggered by a physiological adaptation that occurs during the first few weeks of life.

Left ventricular outflow tract obstruction (LVOTO) can be caused by the presence of an underdeveloped aortic valve or congenital aortic coarctation, and manifest with left ventricular hypertrophy and heart failure. However, a murmur due to LVOTO typically has a systolic ejection character and is usually heard at the upper sternal borders (with possible radiation to the carotid region) or the interscapular region. The patient's murmur and the finding of an intracardiac shunt indicate a different cause for his symptoms.

The closure of the ductus arteriosus leads to worsening of symptoms in patients with ductal-dependent congenital heart defects (e.g., transposition of the great vessels, hypoplastic left heart syndrome), and these conditions are typically more severe; they manifest with cyanosis soon after birth. A VSD is not a ductal-dependent congenital heart defect. The ductus arteriosus closes within 2 days of birth in children without ductal-dependant congenital heart defects.

An increase in systemic vascular resistance is rarely seen in neonates. If present, it is usually due to vascular pathologies, such as renal vein thrombosis or umbilical artery thrombosis, neither of which are seen in this patient.

question_text: A 4-week-old male newborn is brought to the physician for a well-child examination. He was born at 40 weeks' gestation and weighed 3300 g (7 lb 4 oz). He now weighs 4300 g (9 lb 1 oz). There is no family history of serious illness. He is at the 50th percentile for length and weight. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows a grade 3/6 harsh holosystolic murmur at the left lower sternal border and a soft mid-diastolic murmur over the cardiac apex. The lungs are clear to auscultation. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for this patient's clinical findings?
content_preview: A 4-week-old male newborn is brought to the physician for a well-child examination. He was born at 40 weeks' gestation and weighed 3300 g (7 lb 4 oz). He now weighs 4300 g (9 lb 1 oz). There is no family history of serious illness. He is at the 50th percentile for length and weight. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows a grade 3/6 harsh holosystolic murmur at the left lower sternal border and a soft mid-diastolic murmur over the cardiac apex. The lungs are clear to auscultation. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for this patient's clinical findings?
hint: This child's heart murmurs point to the most commonly diagnosed congenital heart defect in newborns.
learning_objective: Recognize a ventricular septal defect, and recall its pathophysiology.

answers.content: Left-to-right shunt through the atrial septum
answers.explanation_why: A left-to-right shunt through the atrial septum can be seen in patients with an atrial septal defect (ASD). Patients with ASD are typically asymptomatic for years and diagnosed when an incidental systolic murmur is heard. However, an ASD typically causes a systolic ejection murmur that is best heard at the left upper sternal border (due to increased pulmonary flow) and a widely split and fixed second heart sound.

images.title: Cardiac hemodynamics in atrial septal defect
images.description: An atrial septal defect causes blood to flow from the left to the right atrium (left-to-right shunt; white arrow), resulting in volume overload of the right atrium and ventricle (1). As a result, there is dilation and compensatory hypertrophy (double-headed white arrows) of the right atrium and ventricle (2). In the late stages, Eisenmenger syndrome with shunt reversal (right-to-left shunt; white arrow) and cyanosis can occur (3).Blue: structures that contain deoxygenated blood; Red: structures that contain oxygenated blood; Purple: structures that contain mixed blood

answers.content: Right-to-left shunt through the atrial septum
answers.explanation_why:
A right-to-left shunt through the atrial septum can be seen in patients with tricuspid valve atresia (TVA) and total anomalous pulmonary venous return (TAPVR). In both conditions, a right-to-left shunt through an atrial septal defect (ASD) is necessary to pump blood to the left side of the heart and, consequently, the systemic circulation. Patients with TVA or TAPVR present with cyanosis in the first few days of life. This patient's lack of cyanosis rules out both of these diagnoses.

A right-to-left shunt through the atrial septum can also be seen in patients with Eisenmenger syndrome secondary to an isolated ASD. However, Eisenmenger syndrome develops only after an extended amount of time (usually a few years) and manifests with cyanosis and features of heart failure.

answers.content: Left-to-right shunt through the ventricular septum
answers.explanation_why:
A ventricular septal defect (VSD) causes a left-to-right shunt through the ventricular septum. Most VSDs manifest in infancy as a holosystolic murmur at the left lower sternal border. The size of the defect is inversely proportional to the intensity of the murmur (i.e., small defects are associated with louder murmurs, while large defects may not have an associated murmur). A mid-diastolic murmur can also sometimes be heard with moderate or large VSDs due to increased flow across the mitral valve secondary to the left-to-right shunt.

After a few years, a VSD can lead to pulmonary hypertension and a shunt reversal (Eisenmenger syndrome) resulting in heart failure with cyanosis. With shunt reversal, the murmur of the VSD may disappear.

images.title: Cardiac hemodynamics in ventricular septal defect
images.description: A defect in the ventricular septum leads to a left-to-right shunt, the volume of which is dependent on the size of the defect. Blood flows from the left ventricle to the right ventricle (white arrow) along the pressure gradient (1). This leads to increased RV and LV preload (due to increased end-diastolic volume), ventricular hypertrophy and dilation (double-headed white arrows), and pulmonary hypertension resulting from excessive pulmonary blood flow (2). In end-stage disease, the pressure gradient is reversed because of Eisenmenger syndrome (shunt reversal), leading to the flow of mixed blood to the systemic circulation (white arrow) and subsequent cyanosis (3).Blue: structures that contain deoxygenated blood; Red: structures that contain oxygenated blood; Purple: structures that contain mixed blood

answers.explanation_why: Right ventricular outflow tract obstruction (RVOTO) secondary to pulmonary infundibular stenosis can be seen in patients with tetralogy of Fallot (TOF). Patients with RVOTO would have a systolic ejection murmur at the left upper sternal border and it would be unlikely for a patient with TOF to present without a history of cyanotic spells.

images.title: Tetralogy of Fallot
images.description:
Tetralogy of Fallot is the simultaneous occurrence of:
(a) Pulmonary stenosis
(b) Right ventricular hypertrophy
(c) Ventricular septal defect (VSD)
(d) An overriding aorta (above the VSD)The hemodynamic effects depend on the extent of right ventricular outflow tract obstruction. With mild obstruction (1), a left-to-right shunt is more pronounced and there is mild cyanosis. With severe obstruction (2), a right-to-left shunt is more pronounced, which results in severe cyanosis. Pulmonary circulation may be supplied via a patent ductus arteriosus.

answers.content: Right-to-left shunt through the ventricular septum
answers.explanation_why:
A right-to-left shunt through the ventricular septum can occur in patients with tetralogy of Fallot (TOF) who have severe right ventricular outflow tract obstruction (RVOTO). In such a scenario, the path of least resistance is through the ventricular septal defect (VSD), and not through the pulmonary valve. Patients with RVOTO would have a systolic ejection murmur at the left upper sternal border and it would be unlikely for a patient with TOF to present without a history of cyanotic spells.

A right-to-left shunt through the ventricular septum can also be seen in patients with Eisenmenger syndrome secondary to an isolated VSD. However, Eisenmenger syndrome develops only after an extended amount of time (usually a few years) and manifests with cyanosis and features of heart failure.

Left ventricular outflow tract obstruction (LVOTO) can be caused by the presence of an underdeveloped aortic valve or congenital aortic coarctation. However, patients with congenital LVOTO usually present soon after birth with features of heart failure. In addition, a murmur due to LVOTO typically has a systolic ejection character and is best heard at the upper sternal borders (with possible radiation to the carotid region) or the interscapular region.

question_text: A 2400-g (5.29-lb) male newborn is delivered at term to a 38-year-old woman. The initial examination shows that the child is at the 5th percentile for head circumference and 10th percentile for weight and length. He has a sloping forehead, a flat nasal bridge, increased interocular distance, low-set ears, and a protruding tongue. An examination of the peripheries reveals a single palmar crease and an increased gap between the first and second toes. Ocular examination reveals small white and brown spots in the periphery of both irises. The abdomen is distended. An x-ray of the abdomen shows two large air-filled spaces in the upper quadrant. This child's condition is most likely associated with which of the following cardiac anomalies?
content_preview: A 2400-g (5.29-lb) male newborn is delivered at term to a 38-year-old woman. The initial examination shows that the child is at the 5th percentile for head circumference and 10th percentile for weight and length. He has a sloping forehead, a flat nasal bridge, increased interocular distance, low-set ears, and a protruding tongue. An examination of the peripheries reveals a single palmar crease and an increased gap between the first and second toes. Ocular examination reveals small white and brown spots in the periphery of both irises. The abdomen is distended. An x-ray of the abdomen shows two large air-filled spaces in the upper quadrant. This child's condition is most likely associated with which of the following cardiac anomalies?
hint: The characteristic morphological features, Brushfield spots in the eye, and the “double bubble” sign on abdominal x-ray (indicating duodenal atresia) are all suggestive of trisomy 21 (Down syndrome).
learning_objective: Recognize Down syndrome, and recall its associated cardiac anomalies.

answers.explanation_why: Atrial septal defects (ASD) are among the most common congenital heart defects and are commonly associated with fetal alcohol syndrome, trisomy 21, and Holt-Oram syndrome. Although ASD occurs in approx. 15% of patients with Down syndrome, it is not the most common congenital cardiac anomaly seen in this condition.

images.title: Cardiac hemodynamics in atrial septal defect
images.description: An atrial septal defect causes blood to flow from the left to the right atrium (left-to-right shunt; white arrow), resulting in volume overload of the right atrium and ventricle (1). As a result, there is dilation and compensatory hypertrophy (double-headed white arrows) of the right atrium and ventricle (2). In the late stages, Eisenmenger syndrome with shunt reversal (right-to-left shunt; white arrow) and cyanosis can occur (3).Blue: structures that contain deoxygenated blood; Red: structures that contain oxygenated blood; Purple: structures that contain mixed blood

answers.explanation_why:
Atrioventricular septal defects (AVSD; also referred to as endocardial cushion defects) are the most common congenital heart defects in patients with Down syndrome, occurring in about 40% of newborns with trisomy 21. AVSDs are usually diagnosed in the prenatal period, and discovery of an AVSD should warrant prompt genetic testing, as there is a strong association with trisomy 21. Down syndrome is diagnosed in approx. 40–50% of children with AVSD.

Diuretics, inotropic agents, and ACE inhibitors are usually given to improve cardiac function. Definitive treatment consists of complete surgical repair.

Ventricular septal defects (VSD) account for approx. 50% of all congenital heart defects, making them the most common cause of congenital heart disease overall. They are commonly associated with fetal alcohol syndrome, intrauterine infections, and many genetic syndromes (including trisomy 13, trisomy 18, and trisomy 21). Although VSD occurs in approximately 30% of patients with Down syndrome, it is not the most common congenital cardiac anomaly seen in this condition.

images.title: Cardiac hemodynamics in ventricular septal defect
images.description: A defect in the ventricular septum leads to a left-to-right shunt, the volume of which is dependent on the size of the defect. Blood flows from the left ventricle to the right ventricle (white arrow) along the pressure gradient (1). This leads to increased RV and LV preload (due to increased end-diastolic volume), ventricular hypertrophy and dilation (double-headed white arrows), and pulmonary hypertension resulting from excessive pulmonary blood flow (2). In end-stage disease, the pressure gradient is reversed because of Eisenmenger syndrome (shunt reversal), leading to the flow of mixed blood to the systemic circulation (white arrow) and subsequent cyanosis (3).Blue: structures that contain deoxygenated blood; Red: structures that contain oxygenated blood; Purple: structures that contain mixed blood

answers.explanation_why: A patent ductus arteriosus is most commonly associated with prematurity, fetal alcohol syndrome, birth at high altitude, or congenital rubella infection. Although it occurs in approx. 5% of patients with Down syndrome, it is not the most common congenital cardiac anomaly seen in this condition.

images.title: Cardiac hemodynamics in patent ductus arteriosus
images.description: In patent ductus arteriosus, there is a left-to-right shunt, with blood flowing from the aorta to the pulmonary arteries during both systole and diastole (1). This shunt leads to volume overload (recirculation) of the blood within the pulmonary vessels, the left atrium, and left ventricle (2). Eventually, because of the increased blood flow to the pulmonary circulation, pulmonary hypertension may develop as well as Eisenmenger syndrome, which involves a shunt reversal. The left-to-right-shunt without cyanosis becomes a right-to-left shunt with cyanosis (3).Blue: structures that contain deoxygenated blood; Red: structures that contain oxygenated blood; Pink: structures that contain mixed blood

answers.explanation_why: Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF) is the most common cause of cyanotic heart disease in children. Most cases arise sporadically, but approx. 15% of patients with TOF have an underlying genetic syndrome (such as Down syndrome or DiGeorge syndrome). Although it occurs in approx. 5% of patients with Down syndrome, it is not the most common congenital cardiac anomaly seen in this condition.

images.title: Tetralogy of Fallot
images.description:
Tetralogy of Fallot is the simultaneous occurrence of:
(a) Pulmonary stenosis
(b) Right ventricular hypertrophy
(c) Ventricular septal defect (VSD)
(d) An overriding aorta (above the VSD)The hemodynamic effects depend on the extent of right ventricular outflow tract obstruction. With mild obstruction (1), a left-to-right shunt is more pronounced and there is mild cyanosis. With severe obstruction (2), a right-to-left shunt is more pronounced, which results in severe cyanosis. Pulmonary circulation may be supplied via a patent ductus arteriosus.

answers.explanation_why: Congenital pulmonary valve stenosis usually arises sporadically, but it can be seen in association with other congenital heart defects such as tetralogy of Fallot. It is not commonly associated with Down syndrome.

Transposition of the great arteries accounts for 20% of all cases of cyanotic congenital heart disease. It is associated with maternal diabetes, advanced maternal age, and congenital rubella infection. Unlike many other congenital heart defects, it is rarely associated with any genetic conditions such as Down syndrome.

images.title: Transposition of the great vessels (TGV)
images.description: TGV is a cyanotic congenital heart disease in which the pulmonary artery arises from the left ventricle and the aorta from the right ventricle, resulting in the formation of parallel circulatory systems. The left ventricle pumps oxygenated blood into the pulmonary circulation (red) and the right ventricle pumps deoxygenated blood into the aorta (blue), resulting in cyanosis.TGV is fatal unless a shunt between the two circulations is present (i.e., a patent ductus arteriosus or a patent foramen ovale) or a surgical intervention is performed in the neonatal period.
