question_text: An 18-year-old primigravid woman comes to the physician for her first prenatal visit at 20 weeks' gestation. There is no family history of serious illness. She appears healthy and well-nourished. The uterus is palpated up to the level of the umbilicus. Laboratory studies show a maternal serum α-fetoprotein concentration of 640 ng/ml (N = 10–150). Ultrasonography shows a defect in the fetal abdominal wall to the right of the umbilical cord. A part of the fetus's bowels herniates through the abdominal defect and is suspended freely in the amniotic fluid. Which of the following extraintestinal structural abnormalities is most likely to be found on further evaluation of the fetus?
content_preview: An 18-year-old primigravid woman comes to the physician for her first prenatal visit at 20 weeks' gestation. There is no family history of serious illness. She appears healthy and well-nourished. The uterus is palpated up to the level of the umbilicus. Laboratory studies show a maternal serum α-fetoprotein concentration of 640 ng/ml (N = 10–150). Ultrasonography shows a defect in the fetal abdominal wall to the right of the umbilical cord. A part of the fetus's bowels herniates through the abdominal defect and is suspended freely in the amniotic fluid. Which of the following extraintestinal structural abnormalities is most likely to be found on further evaluation of the fetus?
hint: This fetus has gastroschisis, a condition in which the intestines herniate freely through an abdominal defect in the paraumbilical area. By contrast, omphalocele is a condition in which the intestines protrude at the midline through the navel but are contained in a hernia sac. Both abdominal wall defects are associated with an elevated 2^nd-trimester maternal serum α-fetoprotein (MSAFP) concentration.
learning_objective: Recognize gastroschisis as an isolated defect.

answers.explanation_why: Brachycephaly is a common feature seen in patients with trisomy 21. Omphalocele rather than gastroschisis is frequently observed in patients with trisomy 21. Gastroschisis occurs relatively late in development and is rarely associated with chromosomal abnormalities.

Spina bifida is an open neural tube defect that can cause elevated MSAFP, but it is not associated with abdominal wall defects. MSAFP is elevated in open neural tube defects (e.g., spina bifida, anencephaly), abdominal wall defects (e.g., omphalocele, gastroschisis), fetal death, and placental abnormalities (e.g., placental abruption).

answers.content: No extraintestinal structural abnormalities are expected
answers.explanation_why: Gastroschisis is a congenital ventral wall defect that is usually isolated. By contrast, omphalocele is commonly associated with structural abnormalities of extraintestinal organs (e.g., heart, neural tube) and often occurs in the context of syndrome complexes (e.g., chromosomal trisomies, Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome). In gastroschisis, the absence of a hernia sac results in an edematous, erythematous, and dull intestinal wall. This condition is mainly seen in premature infants and those with intrauterine growth restriction, and can be associated with cryptorchidism, gastrointestinal stenoses, and atresia, the latter of which can result in short bowel syndrome. Because gastroschisis is not covered by a hernia sac, alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) can diffuse freely into the amniotic fluid and maternal circulation, leading to elevated MSAFP, which can be detected by a screening test.

images.title: Congenital malformations of the anterior abdominal wall
images.description: Omphalocele: herniation of intraabdominal contents through an anterior abdominal wall defect at the base of the umbilical cord caused by the failure of the midgut to return to the abdominal cavity after its physiological herniation through the umbilical ring. Accordingly, the hernial sac is formed by the amniotic membrane and peritoneum, and the umbilical cord lies at the apex of the hernia.Gastroschisis: a developmental defect of the anterior abdominal wall in the paraumbilical region through which intraabdominal contents prolapse. As it is the anterior abdominal wall that fails to develop correctly, there is no outer peritoneal or membranous covering.Congenital umbilical hernia: herniation of intraabdominal contents through a patent umbilical orifice, which typically closes by 2 years of age. The sac of a paraumbilical hernia is the peritoneum.Diastasis recti: an abnormally wide separation of the right and left rectus abdominis muscles. The abdominal fascia are intact. There is therefore no herniation, but a midline bulge is visible on straining (e.g., when trying to sit up).

answers.explanation_why: Bladder exstrophy can be observed in rare cases of patients with omphalocele, but it is extremely rare in gastroschisis. In this fetus, the intestines herniate through the abdominal wall, but no bladder or urethra is visualized.

Organomegaly is a feature of Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome (BWS). BWS is the most common genetic abnormality associated with omphalocele, but it is not associated with gastroschisis. BWS should be suspected in patients who present with macroglossia, macrosomia, and midfacial hypoplasia.

Congenital heart diseases, such as ventricular septal defects (VSDs), are seen in 30–50% of fetuses with omphalocele and are also associated with trisomies, fetal alcohol syndrome, and TORCH infections. However, VSDs are not associated with gastroschisis. VSDs are usually detected in utero by echocardiography. In the neonatal period, VSD should be suspected in patients with poor eating, failure to thrive, tachypnea, and/or dyspnea.

question_text: A 12-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of a 6-day history of gradually worsening right knee pain. The pain is exacerbated by movement and kneeling. There is no pain at rest and no history of trauma to the knee. He is concerned because his soccer tryouts are in a few days. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows mild swelling and tenderness to palpation of the right anterior, superior tibia. Extension of the right knee against resistance reproduces the knee pain; flexion is limited by pain. There is no local erythema or effusion of the right knee. A lateral view of an x-ray of his right knee is shown. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's symptoms?
content_preview: A 12-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of a 6-day history of gradually worsening right knee pain. The pain is exacerbated by movement and kneeling. There is no pain at rest and no history of trauma to the knee. He is concerned because his soccer tryouts are in a few days. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows mild swelling and tenderness to palpation of the right anterior, superior tibia. Extension of the right knee against resistance reproduces the knee pain; flexion is limited by pain. There is no local erythema or effusion of the right knee. A lateral view of an x-ray of his right knee is shown. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's symptoms?
hint: In a physically active adolescent, anterior knee pain that is worse with activity and is reproducible with extension against resistance should raise concern for Osgood Schlatter disease.
learning_objective: Recognize traction apophysitis of the tibial tubercle (Osgood-Schlatter disease).

answers.content: Impingement of the infrapatellar fat pad
answers.explanation_why: Impingement of the infrapatellar fat pad between the femoral condyle and the patella may occur if the fat pad becomes swollen secondary to direct trauma, chronic irritation, or hyperextension injury. Patients present with anterior knee pain inferior to the patella, which is typically exacerbated by sprinting or squatting. Examination may show mild swelling and pain on palpation on either side of the patellar tendon (equivalent to position of the fat pad), but is otherwise unremarkable. Pain over the insertion point of the patellar tendon (proximal anterior tibia), as experienced by this patient, does not occur.

Inflammation of the infrapatellar bursa (i.e., infrapatellar bursitis) can be caused by trauma, overuse, or systemic diseases. It manifests with pain that worsens on kneeling and movement (extension/flexion), reduced mobility, as well as localized swelling, erythema, and warmth. The diagnosis is typically established clinically, and, since bursas are not radiopaque, radiography is rarely used other than to rule out fracture. This patient's x-ray findings suggest another underlying cause of his symptoms.

Osteoid osteomas are benign bone tumors seen typically in individuals 10–30 years old. The tumor can develop in any bone, but most commonly affects the metaphyses and diaphyses of long bones (e.g., femur, tibia, humerus) or the spine. The characteristic clinical feature is a persistent, intense, aching pain localized to the site of the lesion that worsens at night. Physical examination often shows pain on palpation that is not exacerbated by movement, unless intracapsular lesions occur. Since this patient has no history of pain at rest or at night, and extension/flexion elicits pain, osteoid osteoma is unlikely.

Chondromalacia patellae can be due to trauma or overuse and affected individuals (often young adults) report vague discomfort of the anterior knee, which is worsened by activity, especially while climbing stairs. Physical examination may show crepitus of the knee. X-ray is usually normal in early chondromalacia patellae since bones are unaffected.

answers.content: Traction apophysitis of the tibial tubercle
answers.explanation_why:
Traction apophysitis of the tibial tubercle occurs in Osgood Schlatter disease, which typically affects adolescent athletes. Overuse (e.g., sports that involve running and jumping) leads to the patellar tendon exerting excessive strain on the tibial tuberosity, which is not yet fully ossified in adolescents and is thus susceptible to detachment. Patients typically present with anterior knee pain localized to the tibial tubercle. Visible swelling of the proximal tibia may also be present. X-ray is usually not required for diagnosis, but may be helpful to rule out differential diagnoses, especially in cases of atypical presentation (e.g., history of trauma, nocturnal pain, pain at rest). This patient's age, history, and x-ray findings of fragmentation and irregularity of the tibial tubercle are all indicative of Osgood Schlatter disease.

Osgood Schlatter disease is usually self-limited. Treatment is therefore primarily conservative, consisting of rest, ice, stretching exercises, and NSAIDs.

images.title: Lateral view of the knee joint

answers.explanation_why: Osteochondritis dissecans (OCD) commonly occurs in males 10–20 years old and is most likely caused by mechanical stress and/or repetitive trauma. The condition manifests with diffuse joint pain during activities and progressive joint stiffness with locking or catching of the joint. On physical examination, range of motion is intact, though palpation of the femoral condyles in the flexed knee elicits pain. OCD can be ruled out since this patient presents with pain over the proximal tibial and not the femoral condyles. Moreover, patients with OCD would have a crescent-shaped radiolucency on the medial femoral condyle, whereas this patient's abnormality is on the tibial tuberosity.

Iliotibial band syndrome (ITBS) is a common overuse injury of the knee caused by repetitive flexion and extension of the knee. Clinically, the condition manifests with sharp pain at the lateral knee when the foot hits the ground while running and constant, dull pain at rest. Physical examination elicits pain if pressure is applied to the lateral femoral epicondyle during passive flexion of the leg. Although this patient has likely been running frequently and has an increased risk for overuse injury, his symptoms are not consistent with this diagnosis. Moreover, radiographs in patients with ITBS usually appear normal.

answers.content: Avulsion fracture of the proximal tibia
answers.explanation_why:
While an avulsion fracture of the tibial tubercle can also manifest with tenderness over the proximal tibia that is exacerbated by movement, it is generally the result of acute trauma, such as forced flexion against a contracted quadriceps muscle (e.g., coming down from a high jump during basketball). Furthermore, an avulsion fracture of the tibial tubercle would result in severe pain even at rest, as well as effusion of the knee joint. This patient's x-ray shows fragmentation, not avulsion fracture, of the proximal tibia.

This patient's condition may predispose him to developing an avulsion fracture of the tibial tubercle.

images.title: Osgood-Schlatter disease
images.description: X-ray knee (lateral view) of an adolescent with a painful swelling below the kneeThe fragmented appearance of the tibial tuberosity (fragments indicated by green overlay) with overlying soft tissue swelling (indicated by arrow) and thickening of the patellar tendon (red overlay) supports a diagnosis of apophysitis at the patellar tendon insertion (Osgood-Schlatter disease).

question_text: A 4080-g (9-lb) male newborn is delivered at term to a 32-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 1. Apgar scores are 8 and 9 at 1 and 5 minutes, respectively. Examination in the delivery room shows both feet pointing downwards and inwards. Both forefeet are twisted medially in adduction, with the hindfeet elevated and the midfeet appearing concave. Both Achilles tendons are taut on palpation. There are skin creases on the medial side of both feet. The deformity persists despite attempts to passively straighten the foot. X-rays of both feet confirm the suspected diagnosis. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 4080-g (9-lb) male newborn is delivered at term to a 32-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 1. Apgar scores are 8 and 9 at 1 and 5 minutes, respectively. Examination in the delivery room shows both feet pointing downwards and inwards. Both forefeet are twisted medially in adduction, with the hindfeet elevated and the midfeet appearing concave. Both Achilles tendons are taut on palpation. There are skin creases on the medial side of both feet. The deformity persists despite attempts to passively straighten the foot. X-rays of both feet confirm the suspected diagnosis. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: This newborn presents with in-toeing, an elevated hindfoot, and a cavus deformity of the midfoot bilaterally. This presentation is consistent with club foot, a common congenital foot deformity.
learning_objective: Recognize club foot, and choose the most appropriate initial management.

answers.explanation_why: Foot abduction bracing prevents relapses after the initial correction of the club foot. At this point in the patient's presentation, however, another intervention aimed at correcting the deformity is first needed.

Surgery is not considered a first-line approach for the vast majority of club foot cases. Cases that require surgery are often those in which parents/caregivers have difficulty following the non-surgical treatment plan or those in which the deformity is so severe that conservative treatment is unlikely to alleviate the issues. In the event that other treatment options fail, surgery would be indicated to correct deformities in the tendons, ligaments, and joints of the foot and ankle.

Reassurance is inappropriate in this patient because the deformity is rigid on examination, making the likelihood of spontaneous resolution very low. Club foot specifically is known to cause permanent deformity if not corrected in a timely manner.

Repositioning and serial casting is the recommended treatment for patients with club foot. On clinical exam, the deformity cannot be passively corrected, indicating that intervention will be necessary to prevent future gait disorders. If repositioning and casting are initiated within 24 hours and continued through musculoskeletal development, the prognosis for this patient is excellent and surgery can likely be avoided.

images.title: Congenital clubfoot in a newborn
images.description: Right lower leg and foot of a newborn, ventral view of the back of the foot The achilles tendon is shortened, resulting in plantar flexion and the foot pointing downwards (hindfoot equinus). The calcaneus is supinated (hindfoot varus). The forefoot is adducted and supinated and rotates medially (forefoot varus). The midfoot cavus cannot be seen from this perspective.

answers.explanation_why: Physical therapy (PT) is an important element of caring for patients with club feet because it helps to provide optimal alignment, mobility, and range of motion. However, a primary correction of the deformity is required before PT can be initiated.

question_text: A 13-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department because of pain in his right knee for the past week. The pain is exacerbated by jogging and climbing up stairs. He has no history of trauma to the knee. He is otherwise healthy. He is an active member of his school's gymnastics team. His vital signs are within normal limits. Examination of the right knee shows a tender swelling at the proximal tibia; range of motion is full. Knee extension against resistance causes pain in the anterior proximal tibia. The remainder of the examinations shows no abnormalities. X-ray of the right knee shows anterior tibial soft tissue swelling with fragmentation of the tibial tuberosity. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 13-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department because of pain in his right knee for the past week. The pain is exacerbated by jogging and climbing up stairs. He has no history of trauma to the knee. He is otherwise healthy. He is an active member of his school's gymnastics team. His vital signs are within normal limits. Examination of the right knee shows a tender swelling at the proximal tibia; range of motion is full. Knee extension against resistance causes pain in the anterior proximal tibia. The remainder of the examinations shows no abnormalities. X-ray of the right knee shows anterior tibial soft tissue swelling with fragmentation of the tibial tuberosity. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: In a physically active adolescent, a history of nontraumatic knee pain associated with swelling of the proximal tibia that worsens with exercise and is reproducible with extension against resistance is strongly suggestive of Osgood Schlatter disease.
learning_objective: Recognize Osgood-Schlatter disease, and choose the most appropriate initial management.

answers.explanation_why: While steroid injections have been used for many years for the treatment of tendinopathies, recent studies have shown that their long-term benefit is questionable and that they can adversely affect soft tissue, including the injured tendon. Regardless, it would not help the necrotic bone of Osgood Schlatter disease heal. Additionally, an injection intended to treat tendinopathies should be paratendinous, rather than intratendinous, to minimize damage to an already inflamed tendon.

First-line treatment in patients with Osgood Schlatter disease is a combination of rest, ice, and NSAIDs (e.g., ibuprofen). If this combination is not effective, immobilization can be attempted. Surgical excision of the fragmented tibial tubercle (and any other ossicles found in the area of the tendon) is reserved for refractory cases.

A fragmented tibial tubercle must be differentiated from an avulsion fracture of the tubercle, which requires surgical treatment.

images.title: Osgood-Schlatter disease
images.description: X-ray knee (lateral view) of an adolescent with a painful swelling below the kneeThe fragmented appearance of the tibial tuberosity (fragments indicated by green overlay) with overlying soft tissue swelling (indicated by arrow) and thickening of the patellar tendon (red overlay) supports a diagnosis of apophysitis at the patellar tendon insertion (Osgood-Schlatter disease).

answers.explanation_why: Joint aspiration is a very important diagnostic tool for confirming suspected septic arthritis, but septic arthritis is unlikely in a patient with neither fever nor local erythema and warmth. Additionally, the pain is primarily located in the area of the proximal tibia, whereas septic arthritis manifests in the joint itself.

answers.content: Open reduction of the tibial tuberosity
answers.explanation_why: Open reduction is used to treat avulsion fractures of the tibial tuberosity, which is both a differential diagnosis of Osgood Schlatter disease and a possible complication of it. In patients with avulsion fractures, the quadriceps tendon, which inserts in the area of the tibial tuberosity, is typically retracted. This retraction elevates the patella, which is embedded in the quadriceps tendon, and leads to decreased quadriceps strength. This patient does not have reduced quadriceps strength, and the x-ray only shows fragmentation, not avulsion fracture, of the tuberosity.

Excision of the tibial tuberosity may be considered if the patient had already received extensive conservative treatment. Surgical excision of the tuberosity and/or of any ossicles in the area of the tendon is reserved for cases refractory to conservative measures, and is generally only performed after the proximal tibial growth plate has closed.

Bone biopsy is used for the diagnosis of suspected bone tumors such as osteosarcoma, which tends to occur proximal and distal to the knee joint. Pain that worsens with activity and tenderness to palpation would also be consistent with this diagnosis. However, in the case of osteosarcoma, x-ray typically shows osteolysis, sunburst appearance, and/or Codman triangle, none of which is present here.

images.title: Aggressive bone tumor
images.description: X-ray tibia (left; AP view) A mixed density osteoblastic (sclerotic; S) and osteolytic (lucent; L) lesion that replaces most of the proximal tibia shows a permeative pattern of destruction with cortical breakthrough. The aggressive tumor is accompanied by periosteal elevation that has created a triangular area of new bone (Codman triangle; yellow overlay). Linear bony spicules radiate outward and resemble rays of the sun (sunburst pattern; examples indicated by blue lines).A Codman triangle is seen in the setting of an aggressive bone lesion when only the edge of the raised periosteum ossifies. Sunburst periosteal reaction, another sign of aggressive periostitis, occurs when the periosteum is unable to form organized layers and Sharpey fibers are stretched.

answers.explanation_why: Cast immobilization for 6 weeks can be attempted in cases that are refractory to other conservative measures, but it should not be attempted as an initial treatment.

question_text: A 1-year-old girl is brought to the physician because of a 2-day history of fever and crying while passing urine. She was born at term and has been healthy since. Three months ago, she was treated for a urinary tract infection with oral cefixime. Her temperature is 39.0°C (102.2°F), pulse is 144/min, and blood pressure is 85/40 mm Hg. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Her leukocyte count is 14,000/mm^3. Urine dipstick shows leukocyte esterase and nitrites; urinalysis shows WBCs and gram-negative rods. Urine culture results are pending. Renal ultrasonography shows hydronephrosis of the left kidney. Empirical antimicrobial therapy is initiated, after which the patient's symptoms improve. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in diagnosis?
content_preview: A 1-year-old girl is brought to the physician because of a 2-day history of fever and crying while passing urine. She was born at term and has been healthy since. Three months ago, she was treated for a urinary tract infection with oral cefixime. Her temperature is 39.0°C (102.2°F), pulse is 144/min, and blood pressure is 85/40 mm Hg. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Her leukocyte count is 14,000/mm3. Urine dipstick shows leukocyte esterase and nitrites; urinalysis shows WBCs and gram-negative rods. Urine culture results are pending. Renal ultrasonography shows hydronephrosis of the left kidney. Empirical antimicrobial therapy is initiated, after which the patient's symptoms improve. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in diagnosis?
hint: In children aged between 2 and 24 months, a test to identify vesicoureteral reflux (VUR) is indicated if any of the following are present: a previously confirmed urinary tract infection (UTI), slow response to antibiotic therapy (> 48 hours), poor urine flow, flank or suprapubic mass, organisms other than Escherichia coli on urine culture, increased creatinine levels, ultrasonographic evidence of hydronephrosis, ureteric dilation, or renal scarring.
learning_objective: Recognize vesicoureteral reflux, and choose the most appropriate diagnostic study.

answers.explanation_why: Injection of bulking agents into the vesicoureteric junction via cystoscopy is a treatment option for children with severe or persistent VUR. However, VUR should first be diagnosed and its severity assessed before surgical or endoscopic repair can be considered.
Intravenous pyelography (IVP) cannot be used to diagnose VUR since the contrast medium flows in an anterograde direction from the kidney to the bladder.

images.title: Obstructing ureteral calculus
images.description: Excretory urography (AP view; left: pre-contrast; right: 2.5 hours post-contrast)A calcification medial to the lower pole of the right kidney on the pre-contrast radiograph (red overlay) is shown post-contrast to be an obstructing proximal ureteral calculus (UC; red overlay). The right kidney is enlarged, with persistent enhancement (green overlay). There is pelvicaliectasis and poor contrast-filling of the right ureter (region indicated by dashed lines). The left renal collecting system is normal (purple overlay).RP: renal pelvis, U: ureter; UB: urinary bladder

answers.explanation_why: A MAG-3 scan (dynamic renal scintigraphy) is used to distinguish obstructive hydronephrosis from nonobstructive hydronephrosis. However, a different investigation must first be performed to rule out VUR, since VUR is a more common cause of hydronephrosis in children than obstruction. A MAG-3 scan cannot be used to diagnose VUR because the radiolabelled MAG-3 flows in an anterograde direction from the kidney to the bladder.

Urodynamic testing is indicated when a secondary cause for VUR, such as neurogenic bladder dysfunction, is suspected. This patient does not have any clinical evidence of neural tube defects (e.g., a lipoma or a tuft of hair near the sacrum), imperforate anus, spinal cord injury, or central nervous system disorders to suggest neurogenic bladder dysfunction. A different test is indicated to first diagnose VUR before assessment for secondary causes of VUR can be considered.

In patients with UTIs, a DMSA scan (static renal scintigraphy) is indicated if any of the following are present to assess the severity of renal cortical scarring: renal parenchymal abnormalities on ultrasonography, increased serum creatinine, breakthrough UTI, or severe VUR (grade III–V). This patient has neither parenchymal abnormalities nor an increased creatinine concentration and did not develop the UTI while on continuous antibiotic prophylaxis. A different test that can diagnose and assess the severity of VUR must first be performed.

Further workup to rule out VUR is indicated for this patient with a history of a previously confirmed UTI and ultrasonographic evidence of hydronephrosis. Voiding cystourethrography (VCUG) is the diagnostic procedure of choice to diagnose and assess the severity of VUR after empirical antibiotic therapy is initiated and active infection subsides. Early diagnosis and management of VUR are important to prevent renal failure secondary to renal scarring resulting from recurrent infections. Mild to moderate VUR is managed with continuous antibiotic prophylaxis, behavioral modification (e.g., timed voiding), and regular surveillance, whereas patients with severe VUR should undergo surgical or cystoscopic repair of the vesicoureteric junction.

VCUG may be performed when the prescribed antimicrobial regimen for the UTI has been completed or after the patient is asymptomatic. Studies show no improvement in the rates of detection or the severity of VUR between early (< 7 days after UTI detection) and late VCUG.

images.title: Bilateral vesicoureteral reflux
images.description: Voiding cystourethrogram (AP view)Bilateral vesicoureteral reflux (VUR) has resulted in dilatation of the ureters and pelvicalyceal systems. The right ureter is tortuous and moderately dilated, with blunting of calyceal fornices (example indicated by arrow) but preserved papillary impressions (green line; grade IV VUR). The left ureter is markedly dilated with loss of the fornices and papillary impressions (grade V VUR).B: bladder

answers.content: CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis
answers.explanation_why: A CT scan is often used to diagnose urinary calculi among adults. A CT scan is not typically used for diagnosing pathologies associated with VUR (e.g., posterior urethral valves), which are more common causes of hydronephrosis in children than ureteric obstruction by calculi. Additionally, CT scans should be avoided in children because of their significant radiation exposure. A CT scan may be performed if evidence of a perinephric abscess or xanthogranulomatous pyelonephritis is seen on ultrasonography.

question_text: A 2-year-old girl is brought to the physician because of a 1-day history of high-grade fever and crying while passing urine. Four months ago, she was treated for a febrile urinary tract infection with cefixime. There is no family history of serious illness. Her temperature is 39.2°C (102.6°F) and pulse is 123/min. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Urine dipstick shows leukocyte esterase; urinalysis shows WBCs. Urine culture shows Escherichia coli sensitive to cefixime. A voiding cystourethrogram is shown. Without treatment, which of the following is this patient most likely to develop?
content_preview: A 2-year-old girl is brought to the physician because of a 1-day history of high-grade fever and crying while passing urine. Four months ago, she was treated for a febrile urinary tract infection with cefixime. There is no family history of serious illness. Her temperature is 39.2°C (102.6°F) and pulse is 123/min. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Urine dipstick shows leukocyte esterase; urinalysis shows WBCs. Urine culture shows Escherichia coli sensitive to cefixime. A voiding cystourethrogram is shown. Without treatment, which of the following is this patient most likely to develop?
hint: This is the patient's second febrile urinary tract infection (UTI) and the voiding cystourethrogram (VCU) shows vesicoureteral reflux (VUR) on the right side.
learning_objective: Recognize vesicoureteral reflux (VUR), and recall its complication of renal scarring.

answers.explanation_why: VUR is not associated with the development of renal cell carcinoma. Von Hippel‑Lindau syndrome, an autosomal dominant condition, is associated with renal cell carcinoma in younger patients, but this patient has no family history of tumors associated with this disease (e.g., renal cell carcinoma, hemangioma), nor would it explain this patient's recurring UTI or findings on voiding cystourethrogram.

Patients with VUR are at increased risk for renal scarring, which is thought to arise from the combination of retrograde flow of urine into the kidneys and increased rates of pyelonephritis. Although VUR and renal scarring have a clear link, the mechanism by which scarring develops is still being investigated. Scarring may be reduced with prophylactic antibiotics, which prevent infections, and surgical correction for those with high-grade vesicoureteral reflux.
Patients with VUR are at increased risk of developing hydronephrosis, not ureter stenosis, due to elevated ureter pressures from the reflux.

Congenital malformations of the female reproductive tract (e.g., bicornuate uterus, Müllerian agenesis) can result in infertility, which can be diagnosed with hysterosalpingography. Although at first glance hysterosalpingography may resemble a VCU (both procedures inject contrast dye into a tubular structure and take serial x-rays of the lower abdomen), a VCU does not delineate the reproductive structures. Instead, it visualizes the urinary tract and can diagnose VUR, which is not associated with infertility.

VUR is not associated with the development of nephrotic syndrome. Instead, the most common cause of nephrotic syndrome in children is minimal change disease (∼ 90% of all cases), the trigger for which is unknown in most cases.

Smoking is the major risk factor for transitional cell bladder carcinoma, which usually manifests as hematuria in older adults. VUR is not associated with the development of transitional cell bladder cancer. However, transitional cell bladder carcinoma and VUR could result in the dissemination of malignant cells to the upper urinary tract.

images.title: Vesicoureteral reflux
images.description: Fluoroscopy (voiding cystourethrogram; supine; frontal view)Reflux of contrast (vesicoureteral reflux; green overlay) from the bladder (B) into the right ureter is seen, without dilation of the ureter. The proximal collecting system and kidney are not visible on this image.U: urethra

question_text: A 4670-g (10-lb 5-oz) male newborn is delivered at term to a 26-year-old woman after prolonged labor. Apgar scores are 9 and 9 at 1 and 5 minutes. Examination in the delivery room shows swelling, tenderness, and crepitus over the left clavicle. There is decreased movement of the left upper extremity. Movement of the hands and wrists is normal. Grasping reflex is normal in both hands. An asymmetric Moro reflex is present. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. An anteroposterior x-ray confirms the diagnosis. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 4670-g (10-lb 5-oz) male newborn is delivered at term to a 26-year-old woman after prolonged labor. Apgar scores are 9 and 9 at 1 and 5 minutes. Examination in the delivery room shows swelling, tenderness, and crepitus over the left clavicle. There is decreased movement of the left upper extremity. Movement of the hands and wrists is normal. Grasping reflex is normal in both hands. An asymmetric Moro reflex is present. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. An anteroposterior x-ray confirms the diagnosis. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: This neonate's physical examination findings (tenderness, swelling, and crepitus over the left clavicle, decreased mobility of the left upper extremity, asymmetric Moro reflex) are consistent with a neonatal clavicle fracture. Both prolonged labor and macrosomia increase the risk of this birth trauma.
learning_objective: Recognize neonatal clavicle fracture, and choose the most appropriate initial management.

answers.explanation_why: Nerve conduction studies are not indicated in cases of uncomplicated neonatal clavicle fracture. This patient's reduced movement of the left upper extremity is most likely a manifestation of pseudoparalysis, not true brachial plexus injury, especially since his hand movement is normal. Decreased ipsilateral extremity movement is believed to take strain off the clavicle and reduce discomfort for the child. If this infant does not recover function by one month of age, a nerve conduction study should be considered to evaluate for underlying nerve damage.
Surgical fixation may be indicated for clavicle fractures in adults, but neonatal clavicle fractures usually do not require surgery.
Physical therapy can enhance recovery for adults with clavicle fractures, but there is no indication for it in neonates.

Parents of a neonate who has a clavicle fracture should be reassured and advised to handle the affected arm gently (e.g., while dressing). To reduce discomfort, the patient's sleeve can be pinned to the front of their shirt with the arm flexed at 90 degrees. Analgesics may also be considered. After 2 weeks, proper healing should be confirmed either via clinical examination (palpable callus formation) or x-ray. The condition usually self-resolves within 2–3 weeks, and long-term complications are not expected.

Neonatal clavicle fracture is most often a clinical diagnosis but an x-ray can be performed to confirm the diagnosis.
Splinting is not indicated for neonatal clavicle fractures.

MRI is not needed for the diagnosis of a neonatal clavicle fracture. Clinical examination is most often sufficient to establish the diagnosis. For uncertain cases, an anteroposterior x-ray is the preferred imaging modality.

question_text: Two hours after delivery, a 3600-g (7-lb 15-oz) female newborn has noisy breathing, bluish discoloration of her lips, and intermittent respiratory distress. She was born at 38 weeks' gestation and required bag-mask resuscitation immediately after delivery. Pregnancy was uncomplicated. Her mother has noticed that the bluish lip discoloration worsens when she feeds and improves when she cries. The newborn's pulse is 163/min, respirations are 62/min, and blood pressure is 60/30 mm Hg. Lungs are clear to auscultation. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following?
content_preview: Two hours after delivery, a 3600-g (7-lb 15-oz) female newborn has noisy breathing, bluish discoloration of her lips, and intermittent respiratory distress. She was born at 38 weeks' gestation and required bag-mask resuscitation immediately after delivery. Pregnancy was uncomplicated. Her mother has noticed that the bluish lip discoloration worsens when she feeds and improves when she cries. The newborn's pulse is 163/min, respirations are 62/min, and blood pressure is 60/30 mm Hg. Lungs are clear to auscultation. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following?
hint: The newborn's condition is associated with CHARGE syndrome.
learning_objective: Recognize bilateral choanal atresia, and recall its diagnostic finding.

answers.content: Diffuse reticulogranular densities on chest x-ray
answers.explanation_why: Diffuse reticulogranular densities on chest x-ray are seen in neonates with neonatal respiratory distress syndrome (NRDS). NRDS is typically seen in premature infants due to impaired synthesis and secretion of surfactant. Affected newborns have tachypnea, expiratory grunting, and cyanosis immediately following birth. However, auscultation of the lungs in newborns with NRDS shows decreased breath sounds, and breathing would not normalize after crying.

Acrocyanosis (blue extremities and a pink trunk) is common in neonates and is not necessarily a sign of a concerning pathology. In premature infants, even transient apnea is not unusual, as their regulatory functions are not yet fully developed. However, this patient shows signs of central cyanosis and intermittent dyspnea, which are unusual, especially for a full-term infant.

A boot-shaped heart on chest x-ray is a typical finding in patients with tetralogy of Fallot (TOF), the most common congenital cyanotic heart disease. In addition to persistent mild cyanosis, patients with TOF may develop recurrent episodes of cyanosis and hypoxia during feeding and crying. However, these tet spells are more common between the ages of 2 and 4 months rather than immediately following birth. In addition, this patient's cyanosis worsens with feeding rather than during a physiologic stressor and improves with crying, which is unlikely in patients with TOF.

images.title: Boot-shaped heart in tetralogy of Fallot
images.description: X-ray chest (PA view) of a patient with a history of tetralogy of FallotThe cardiac apex is upturned from right ventricular hypertrophy, and the pulmonary artery segment is small and concave in appearance as a result of pulmonary stenosis. These findings produce a characteristic boot-shaped heart (green overlay; cf. illustration), seen in some patients with tetralogy of Fallot. Pulmonary vascular markings are diminished as a result of reduced blood flow to the lungs.White dashed outline: normal size and shape of the heart

answers.content: Inability to pass a gastric catheter through the mouth
answers.explanation_why: Insertion of a gastric catheter through the mouth would be impossible in patients with esophageal atresia (EA), in which the upper and lower esophagus are not connected. This congenital defect is often associated with a tracheoesophageal fistula (TEF) between the lower esophagus and trachea. Patients develop cyanotic attacks, excessive foamy secretions at the mouth, and coughing spells immediately after birth. Normalization of breathing after crying suggests another diagnosis.

answers.content: Inability to pass a catheter through the nasal cavity
answers.explanation_why: This patient is presenting shortly after birth with difficulty breathing and cyanosis that worsens when feeding and improves when crying, which are typical symptoms of bilateral choanal atresia. Patients with this condition have complete blockage of both nasal cavities and, therefore, are only able to breathe through their mouths, which results in cyanosis when the mouth is blocked during feeding. The inability to pass a catheter through the nasal cavities supports the presumptive diagnosis of choanal atresia. Confirmatory testing by CT scan or contrast rhinography in the supine position should follow. Unilateral choanal atresia is twice as prevalent as its bilateral counterpart. However, the bilateral type is most frequently associated with other congenital anomalies, most commonly CHARGE syndrome.

images.title: Choanal atresia
images.description: Retropalatal endoscopic viewUnilateral choanal atresia can be seen.

answers.explanation_why: A scaphoid abdomen and barrel-shaped chest are typical findings in patients with a congenital diaphragmatic hernia (CDH). In CDH, herniation of bowel contents into the chest cavity results in pulmonary hypoplasia, and patients develop tachypnea, respiratory distress, and cyanosis. However, in patients with CDH, an absence of breath sounds would be present on auscultation of the ipsilateral chest, and if on the left side (most common), bowel sounds would be present, unlike the normal auscultatory findings in this patient. In addition, the degree of cyanosis would not change during feeding and crying.

question_text: A 7-month-old boy is brought to the physician for a well-child examination. He was born at 36 weeks' gestation and has been healthy since. He is at the 60^th percentile for length and weight. Vital signs are within normal limits. The abdomen is soft and nontender. Examination shows normal scrotal rugae and a circumcised penis. There is a single palpable testicle in the right hemiscrotum. The scrotum is nontender and not enlarged. There is a palpable mass in the left inguinal canal. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 7-month-old boy is brought to the physician for a well-child examination. He was born at 36 weeks' gestation and has been healthy since. He is at the 60th percentile for length and weight. Vital signs are within normal limits. The abdomen is soft and nontender. Examination shows normal scrotal rugae and a circumcised penis. There is a single palpable testicle in the right hemiscrotum. The scrotum is nontender and not enlarged. There is a palpable mass in the left inguinal canal. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: Spontaneous testicular descent should occur by 6 months of age.
learning_objective: Recognize undescended testes, and choose the most appropriate surgical management.

answers.explanation_why: Gonadotropin therapy involves the administration of either human chorionic gonadotropin or gonadotropin-releasing hormone to stimulate gonadal steroidogenesis and promote testicular descent. However, the success rates of gonadotropin therapy are highly variable and there is a possibility of long-term adverse effects (e.g., low testicular volume, infertility) in infants who received gonadotropin therapy. Hormonal therapy with gonadotropins is not recommended for the treatment of cryptorchidism.

Immediate surgical treatment of undescended testes is recommended starting from the corrected age of 6 months because spontaneous descent is unlikely to occur after this time. Early surgery promotes normal testicular growth and improves the chances of fertility. Because the infant has a palpable testis in the inguinal canal, orchiopexy is the surgical procedure of choice. Orchiopexy should ideally be performed between 6–12 months, but no later than 24 months of corrected age.

The rate of cryptorchidism is higher in preterm infants, such as this patient, and in patients who are small for gestational age or have low birth weight. Complications of cryptorchidism include subfertility and testicular cancer (even in patients who underwent timely intervention), inguinal hernia (due to concurrent patent processus vaginalis), and testicular torsion.

images.title: Cryptorchidism
images.description:
Failure of one or both testicles to descend to their natural position in the scrotum. Most common variations (from top to bottom):– abdominal testis (blue): the testicle is located proximal to the internal inguinal ring
– inguinal testis (green): the testicle is located inside the inguinal canal between the external and internal inguinal ring, preventing adequate mobilization (90% of cases)
– suprascrotal testis (purple): the testicle is located distal to the internal inguinal ring and above the scrotum

answers.explanation_why: Orchiectomy for cryptorchidism may be indicated if the undescended testicle is hypoplastic, atrophic, or nonviable. Orchiectomy may also be indicated for an abdominal testis (especially in post-pubertal boys) to minimize the risk of testicular cancer or if the testicular vessels and vas deferens are too short to perform a scrotal orchiopexy, provided that the child has a normal contralateral testis. This patient has an inguinal cryptorchid testis and there is no reason to suspect impaired viability of the testis.

Exploration under anesthesia is recommended in infants with cryptorchidism and nonpalpable testes in order to evaluate for the presence and location of the testes. A nonpalpable testis may be absent (blind-ending cord structures indicate absent testes), atrophic, or located anywhere along the line of testicular descent (intra-abdominal or within the inguinal canal). Since the left testicle of this infant is palpable in the left inguinal canal, exploration under anesthesia is not necessary.

Measurement of serum testosterone level is indicated in addition to gonadotropin and Müllerian inhibiting substance assay to evaluate male infants with bilaterally nonpalpable testes. Testosterone is usually normal in unilateral cryptorchidism and significantly decreased in bilateral cryptorchidism. Assessment of testosterone is not indicated in this boy with unilateral cryptorchidism.

answers.content: Ultrasound of the abdomen and pelvis
answers.explanation_why: Ultrasound of the abdomen and pelvis can be considered in the evaluation of a phenotypically male infant with bilateral nonpalpable testes to evaluate for the presence of a uterus (e.g., due to congenital adrenal hyperplasia). However, an ultrasound of the abdomen and pelvis in a patient with a palpable undescended testis is unlikely to contribute to the diagnosis or affect the course of treatment. Therefore, it is not indicated in this patient.

Spontaneous descent of a cryptorchid testis rarely occurs after 6 months of age. Re-evaluating this patient at 3 years of age would increase the risk of complications (e.g., infertility, testicular torsion). Therefore, another step in management is required.

Genetic karyotyping is indicated in male infants with bilaterally nonpalpable testes to identify if the condition is due to true bilateral cryptorchidism or a disorder of sexual development (e.g., Klinefelter syndrome). It is not indicated in this patient with unilateral cryptorchidism.

Reassurance for cryptorchidism is indicated in boys < 4 months of age since the majority of testicles descend spontaneously by 4 months of age. Spontaneous descent most likely occurs at this time because of a gonadotropic hormone surge (FSH and LH) at around 60–90 days of life. However, spontaneous descent is unlikely to occur after 6 months of age and, therefore, reassurance is not appropriate because uncorrected cryptorchidism is associated with subfertility, infertility, testicular torsion, inguinal hernia, and testicular malignancy.

question_text: A 6-month-old boy is brought to the physician because of a right-sided scrotal swelling for the past 2 months. The swelling is intermittent and appears usually after the patient has been taken outdoors in a baby carrier, and disappears the next morning. The patient was born at term without complications and has been healthy. Examination shows a 3-cm, soft, nontender, and fluctuant right scrotal mass that is reducible and does not extend into the inguinal area. A light held behind the scrotum shines through. There are no bowel sounds in the mass. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?
content_preview: A 6-month-old boy is brought to the physician because of a right-sided scrotal swelling for the past 2 months. The swelling is intermittent and appears usually after the patient has been taken outdoors in a baby carrier, and disappears the next morning. The patient was born at term without complications and has been healthy. Examination shows a 3-cm, soft, nontender, and fluctuant right scrotal mass that is reducible and does not extend into the inguinal area. A light held behind the scrotum shines through. There are no bowel sounds in the mass. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?
hint: This infant presents with an asymptomatic right-sided scrotal swelling that is fluctuant, transilluminates and does not extend into the inguinal region. The swelling increases after the baby has been carried and decreases after sleep. These features are characteristic of a congenital communicating hydrocele.
learning_objective: Recognize congenital communicating hydrocele, and choose the most appropriate management for an asymptomatic infant.

answers.explanation_why:
The scrotal swelling in this infant is typical of a congenital communicating hydrocele, which occurs due to a failed closure of the processus vaginalis during development. This condition resolves spontaneously in most cases by 1 year of age, as the patent processus vaginalis normally closes during the first year of life. Moreover, since this infant's hydrocele is small, it is unlikely to cause pressure-related complications, such as atrophy of the testis or skin erosions. Reassurance and follow-up is, therefore, the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient.

The preliminary diagnosis of a hydrocele can be confirmed by ultrasonography, which typically reveals anechoic fluid. Ligation of the patent processus vaginalis is the procedure of choice for pediatric communicating hydroceles which do not resolve spontaneously by 1 year of age.

Percutaneous drainage is a treatment option for cases of hydrocele in adult patients for whom surgery is contraindicated and when remaining fertility is not a concern. However, drainage is not recommended for congenital hydroceles, since here the hydrocele communicates with the peritoneal cavity and contains peritoneal fluid. In these cases, aspiration brings no benefit, as the processus vaginalis will again fill with peritoneal fluid after the drainage, and hence the hydrocele will recur.

answers.content: Ligation of the patent processus vaginalis
answers.explanation_why: Ligation of the patent processus vaginalis is the procedure of choice for pediatric communicating hydroceles that do not resolve spontaneously. The processus vaginalis is ligated high within the internal inguinal ring to prevent peritoneal fluid from flowing into the tunica vaginalis and thereby reduce the hydrocele. However, considering the age of this child, ligation is not indicated at this stage.

Orchidopexy is the surgical procedure employed to permanently fix a testis in the scrotum for cases of either cryptorchidism or testicular torsion. Typically, an unaffected side is also prophylactically operated on. Testicular torsion is known to occur in neonates, and it could be either in-utero or postnatal. Prenatal torsion presents with few localized findings, but postnatal torsion could present with considerable scrotal swelling. However, the swelling would be extremely tender. In cryptorchidism, the scrotal sac would be empty, which is not the case in this child.

Laparoscopic hernia repair is indicated for uncomplicated hernias (without signs of bowel obstruction or strangulation), usually carried out as an elective procedure. Inguinal hernias that extend into the scrotum may appear as a scrotal enlargement that fluctuates in size. However, they do not transilluminate.

Excision of dilated pampiniform plexus or varicocelectomy is the primary form of treatment for varicoceles. This child presents with a fluctuant, soft scrotal swelling, which could possibly be a varicocele. However, a varicocele would be typically felt like a “bag of worms” on palpation and would not transilluminate. Moreover, varicoceles are more likely to occur in males 15–25 years of age rather than in infants and are not seen as reducible swellings.

images.title: Varicocele
images.description: Swelling of the left hemiscrotum with prominent tortuous veins and shiny appearance of the scrotal skin. Unlike secondary varicoceles (e.g., due to a renal tumor), idiopathic varicoceles are usually more pronounced when the patient is standing up and disappear when he lies down.

question_text: A 3-year-old boy is brought to the physician for presurgical evaluation before undergoing splenectomy. One year ago, he was diagnosed with hereditary spherocytosis and has received 6 blood transfusions for severe anemia since then. His only medication is a folate supplement. Immunizations are up-to-date. His temperature is 36.7°C (98°F), pulse is 115/min, respirations are 24/min, and blood pressure is 110/60 mm Hg. Examination shows conjunctival pallor and jaundice. The spleen tip is palpated 5 cm below the left costal margin. Which of the following is the most appropriate recommendation to prevent future morbidity and mortality in this patient?
content_preview: A 3-year-old boy is brought to the physician for presurgical evaluation before undergoing splenectomy. One year ago, he was diagnosed with hereditary spherocytosis and has received 6 blood transfusions for severe anemia since then. His only medication is a folate supplement. Immunizations are up-to-date. His temperature is 36.7°C (98°F), pulse is 115/min, respirations are 24/min, and blood pressure is 110/60 mm Hg. Examination shows conjunctival pallor and jaundice. The spleen tip is palpated 5 cm below the left costal margin. Which of the following is the most appropriate recommendation to prevent future morbidity and mortality in this patient?
hint: After a splenectomy, a patient's defense system against encapsulated pathogens is impaired.
learning_objective: Choose the most appropriate post-splenectomy prophylactic measure to prevent infections in pediatric patients.

answers.explanation_why: Iron chelation therapy with deferoxamine is indicated for patients who receive multiple red blood cell transfusions (e.g., thalassemia major, sickle cell anemia, aplastic anemia). In hereditary spherocytosis, however, near-complete resolution of hemolysis would occur following splenectomy and multiple transfusions would not be necessary.

This 3-year-old child would have already received 3 routine immunizations against hepatitis B: at birth, 1–2 months after birth, and then between 6 and 18 months. Additional immunization against hepatitis B is not recommended since the risk of infection is not increased by asplenia.

Immunoglobulins required for the opsonization of encapsulated organisms are predominantly produced in the white pulp of the spleen. Asplenic patients are therefore at increased risk of developing overwhelming postsplenectomy infections (OPSI) by encapsulated organisms such as Streptococcus pneumoniae, Neisseria meningitidis, and Haemophilus influenzae type B because these pathogens are no longer opsonized by IgG antibodies and phagocytosed by splenic macrophages. In addition to vaccination against these pathogens, which should occur either > 2 weeks before scheduled splenectomy or > 2 weeks after splenectomy, pediatric patients should also receive continuous antibiotic prophylaxis with oral penicillin or amoxicillin at least until the age of five years. A longer duration of antibiotic prophylaxis can be considered, especially in immunosuppressed individuals (e.g., with HIV infection, congenital immunodeficiencies, chronic liver disease).

The risk of sepsis remains increased for up to 30 years after splenectomy but is highest in asplenic children. Adults are not routinely prescribed antibiotic prophylaxis after splenectomy. OPSI, however, has a high mortality rate if left untreated, and patients should receive empirical therapy with vancomycin and an intravenous third-generation cephalosporin (e.g., ceftriaxone, cefotaxime) immediately upon suspicion of OPSI.

Reactive thrombocytosis often occurs following splenectomy, and low-dose aspirin could be considered if this child had a high platelet count postoperatively. Reactive thrombocytosis alone is, however, not an indication for thromboprophylaxis with warfarin.

Hydroxyurea can be used on an off-label basis to treat severe reactive thrombocytosis, which may occur following splenectomy. Hydroxyurea should not, however, be routinely given to all patients who undergo splenectomy.

In hereditary spherocytosis, hemolysis occurs by phagocytic destruction of abnormally shaped red blood cells that get mechanically sequestered within the spleen (i.e., in a process that is not dependent on antibodies). B-cell inhibition with rituximab would not have any benefit, as near-complete resolution of hemolysis is expected following splenectomy.

question_text: A 16-year-old boy comes to the physician because of painless enlargement of his left scrotum for the past 2 weeks. The patient reports that the enlargement is worse in the evenings, especially after playing soccer. He has not had any trauma to the testes. He has not had inguinal pain. He started to become sexually active with his girlfriend 3 weeks ago; they use condoms regularly. There is no personal or family history of serious illness and he takes no medications. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination of the external genitalia shows no groin protrusion and no penile discharge or lesions. Inguinal lymph nodes are normal. There is a palpable soft, irregular swelling above the left testis. This swelling is more prominent while standing and disappears in the supine position. Right scrotal examination shows no abnormalities. The patient is at greatest risk of developing which of the following complications?

The patient reports that the enlargement is worse in the evenings, especially after playing soccer. He has not had any trauma to the testes. He has not had inguinal pain. He started to become sexually active with his girlfriend 3 weeks ago; they use condoms regularly. There is no personal or family history of serious illness and he takes no medications. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination of the external genitalia shows no groin protrusion and no penile discharge or lesions. Inguinal lymph nodes are normal. There is a palpable soft, irregular swelling above the left testis. This swelling is more prominent while standing and disappears in the supine position. Right scrotal examination shows no abnormalities. The patient is at greatest risk of developing which of the following complications?
hint: Vague discomfort and soft, irregular swelling in the scrotal region that enlarges on standing or with a Valsalva maneuver suggests a varicocele, which most commonly occurs during adolescence.
learning_objective: Recognize varicocele, and recall its complications.

answers.explanation_why: The risk of bowel strangulation is increased in patients with inguinal and scrotal hernias, which can manifest as a painless scrotal swelling that increases in size on standing up and on performing the Valsalva maneuver. However, such hernias typically manifest with pain localized to the inguinal region and a visible or palpable groin bulge. An isolated soft scrotal mass is not characteristic of a groin hernia.
A scrotal hematoma can occur following the rupture of a varicocele, but this complication is extremely rare and only a few cases have been reported to date.

Risk factors for testicular torsion include puberty (due to the sudden increase in testicular volume), testicular tumors, testicles with a horizontal lie, undescended testes, a spermatic cord with a long intrascrotal portion, and extension of the tunica vaginalis over the proximal spermatic cord (bell-clapper anatomical variant). However, this patient has a varicocele, which does not increase the risk of testicular torsion.

Cryptorchidism, which manifests as an empty scrotal sac, is a known risk factor for a testicular tumor. A palpable lump may be present in the inguinal region if the undescended testis is located within the inguinal canal. In this patient, however, both the testes are palpated within the scrotal sac. Intermittent hemiscrotal swelling with cord-like structures above the testis indicates a varicocele, which is not a known risk factor for testicular tumors.

Varicoceles can result in testicular atrophy and infertility. The most probable mechanism is impaired spermatogenesis as a result of increased testicular temperature and testicular ischemia (due to increased intratesticular pressure, venous stasis, and/or vasoconstriction secondary to catecholamine reflux from the adrenal gland). The diagnosis of a varicocele is confirmed by ultrasonography, which should reveal dilated pampiniform veins.

In young men, semen analysis should be performed regularly to assess sperm number and quality. Most asymptomatic patients do not require intervention. Definitive treatment with laparoscopic varicocelectomy or percutaneous embolization is indicated for those with intractable discomfort and/or abnormalities on semen analysis.

images.title: Varicocele
images.description: A varicocele is a dilatation of the pampiniform venous plexus in the scrotum.

question_text: A 2500-g (5-lb 8-oz) male newborn is delivered at 35 weeks' gestation to a 25-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 1. The pregnancy was complicated by oligohydramnios. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 78%. Examination in the delivery room shows that the newborn's skin appears blue. He has a weak cry with irregular breathing and gasping. The nose is flat with prominent bilateral epicanthal folds. The ears are low-set with broad auricles. The lower jaw is abnormally displaced backwards. The right lower limb appears shorter than the left lower limb with displaced right great toe. Breath sounds are decreased bilaterally. Renal ultrasound shows bilateral dilatation of the renal pelvis and ureters. Which of the following is most likely to confirm the underlying cause of this patient's condition?
content_preview: A 2500-g (5-lb 8-oz) male newborn is delivered at 35 weeks' gestation to a 25-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 1. The pregnancy was complicated by oligohydramnios. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 78%. Examination in the delivery room shows that the newborn's skin appears blue. He has a weak cry with irregular breathing and gasping. The nose is flat with prominent bilateral epicanthal folds. The ears are low-set with broad auricles. The lower jaw is abnormally displaced backwards. The right lower limb appears shorter than the left lower limb with displaced right great toe. Breath sounds are decreased bilaterally. Renal ultrasound shows bilateral dilatation of the renal pelvis and ureters. Which of the following is most likely to confirm the underlying cause of this patient's condition?
hint: This newborn has features suggestive of Potter sequence: respiratory distress, Potter facies, limb anomalies, and a pregnancy complicated by oligohydramnios.
learning_objective: Recognize Potter sequence, and choose the most appropriate diagnostic study.

answers.explanation_why:
Voiding cystourethrogram is the test of choice to diagnose posterior urethral valves (PUV), which is the most common cause of urinary tract obstruction (UTO) in newborn males. Lower UTO, indicated by the presence of bilateral hydronephrosis on renal ultrasound, results in reduced urine output and oligohydramnios. The decreased amount of amniotic fluid leads to the development of Potter sequence. Moreover, oligohydramnios can affect the development of the fetal lung resulting in lung hypoplasia, which is the most likely cause of this patient's cyanosis and hypoxia.

Once the vital functions have been stabilized, temporary insertion of a urinary catheter can relieve the UTO and allow for correction of possible electrolyte imbalances. Definitive treatment of PUV is either primary valve ablation during cystoscopy (first-line) or vesicostomy (in preterm boys or if ablation is not possible).

Echocardiography is used to confirm congenital heart defects. Cyanotic heart defects may present shortly after birth with respiratory distress and cyanosis. Some of these defects are associated with certain genetic/chromosomal abnormalities (e.g., tetralogy of Fallot or persistent truncus arteriosus with DiGeorge syndrome), which often present with craniofacial anomalies. However, the patient's hydronephrosis and limb abnormalities cannot be explained by this diagnosis.

Karyotyping confirms chromosomal abnormalities, which are frequently associated with dysmorphic facial and limb abnormalities. Low-set ears and retrognathia can be seen in patients with Edwards syndrome. A flattened nose and epicanthus are features of Down syndrome. The combination of oligohydramnios, hydronephrosis, and respiratory distress in the newborn period would not be typical for a chromosomal aberration. Certain causes of Potter sequence are associated with chromosomal aberrations. However, these abnormalities usually account for bilateral renal agenesis, whereas this infant's ultrasound confirms the presence of two kidneys.

Blood cultures are essential in a newborn with respiratory distress to rule out sepsis. Early-onset sepsis (≤ 72 hours after birth) is often due to chorioamnionitis or bacterial colonization of the maternal genital tract (e.g., with group B Streptococcus). While the symptoms of neonatal sepsis may be nonspecific, infants with neonatal pneumonia typically present with dyspnea and decreased breath sounds, as seen in the vignette. However, neonatal pneumonia would not explain hydronephrosis and dysmorphia in this child.

In patients with Potter sequence, chest x-ray may reveal pulmonary hypoplasia as the cause of this patient's respiratory distress, but it does not reveal the underlying mechanism of the condition. Chest x-ray is used, however, for diagnosing infant respiratory distress syndrome (IRDS) and meconium aspiration. IRDS manifests most frequently in preterm infants, usually immediately after birth, with signs of increased breathing effort, hypoxia, cyanosis, and decreased breath sounds on auscultation. However, the additional clinical features seen in this neonate (e.g., craniofacial dysmorphism, limb abnormalities, and hydronephrosis) could not be explained by this diagnosis. Meconium aspiration syndrome manifests with respiratory distress or unresponsiveness usually in postterm rather than preterm infants. Furthermore, the absence of a green amniotic fluid makes the diagnosis unlikely in this patient.

question_text: A 2-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of a 2-day history of fatigue and yellow discoloration of his skin. One week ago, he had a 3-day course of low-grade fever and runny nose. As a newborn, he underwent a 5-day course of phototherapy for neonatal jaundice. His vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows jaundice of the skin and conjunctivae. The spleen tip is palpated 3 cm below the left costal margin. His hemoglobin is 9.8 g/dL and mean corpuscular hemoglobin concentration is 38% Hb/cell. A Coombs test is negative. A peripheral blood smear is shown. This patient is at greatest risk for which of the following complications?
content_preview: A 2-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of a 2-day history of fatigue and yellow discoloration of his skin. One week ago, he had a 3-day course of low-grade fever and runny nose. As a newborn, he underwent a 5-day course of phototherapy for neonatal jaundice. His vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows jaundice of the skin and conjunctivae. The spleen tip is palpated 3 cm below the left costal margin. His hemoglobin is 9.8 g/dL and mean corpuscular hemoglobin concentration is 38% Hb/cell. A Coombs test is negative. A peripheral blood smear is shown. This patient is at greatest risk for which of the following complications?
hint: The blood smear shows spherocytes without central pallor.
learning_objective: Recognize hereditary spherocytosis, and recall its complications.

answers.explanation_why: Skeletal deformities (high forehead, prominent zygomatic bones and maxilla) are associated with thalassemia, particularly beta-thalassemia major. While beta-thalassemia causes anemia, jaundice, and splenomegaly, it would cause decreased, not increased, mean corpuscular hemoglobin concentration. Additionally, the peripheral smear would show hypochromic erythrocytes, target cells (image), and teardrop cells, and not spherocytes.

Some hemoglobinopathies (particularly sickle cell anemia) actually protect against malaria, likely because the plasmodia responsible for malaria are unable to multiply sufficiently within the defective erythrocytes.

Acute chest syndrome (chest pain, shortness of breath from vasoocclusion of pulmonary capillaries) is associated with sickle cell anemia (SCA), which may manifest with low hemoglobin and an elevated mean corpuscular hemoglobin concentration. However, SCA would show sickle cells or target cells on the peripheral smear, rather than spherocytes.

Renal papillary necrosis is associated with sickle cell anemia (SCA) and results from vasoocclusion of blood vessels in the vasa recta. SCA may manifest with low hemoglobin and can cause an elevated mean corpuscular hemoglobin concentration. However, SCA would show sickle cells or target cells on the peripheral smear (image), and would not be associated with spherocytes.

Osteomyelitis is associated with sickle cell anemia (SCA), arising from infection of ischemic or infarcted areas of bone. SCA may manifest with low hemoglobin and can result in elevated mean corpuscular hemoglobin concentration. However, SCA would show sickle cells or target cells on the peripheral smear, rather than spherocytes.

Acute myelogenous leukemia is associated with paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH). PNH may manifest with anemia and jaundice, but cannot explain this patient's elevated mean corpuscular hemoglobin concentration or spherocytes on peripheral smear.

Splenomegaly, jaundice, anemia, elevated mean corpuscular hemoglobin concentration, and characteristic spherocytes on the peripheral smear are indicative of hereditary spherocytosis. Recurrent extravascular hemolysis of fragile red blood cells within the spleen (typically worsened by viral infections, as seen in this boy) leads to increased bilirubin and formation of calcium bilirubinate gallstones, predisposing to cholecystitis. Additional findings may include increased red cell distribution width and increased reticulocyte count. Splenectomy can prevent the destruction and removal of spherocytes, thereby preventing the development of gallstones.

Recurrent infections with Neisseria meningitidis (an encapsulated organism), rather than Neisseria gonorrhoeae (an unencapsulated organism), can occur as a complication of splenectomy or functional asplenia (due to sickle cell anemia), as patients are at greater risk of infection with encapsulated organisms.

Esophageal webs are associated with Plummer-Vinson syndrome (PVS). While PVS may manifest with anemia (from iron deficiency anemia) and splenomegaly, it is not associated with jaundice or elevated mean corpuscular hemoglobin concentration. In addition, a peripheral smear would show erythrocytes with an increased zone of central pallor, not lack of central pallor.

images.title: Spherocytosis
images.description: Photomicrograph of a peripheral blood smearMultiple spherocytes can be seen (red circles), which have a typical round (rather than biconcave) shape and no central pallor. The erythrocytes vary significantly in size, which is consistent with anisocytosis (red arrows). On electron microscopy (overlay box with drawings based on EM appearance), the spherical shape of spherocytes (1) and normal biconcave erythrocytes (2) can be seen.

question_text: A 4-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department because of severe abdominal pain and bilious vomiting for 6 hours. He has not had bowel movements in the past 24 hours. He appears ill. His temperature is 37.8°C (100.0°F) and pulse is 122/min. Examination shows a distended abdomen. There is tenderness to palpation in the lower abdomen; guarding and rebound tenderness are present. Bowel sounds are decreased. An x-ray of the abdomen shows dilated bowel loops. He has been accompanied by his 14-year-old brother. The surgeon recommends an emergency laparotomy. The parents are away visiting friends and cannot be reached. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 4-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department because of severe abdominal pain and bilious vomiting for 6 hours. He has not had bowel movements in the past 24 hours. He appears ill. His temperature is 37.8°C (100.0°F) and pulse is 122/min. Examination shows a distended abdomen. There is tenderness to palpation in the lower abdomen; guarding and rebound tenderness are present. Bowel sounds are decreased. An x-ray of the abdomen shows dilated bowel loops. He has been accompanied by his 14-year-old brother. The surgeon recommends an emergency laparotomy. The parents are away visiting friends and cannot be reached. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: This patient's condition is considered a surgical emergency.
learning_objective: Recognize exceptions to the requirement for parental consent in pediatric emergencies.

answers.content: Get consent from the patient's brother
answers.explanation_why: This patient's 14-year-old brother is legally a minor (and even if emancipated, not the legal guardian) and cannot consent to nor refuse his brother's medical care.

As a minor (< 18 years of age in most US states), this patient usually cannot consent to his own medical care. Minors can only consent if they are legally emancipated through military service, marriage, court petition, or if they are seeking care regarding contraception, pregnancy, STIs, or substance abuse. Legal emancipation often requires a minimum age (e.g., 16 years) and requirements vary a lot from state to state.

answers.content: Obtain a court order for surgery
answers.explanation_why: Obtaining a court order is the best next step in providing care if a minor's parents are refusing life-saving treatment for a non-emergent but ultimately fatal condition. This patient's case requires a prompt decision regarding immediate management.

A hospital ethics committee should be consulted if a patient cannot provide consent and his or her surrogate decision maker is not available or thought to be acting contrary to the patient's preferred decision or against the patient's best interest. In this time-sensitive situation, another approach is indicated.

Although parental consent is usually required at all times in minors (< 18 years of age in most US states) who are not emancipated before receiving medical care, informed consent does not apply in emergency situations where there is a legal obligation to treat in order to save a child's life. Other cases in which informed consent by the parents is not required are: substance abuse treatment, birth control, prenatal care, and treatment for sexually transmitted diseases.
Although parental consent is typically required before a minor can undergo a medical procedure or treatment, this time-sensitive situation requires a different management approach.
