question_text: A previously healthy 6-year-old boy is brought to the physician because he has increased facial and axillary hair. There is no family history of serious illness. He is at 95th percentile for height and weight. Examination shows coarse pubic and axillary hair. The penis and left testicle are enlarged. Serum concentrations of human chorionic gonadotropin and alpha-fetoprotein are within the reference range. Which of the following is the most likely cause of these findings?
content_preview: A previously healthy 6-year-old boy is brought to the physician because he has increased facial and axillary hair. There is no family history of serious illness. He is at 95th percentile for height and weight. Examination shows coarse pubic and axillary hair. The penis and left testicle are enlarged. Serum concentrations of human chorionic gonadotropin and alpha-fetoprotein are within the reference range. Which of the following is the most likely cause of these findings?
hint: Laboratory studies in this patient would likely show elevated testosterone and estrogen levels.
learning_objective: Recognize a Leydig cell tumor.

answers.explanation_why:
Leydig cell tumors are rare testicular tumors that usually develop after the age of 4. The tumors typically manifest as painless testicular masses and produce large amounts of testosterone as well as smaller amounts of estrogen, progesterone, and corticosteroids. The excess in androgens leads to precocious pseudopuberty in boys with prominent external genitalia, accelerated skeletomuscular development, mature masculine voice, and growth of facial, axillary, and pubic hair. GnRH, FSH, and LH levels are decreased in response to the elevated androgen levels in precocious pseudopuberty. The treatment of Leydig-cell tumors consists of surgical resection using radical inguinal orchiectomy.

See “Overview of testicular tumors” table.

Teratomas are more common in children and can manifest with a painless testicular mass and typically normal alpha-fetoprotein and human chorionic gonadotropin levels. However, they usually do not secrete hormones and thus do not cause precocious puberty.

Seminomas can manifest with a painless testicular mass and normal alpha-fetoprotein and human chorionic gonadotropin levels. However, these tumors have a peak incidence in the fourth decade of life and do not cause precocious puberty.

Sertoli cell tumors can manifest with a painless testicular mass and normal alpha-fetoprotein and human chorionic gonadotropin levels. However, these tumors are more common in older males (with a peak incidence of around 40 years). Furthermore, although Sertoli cell tumors can also produce hormones, they more commonly secrete estrogen so that gynecomastia, rather than virilization is seen.

Choriocarcinoma can also present as a painless testicular mass and cause precocious puberty if it occurs in young children such as in this patient. However, human chorionic gonadotropin levels are usually markedly increased (which causes precocious puberty secondary to increased production of testosterone).

Lymphomas can manifest with a painless testicular mass and normal alpha-fetoprotein and human chorionic gonadotropin levels. However, these tumors are more common in adults and do not cause precocious puberty. Additionally, other symptoms, such as weight loss, fever, or night sweats, are often present.

question_text: A 3-week-old male newborn is brought to the emergency department by his parents because of 4 episodes of vomiting that occurred that morning. The parents report that the vomit was yellowish-green with no blood in it. The patient was born at 38 weeks' gestation via vaginal delivery and has generally been healthy. He has passed normal stools each day. There is no family history of serious illness. He appears irritable and pale. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 146/min, and blood pressure is 90/55 mm Hg. Examination shows a soft, mildly distended abdomen with no masses or organomegaly. A nasogastric tube is inserted, and intravenous fluid resuscitation is initiated. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 3-week-old male newborn is brought to the emergency department by his parents because of 4 episodes of vomiting that occurred that morning. The parents report that the vomit was yellowish-green with no blood in it. The patient was born at 38 weeks' gestation via vaginal delivery and has generally been healthy. He has passed normal stools each day. There is no family history of serious illness. He appears irritable and pale. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 146/min, and blood pressure is 90/55 mm Hg. Examination shows a soft, mildly distended abdomen with no masses or organomegaly. A nasogastric tube is inserted, and intravenous fluid resuscitation is initiated. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: This 3-week-old neonate presents with acute-onset bilious vomiting and a mildly distended abdomen, which should raise suspicion for midgut obstruction, most likely due to intestinal malrotation.
learning_objective: Recognize midgut obstruction in a neonate, and choose the most appropriate diagnostic test.

answers.explanation_why: CT imaging should not be performed on this patient. This patient has features that are most concerning for an anatomical obstruction in the midgut, and other diagnostic tests provide better visualization of this region. Moreover, a CT scan would expose this neonate to unnecessary radiation.

Laparoscopy would be indicated if further diagnostic workup did not establish a definitive diagnosis or was suggestive of malrotation with a complicating volvulus. In this neonate, further studies should be performed first to confirm the diagnosis.

An upper gastrointestinal contrast series is the most sensitive exam to visualize the duodenum in infants and the gold standard for diagnosis of intestinal malrotation with midgut volvulus. The obvious signs of malrotation are a misplaced ligament of Treitz and duodenojejunal junction on the right of the midline. A twisted and thus corkscrew-like appearance of the duodenum and duodenal blockage with a distended stomach would reflect midgut volvulus. See “Imaging in intestinal malrotation and midgut volvulus” table.

Given this neonate's hemodynamic stability, there is no indication for emergency surgery, but the Ladd procedure is recommended as soon as possible to minimize the risk of future volvulus.

images.title: Malrotation with midgut volvulus
images.description: Fluoroscopy (upper GI series)The distal duodenum and proximal jejunum has a spiral configuration (green overlay) and fail to cross the midline into the left upper quadrant. This appearance, referred to as the corkscrew sign, is produced by the twisting of small bowel loops on a shortened mesentery.The corkscrew sign is characteristic of intestinal malrotation with midgut volvulus.

answers.explanation_why: Water-soluble contrast enema is used as a confirmatory test and therapeutic tool for intussusception, which also manifests in infants with vomiting. However, as most cases of intussusception are ileocecal, bilious vomiting occurs only in progressive disease. Additionally, patients typically present between 3–12 months of age and usually also have acute cyclical abdominal pain (every 15–30 minutes) and possibly a palpable mass on abdominal exam.

Emergency exploratory laparotomy is indicated in cases of hemodynamic instability and/or bowel ischemia or perforation. This patient is hemodynamically stable, is afebrile, and has a soft abdomen, indicating that further diagnostic workup is safe. Should he decompensate and develop profound tachycardia, hypotension, signs of perforation (e.g., free air under the diaphragm on repeat plain film), or signs of bowel infarction (e.g. hematochezia), emergency surgery would be indicated.

Abdominal ultrasound is an important imaging modality for differentiating between causes of abdominal pain in children. It is most helpful in establishing the diagnosis of pyloric stenosis, which also manifests with acute-onset emesis and abdominal pain. Classically, an olive-shaped mass can be felt on abdominal exam; this patient's abdominal exam is notable for mild distention but no mass is evident. Moreover, the patient described here has bilious vomiting, a finding that is less likely with an obstruction caused by a hypertrophic pylorus, which is proximal to the ampulla of Vater and is therefore more commonly associated with nonbilious vomiting. While ultrasonography can be used in the diagnosis of intestinal malrotation and midgut volvulus, it is not the most sensitive diagnostic technique. For this reason, it is not the most appropriate next step in management.

Flexible sigmoidoscopy is used to treat sigmoid volvulus in patients who have no signs or symptoms of peritonitis (e.g., rebound tenderness, hemodynamic instability). Sigmoid volvulus is most commonly seen in elderly adults and manifests with abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, and bloating. This young patient most likely has a more proximal intestinal pathology, meaning that sigmoidoscopy would not be appropriate.

question_text: A 3-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his mother because of abdominal pain that started one hour ago after drinking from a bottle of toilet cleaner. The mother reports that he vomited once on the way to the hospital and his vomit was nonbloody. The patient has pain with swallowing. He appears uncomfortable. Pulse oximetry shows an oxygen saturation of 82%. Examination shows heavy salivation. Oral examination shows mild oral erythema in the area of the epiglottis, but no burns. An x-ray of the chest shows no abnormalities. The patient is admitted to the intensive care unit. He is intubated and oxygenation and intravenous fluid resuscitation are begun. All contaminated clothes are removed. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 3-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his mother because of abdominal pain that started one hour ago after drinking from a bottle of toilet cleaner. The mother reports that he vomited once on the way to the hospital and his vomit was nonbloody. The patient has pain with swallowing. He appears uncomfortable. Pulse oximetry shows an oxygen saturation of 82%. Examination shows heavy salivation. Oral examination shows mild oral erythema in the area of the epiglottis, but no burns. An x-ray of the chest shows no abnormalities. The patient is admitted to the intensive care unit. He is intubated and oxygenation and intravenous fluid resuscitation are begun. All contaminated clothes are removed. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: This patient presents with abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, odynophagia, and heavy salivation that began shortly after ingestion of toilet cleaner, which often contains caustic substances.
learning_objective: Recognize caustic ingestion, and choose the most appropriate diagnostic procedure.

answers.explanation_why:
Acute treatment of caustic ingestion includes airway management, supplemental oxygen, fluid resuscitation, and decontamination (e.g., removal of contaminated clothes). Upper endoscopy within 12–24 hours should be performed in symptomatic patients to assess the severity of esophageal injury and guide further therapy, such as the need for surgery. Endoscopy is contraindicated in cases of airway compromise (e.g., burns in the area of the epiglottis) and overt esophageal perforation seen on initial radiography imaging (e.g., x-ray or CT scan). If the airway is compromised, intubation needs to be performed first (as was done in this patient). In overt perforation, immediate surgery is required.

Long-term sequelae of caustic ingestion include esophageal strictures and squamous cell carcinoma of the esophagus.

A tube that is passed blindly through the esophagus into the stomach can damage the already injured esophageal lining. Furthermore, gastric lavage can induce vomiting or push some of the stomach contents back into the esophagus. In both cases, the esophagus would again be exposed to the caustic agent, potentially causing further damage. Therefore, gastric lavage is contraindicated for the treatment of caustic ingestion.

Dilution should not be attempted as it increases the risk of vomiting. Vomiting would reintroduce the ingested caustic agent to the esophagus and cause damage to the already injured esophageal mucosa. Neutralizing the caustic agent with the application of acid is also absolutely contraindicated as this can lead to chemical reactions that would further damage the esophagus.

A barium upper gastrointestinal series is not part of the initial management of caustic ingestion. If there is a perforation, barium would leak into the mediastinum and potentially cause mediastinitis. If perforation is suspected, a water-soluble contrast agent should be used instead. Barium swallow may be useful for evaluating strictures or stenoses 2–3 weeks after the ingestion.

Charcoal is used to treat certain kinds of poisoning. The charcoal can bind the poison and prevent intestinal resorption. But in the case of caustic ingestion, intestinal resorption is not the main issue. Instead, the caustic agent can cause severe burns to the mucosal lining of the gastrointestinal tract, which would not be prevented through activated charcoal.
Inducing vomiting is contraindicated. The ingested caustic agent could cause further damage if it is regurgitated through the already damaged esophagus.

question_text:
A 17-year-old boy comes to the physician for a follow-up examination. Two months ago, he suffered a spinal fracture after a fall from the roof, which was managed with external bracing, physical therapy, and rest. He feels well. His father has multiple endocrine neoplasia type 1. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show:

Hemoglobin

Which of the following is the most likely cause of these findings?
content_preview: A 17-year-old boy comes to the physician for a follow-up examination. Two months ago, he suffered a spinal fracture after a fall from the roof, which was managed with external bracing, physical therapy, and rest. He feels well. His father has multiple endocrine neoplasia type 1. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show: Hemoglobin 13.7 g/dL Serum Creatinine 0.7 mg/dL Proteins Total 7.0 g/dL Albumin 4.1 g/dL Calcium 11.4 mg/dL Phosphorus 5.3 mg/dL Alkaline phosphatase 130 U/L Which of the following is the most likely cause of these findings?
hint: The hypercalcemia in this adolescent is due to excess osteoclastic bone resorption.
learning_objective: Recognize hypercalcemia due to immobilization.

answers.explanation_why: Granulomatous diseases such as sarcoidosis can result in hypercalcemia as a result of ectopic vitamin D production by activated mononuclear cells (e.g., macrophages) of lungs and lymph nodes. Alkaline phosphatase levels may also be increased due to hepatic granuloma formation. However, phosphate levels are usually normal, and this patient lacks clinical features that would suggest sarcoidosis (e.g., dyspnea, lymphadenopathy, iridocyclitis, skin plaques).
Familial hypocalciuric hypercalcemia would result in elevated calcium and mildly elevated alkaline phosphatase levels. However, phosphate levels would be either normal or decreased.
Prolonged immobilization (e.g., following a vertebral fracture) can lead to increased bone demineralization with mild hypercalcemia, hyperphosphatemia, and increased alkaline phosphatase.

The family history of multiple endocrine neoplasia might suggest a diagnosis of parathyroid adenoma, which would result in hypercalcemia and mildly increased alkaline phosphatase levels (as a result of primary hyperparathyroidism). However, patients with parathyroid adenoma would have hypophosphatemia because parathyroid hormone (PTH) receptor activation in the proximal convoluted tubule decreases renal phosphate reabsorption.

Pseudohypercalcemia occurs in patients with increased serum protein concentration (e.g., hyperalbuminemia in dehydrated patients, paraproteinemia in patients with multiple myeloma) because approximately half of all serum calcium is bound to serum proteins. This patient, however, has normal albumin and serum total protein levels.

Paraneoplastic production of the PTH-related peptide (PTHrP) by tumors (e.g., neuroblastoma, renal tumors, and leukemia) can result in hypercalcemia and mildly increased alkaline phosphatase levels. Phosphate levels, however, would be decreased because parathyroid hormone (PTH) receptor activation in the proximal convoluted tubule decreases renal phosphate reabsorption. This patient also lacks any clinical feature that would suggest an underlying malignancy (e.g., weight loss, fatigue, bone pain, abdominal pain, hematuria).

question_text: A 2-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department because of a prolonged episode of coughing that started 30 minutes ago. His mother says her son was playing with some new toys, including a squirt gun, a robot, and some plastic building blocks he got for his birthday when the symptoms began. The coughing lasted several minutes, after which he was crying but could be soothed by his mother. He is otherwise healthy and his immunizations are up-to-date. He is alert and babbles. His temperature is 37.4°C (99.3°F), pulse is 139/min, respirations are 34/min, and blood pressure is 96/47 mm Hg. The oropharynx is clear and cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. The abdomen is soft and nontender to palpation. X-rays of the chest are shown. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the management?
content_preview: A 2-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department because of a prolonged episode of coughing that started 30 minutes ago. His mother says her son was playing with some new toys, including a squirt gun, a robot, and some plastic building blocks he got for his birthday when the symptoms began. The coughing lasted several minutes, after which he was crying but could be soothed by his mother. He is otherwise healthy and his immunizations are up-to-date. He is alert and babbles. His temperature is 37.4°C (99.3°F), pulse is 139/min, respirations are 34/min, and blood pressure is 96/47 mm Hg. The oropharynx is clear and cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. The abdomen is soft and nontender to palpation. X-rays of the chest are shown. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the management?
hint: The foreign body this patient has ingested is thin, circular, and shows a double-rim (halo) on chest x-ray which indicates that it is a button battery.
learning_objective: Recognize button battery ingestion, and choose the most appropriate management.

answers.explanation_why: Administration of ipecac as an emetic is not recommended as treatment for toxic ingestion. There is insufficient evidence to support that syrup of ipecac improves outcomes in cases of poisoning. Moreover, its side effects, such as lethargy, complicate diagnosis.

answers.content: Removal of the foreign body with magnet and nasogastric tube
answers.explanation_why: Removal of the battery with a magnet and nasogastric tube would not allow visualization of the esophageal mucosa and any injury that may be present.

Reassurance and observation would be inappropriate in this case. The alkali material in this battery, which is lodged in the esophagus, can cause chemical burns and injury of the mucosa 2 hours after ingestion, even in an asymptomatic patient.

Conservative management can be considered if the battery is located in the bowel and the patient is asymptomatic. In this patient with a button battery in an esophageal location, treatment should not be delayed because of the risk of caustic injury from the battery.

Chelation therapy can be used to manage metal poisoning. While ingestion of a battery containing mercury can elevate blood mercury levels, this patient does not have any symptoms of mercury toxicity, such as intention tremor, ataxia, or psychiatric disturbances.

Emergency endoscopic removal is necessary for all ingested batteries that become lodged in the esophagus. Because alkali material leaking from the battery may cause severe chemical burns 2 hours after ingestion, removal is necessary regardless of whether the patient is symptomatic or not. Removal should not be delayed, even if the patient has eaten. Endoscopic removal allows visualization and assessment of any tissue damage. The position of the negative pole of the battery should also be assessed during endoscopy. The negative pole causes the most severe necrotic injury. Possible complications of a mucosal injury include tracheal stenosis, tracheomalacia, fistula, perforation, and mediastinitis.

images.title: Button battery impaction in esophagus
images.description: X-ray chest (PA and lateral views) of a young childA well-defined disc-shaped metallic foreign body is seen behind the trachea in the upper esophagus. On close inspection, a double rim (dashed lines), or halo (green overlay), is visible on the PA view, which indicates that it is a button battery. A step-off (arrows) to the small diameter anode (hatched green overlay) is seen on the lateral view.Recognition of a button battery in the esophagus is a pediatric emergency. Radiographs can frequently differentiate button batteries from similarly sized coins and ascertain the direction of the anode, where the most severe damage from the battery occurs. The anode step-off (arrows) may not be visible on some very thin batteries.

question_text: A 7-year-old girl is brought to the physician by her parents for a well-child examination. Five days ago, her mother noticed traces of blood on her daughter's underwear while doing the laundry. The patient has had intermittent lower abdominal discomfort for the past 4 months but feels well otherwise. There is no personal or family history of serious illness. She is at the 95^th percentile for height and at the 70^th percentile for weight. Vital signs are within normal limits. The patient appears well nourished. Physical examination shows breast buds that are elevated and extend beyond the areolae. Examination of the skin shows no abnormalities. There is no axillary or pubic hair. The external genital organs appear normal. There is no vaginal discharge. An x-ray of the left wrist shows a bone age of 9 years. Serum luteinizing hormone concentration does not increase following gonadotropin-releasing hormone agonist stimulation. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for this patient's clinical findings?
content_preview: A 7-year-old girl is brought to the physician by her parents for a well-child examination. Five days ago, her mother noticed traces of blood on her daughter's underwear while doing the laundry. The patient has had intermittent lower abdominal discomfort for the past 4 months but feels well otherwise. There is no personal or family history of serious illness. She is at the 95th percentile for height and at the 70th percentile for weight. Vital signs are within normal limits. The patient appears well nourished. Physical examination shows breast buds that are elevated and extend beyond the areolae. Examination of the skin shows no abnormalities. There is no axillary or pubic hair. The external genital organs appear normal. There is no vaginal discharge. An x-ray of the left wrist shows a bone age of 9 years. Serum luteinizing hormone concentration does not increase following gonadotropin-releasing hormone agonist stimulation. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for this patient's clinical findings?
hint: The development of secondary sexual characteristics and menarche in a girl < 8 years of age in combination with advanced bone age indicates precocious puberty. This patient's luteinizing hormone (LH) levels do not respond to gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH) agonist stimulation, which is characteristic of peripheral precocious puberty (PPP).
learning_objective: Recognize juvenile granulosa cell tumor as a cause of peripheral precocious puberty.

answers.explanation_why:
This patient's intermittent lower abdominal discomfort in combination with signs of hyperestrogenism (e.g., premature menarche, precocious breast development) indicates an estrogen-secreting ovarian tumor (e.g., granulosa cell tumor, thecoma) as the underlying cause of PPP. Although granulosa cell tumors are more common in perimenopausal patients, there is a rare juvenile type that typically manifests with PPP and a bone age greater than chronological age. Because of the high levels of estrogen produced by these tumors, LH production is suppressed and there is no LH response to GnRH agonist stimulation. Pediatric patients with estrogen-secreting tumors are usually taller than their peers, but if the condition is untreated, they often have a short stature in adulthood due to early closure of the epiphyseal plate.

Patients with granulosa cell tumors may have a palpable mass in the lower abdomen, and pelvic imaging usually shows enlarged ovaries. Inhibin A and/or Inhibin B can be used as tumor markers. Regression of symptoms is expected after tumor resection (e.g., unilateral salpingo-oophorectomy).

For girls, the normal age of onset of puberty is 8–13 years, with the average age being 11 years. This patient presents with menarche and the development of secondary sex characteristics before the age of eight, indicating precocious puberty.

McCune-Albright syndrome may cause GnRH-independent PPP and occurs more frequently in girls. However, affected patients typically also have abnormal skin pigmentation (cafe-au-lait spots with ragged edges) and unilateral, polyostotic fibrous dysplasia.

Neoplasms of the hypothalamic region, such as gliomas, can cause central precocious puberty by disrupting the normal regulation of pubertal development, leading to increased secretion of GnRH. However, patients with central precocious puberty show an increased rather than suppressed LH response to GnRH agonist stimulation, indicating activation of the hypothalamic-pituitary axis.

Congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH) leads to an excess of adrenal androgens, which are then converted to estrogen in the ovaries (aromatization). Patients with mild 21β-hydroxylase deficiency (nonclassic CAH) can present with normal isosexual external genitalia, PPP, and advanced bone age. However, pubarche and/or treatment-resistant acne due to androgen excess would also be expected. This patient has isolated findings of excess estrogen (precocious development of breast buds, menarche). In addition, CAH would not explain her intermittent lower abdominal discomfort.

Classic CAH manifests earlier in life with features of pseudohermaphroditism (e.g., clitoromegaly at birth) and signs of virilization (e.g., hirsutism), which are also not present here.

question_text: A 16-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of a 3-week history of loose stools. He has 2–3 episodes of loose stools a day that are occasionally bloody. During this period, he has also had crampy abdominal pain, generalized fatigue, and a 2-kg (5-lb) weight loss. His temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 82/min, and blood pressure is 106/68 mm Hg. Examination shows mild lower abdominal tenderness to palpation. His hemoglobin concentration is 13.1 g/dL, leukocyte count is 12,400/mm^3, and erythrocyte sedimentation rate is 14 mm/h. Test of the stool for ova and parasites is negative. A colonoscopy shows a friable and inflamed rectal mucosa that bleeds on contact with the endoscope. A biopsy confirms the diagnosis. Which of the following is the most appropriate therapy for this patient?
content_preview: A 16-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of a 3-week history of loose stools. He has 2–3 episodes of loose stools a day that are occasionally bloody. During this period, he has also had crampy abdominal pain, generalized fatigue, and a 2-kg (5-lb) weight loss. His temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 82/min, and blood pressure is 106/68 mm Hg. Examination shows mild lower abdominal tenderness to palpation. His hemoglobin concentration is 13.1 g/dL, leukocyte count is 12,400/mm3, and erythrocyte sedimentation rate is 14 mm/h. Test of the stool for ova and parasites is negative. A colonoscopy shows a friable and inflamed rectal mucosa that bleeds on contact with the endoscope. A biopsy confirms the diagnosis. Which of the following is the most appropriate therapy for this patient?
hint: Bloody diarrhea and crampy abdominal pain raise concern for ulcerative colitis (UC). Colonoscopy findings of friable and inflamed rectal mucosa that bleeds on contact support this diagnosis.
learning_objective: Choose the most appropriate therapy for mild ulcerative colitis.

answers.explanation_why: A gluten-free diet is indicated as a diagnostic and therapeutic option in patients with suspected or confirmed celiac disease (CD). Although recurrent abdominal pain, diarrhea, and fatigue are also seen in patients with CD, bloody stools and inflamed, friable rectal mucosa on colonoscopy are not features of this condition.

Proctocolectomy is an elective surgery for patients with refractory UC, medication-induced side effects, and increased risk of malignancy (e.g., those with dysplastic polyps). Emergency proctocolectomy is indicated in patients with life-threatening complications due to UC such as toxic megacolon, colonic perforation, or massive gastrointestinal hemorrhage. Since this adolescent has features of mild UC, has not yet received a trial of medical therapy, and has no symptoms of complications due to UC, a proctocolectomy is not the appropriate treatment at this time.

This patient has mild UC, the criteria for which are < 4 stools/day (that can occasionally be bloody) and no signs of systemic illness such as fever, tachycardia, hemoglobin ≤ 11.5 g/dL, and erythrocyte sedimentation rate ≥ 30 mm/h (see “Classification of ulcerative colitis by severity"). The first-line treatment for mild UC limited to the rectum and sigmoid colon is rectal 5-aminosalicylic acid derivatives (5-ASAs) such as mesalamine. Rectal 5-ASAs are more effective in inducing remission than rectal glucocorticoids, and they have fewer side effects. Patients who cannot tolerate rectal medications or who have extensive disease (i.e., extending proximal to the splenic flexure) can be treated with oral 5-ASAs.

See “Pharmacological treatment for induction of remission in ulcerative colitis” table.

Systemic glucocorticoid therapy (e.g., oral prednisone) is often used to induce remission in ambulatory patients with severely active UC, which is defined as having > 6 bloody stools/day with signs of systemic illness (e.g., fever, tachycardia, hemoglobin < 10.5 g/dL, elevated inflammatory markers). Oral glucocorticoids may also be indicated in patients with mild or moderate UC who have not responded to first-line treatment and topical glucocorticoids. As this patient has features of mild UC and has not received first-line treatment, systemic glucocorticoid therapy is not indicated at this time.

Anti-TNF-α therapy (e.g., infliximab) can be used to induce and maintain remission in patients with moderate to severe UC. This patient has mild UC (defined as having < 4 stools/day and no signs of systemic illness), for which anti-TNF-α therapy is not indicated.

Calcineurin inhibitors like cyclosporine and tacrolimus may be used as rescue therapy for patients with steroid-refractory severe UC (patients who show no improvement after a 7–10-day trial of IV glucocorticoids). Since this patient only has signs of mild UC, immunosuppressants are not the most appropriate initial treatment at this stage.

question_text: A 13-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of a 1-month history of progressive difficulty breathing through his nose and a 2-week history of recurrent severe nosebleeds. When he holds the right nostril shut, he is unable to breathe nasally and his sense of smell is reduced. He has a 6-year history of asthma, which is well controlled with inhaled albuterol. Vital signs are within normal limits. Nasal inspection shows a pink, lobulated mass filling the left nasal cavity. The septum is deviated to the right side. The mass bleeds on touch. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in diagnosis?
content_preview: A 13-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of a 1-month history of progressive difficulty breathing through his nose and a 2-week history of recurrent severe nosebleeds. When he holds the right nostril shut, he is unable to breathe nasally and his sense of smell is reduced. He has a 6-year history of asthma, which is well controlled with inhaled albuterol. Vital signs are within normal limits. Nasal inspection shows a pink, lobulated mass filling the left nasal cavity. The septum is deviated to the right side. The mass bleeds on touch. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in diagnosis?
hint: The combination of a pink nasal mass, septum deviation, nasal obstruction, and recurrent epistaxis in an adolescent boy is highly suggestive of juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma (JNA).
learning_objective: Recognize juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma, and choose the most appropriate diagnostic study.

answers.explanation_why: Coagulation tests are indicated for patients with suspected bleeding disorders, which frequently manifest with recurrent epistaxis. However, patients with bleeding disorders typically have additional features, e.g., petechiae in platelet disorders, hemarthrosis in coagulation defects. Coagulation tests are likely necessary in this patient with suspected JNA to exclude a concurrent bleeding disorder; however, another step is required to confirm his diagnosis.

A sweat chloride test is indicated in suspected cystic fibrosis (CF), which may manifest with nasal polyposis. However, CF most commonly manifests in infancy with gastrointestinal features (e.g., meconium ileus) or in early childhood with respiratory symptoms such as recurrent pneumonia or bronchitis (not asthma). Moreover, polyps in CF are usually bilateral, pale, and greyish and do not typically cause bleeding.

The NSAID challenge test is indicated in suspected NSAID-exacerbated respiratory disease, which manifests with asthma and nasal polyposis. However, this patient does not have a history of NSAID use, and recurrent rhinosinusitis would be expected, rather than epistaxis.

Punch biopsy is an important test in the workup of unilateral nasal masses to determine malignancy (e.g., nasopharyngeal carcinoma). However, biopsy is contraindicated in JNA because the tumor is highly vascular, so biopsy will cause massive bleeding. If the diagnosis is inconclusive after further evaluation, a biopsy can be considered. However, the procedure should only be performed by a specialist in an operating room where adequate airway protection and blood products can be ensured.

A foreign nasal body may cause nasal obstruction and epistaxis. However, the presence of a foreign nasal body is commonly associated with unilateral, foul-smelling, and purulent nasal discharge due to local inflammation and infection, and it is more common in very young children and individuals with developmental impairment.

answers.content: CT scan of head with contrast
answers.explanation_why: A CT scan is the preferred method to confirm the diagnosis of JNA and to assess the extent of the tumor. These rare, benign, but rapidly expanding tumors occur exclusively in boys and manifest with a mass arising from the roof of the nasopharynx on a cranial CT scan. JNAs typically show strong contrast enhancement on CT scan due to their increased vascularity, which is the cause for recurrent epistaxis. The tumors also induce pressure necrosis on adjacent structures (e.g., the orbits, the intracranial cavity). Surgical excision is the treatment of choice for symptomatic JNAs, because they are locally aggressive and have a high recurrence rate. Radiosurgery (i.e., with a stereotactic gamma knife) is reserved for recurrent JNAs and/or JNAs with intracranial extension.

question_text:
A previously healthy 2-year-old girl is brought to the physician because of a 1-week history of yellow discoloration of her skin, loss of appetite, and 3 episodes of vomiting. Her parents also report darkening of her urine and light stools. During the last 2 days, the girl has been scratching her abdomen and arms and has been crying excessively. She was born at 38 weeks' gestation after an uncomplicated pregnancy and delivery. Her family emigrated from Japan 8 years ago. Immunizations are up-to-date. Her vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows jaundice of her skin and sclerae. Abdominal examination shows a mass in the right upper abdomen. Serum studies show:

Bilirubin (total)
5 mg/dL

Direct
4.2 mg/dL

Aspartate aminotransferase (AST)
40 U/L

Alanine aminotransferase (ALT)
60 U/L

γ-Glutamyltransferase (GGT)

110 U/L (N = 5–50)

Abdominal ultrasonography shows dilation of the gallbladder and a fusiform dilation of the extrahepatic common bile duct. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
content_preview: A previously healthy 2-year-old girl is brought to the physician because of a 1-week history of yellow discoloration of her skin, loss of appetite, and 3 episodes of vomiting. Her parents also report darkening of her urine and light stools. During the last 2 days, the girl has been scratching her abdomen and arms and has been crying excessively. She was born at 38 weeks' gestation after an uncomplicated pregnancy and delivery. Her family emigrated from Japan 8 years ago. Immunizations are up-to-date. Her vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows jaundice of her skin and sclerae. Abdominal examination shows a mass in the right upper abdomen. Serum studies show: Bilirubin (total) 5 mg/dL Direct 4.2 mg/dL Aspartate aminotransferase (AST) 40 U/L Alanine aminotransferase (ALT) 60 U/L γ-Glutamyltransferase (GGT) 110 U/L (N = 5–50) Abdominal ultrasonography shows dilation of the gallbladder and a fusiform dilation of the extrahepatic common bile duct. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
hint: Conjugated hyperbilirubinemia, dark urine, acholic stools, and pruritus indicates cholestasis. The cause of cholestasis is evident from the findings of physical examination and ultrasonography.
learning_objective: Recognize a biliary cyst.

answers.explanation_why: Biliary cysts (i.e., choledochal cysts) are most commonly seen in patients of Asian descent and appear as saccular or fusiform dilations of the biliary tree or as dilated masses that communicate with the biliary tree. A biliary cyst can result in cholestatic jaundice, abdominal pain, and a palpable right upper quadrant mass and, if left untreated, increases the risk of cholangitis and malignancy (e.g., cholangiocarcinoma, pancreatic cancer, gallbladder cancer). In rare cases, a biliary cyst may involve the cystic duct and result in gallbladder dilation. The recommended treatment for a biliary cyst is surgical excision of the cyst, followed by the creation of a biliary-enteric anastomosis with a Roux-en-Y hepaticojejunostomy.

Mirizzi syndrome would result in cholestatic jaundice and dilation of the gallbladder and extrahepatic bile ducts on ultrasound. However, gallstone disease is rare in children unless risk factors such as chronic hemolytic anemia (e.g., hereditary spherocytosis) are present.

Biliary atresia would manifest with cholestatic jaundice. However, jaundice usually develops within the first few weeks of life, and dilation of the gallbladder or extrahepatic bile ducts would not be expected. Instead, ultrasound would reveal atresia of the extrahepatic bile ducts and typically a small or absent gallbladder.

Caroli disease would result in cholestatic jaundice, but the gallbladder and extrahepatic bile duct would not be dilated on ultrasound. Instead, multiple saccular dilations of the intrahepatic bile ducts could be seen.

Pancreatic pseudocysts, which develop 2–4 weeks following acute pancreatitis, can be associated with nausea, vomiting, and anorexia. A pseudocyst at the head of the pancreas can also compress the biliary tree and result in cholestatic jaundice. However, there is no history of acute pancreatitis in this toddler. Moreover, acute pancreatitis is very rare in children; it typically occurs among adults with risk factors such as alcohol use disorder and gallstone disease.

Alagille syndrome can result in cholestatic jaundice. However, this condition is not associated with a right upper quadrant mass or dilation of the gallbladder and extrahepatic bile ducts. Moreover, the onset of jaundice typically occurs before the age of 6 months, and other features, such as broad nasal bridge, triangular facies, deep-set eyes, a posterior embryotoxon, and/or murmurs of congenital heart defects, would be expected.

Type 2 Crigler-Najjar syndrome may manifest with jaundice in a 2-year-old child. However, the condition would cause unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia rather than conjugated hyperbilirubinemia, and clinical features of cholestasis (e.g., pruritus, acholic stools, dark urine) would not be expected.

question_text: A 15-year-old girl comes to the physician with her father for evaluation of her tall stature. She is concerned because she is taller than all of her friends. Her birth weight and height were within normal limits. Her father is 174 cm (5 ft 7 in) tall; her mother is 162 cm (5 ft 3 in) tall. She is at the 98^th percentile for height and 90^th percentile for BMI. She has not had her menstrual period yet. Her mother has Graves disease. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows a tall stature with broad hands and feet. There is frontal bossing and protrusion of the mandible. Finger perimetry is normal. The remainder of the examinations shows no abnormalities. Serum studies show a fasting serum glucose concentration of 144 mg/dL. An x-ray of the left hand and wrist shows a bone age of 15 years. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment for this patient's condition?
content_preview: A 15-year-old girl comes to the physician with her father for evaluation of her tall stature. She is concerned because she is taller than all of her friends. Her birth weight and height were within normal limits. Her father is 174 cm (5 ft 7 in) tall; her mother is 162 cm (5 ft 3 in) tall. She is at the 98th percentile for height and 90th percentile for BMI. She has not had her menstrual period yet. Her mother has Graves disease. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows a tall stature with broad hands and feet. There is frontal bossing and protrusion of the mandible. Finger perimetry is normal. The remainder of the examinations shows no abnormalities. Serum studies show a fasting serum glucose concentration of 144 mg/dL. An x-ray of the left hand and wrist shows a bone age of 15 years. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment for this patient's condition?
hint: Tall stature (> 97^th percentile for age and sex), broad hands and feet, prognathism (protrusion of the mandible), and frontal bossing are consistent with the diagnosis of gigantism.
learning_objective: Recognize gigantism, and choose the most appropriate treatment.

answers.explanation_why:
Growth hormone-secreting pituitary adenomas cause gigantism in children and adolescents, and acromegaly in adults. Growth hormone (GH) stimulates IGF-1 synthesis, which in turn promotes cell proliferation, especially of the bones and cartilage. Excess GH also has a diabetogenic effect, which explains the elevated serum glucose seen in this patient. The treatment of choice for both gigantism and acromegaly is transsphenoidal adenomectomy. Pharmacotherapy with somatostatin analogs (e.g., octreotide) is indicated if GH excess is not completely resolved by surgery or if surgery is not possible.

See "Etiology of tall stature" table.

Letrozole is a medication indicated to treat individuals with McCune-Albright syndrome. One of the findings associated with the condition is precocious puberty, which may lead to accelerated growth and increased height. However, since this patient shows no other features of McCune-Albright syndrome (e.g., cafe-au-lait spots, pathological fractures) and her puberty is delayed rather than precocious, this diagnosis is unlikely.

Insulin therapy is the treatment of choice for type 1 diabetes mellitus (T1DM). Although this patient presents with fasting hyperglycemia, which is a cardinal feature of diabetes mellitus, she has no other signs or symptoms of the disease, such as polyuria, polydipsia, or weight loss. Her obesity, broad hands and feet, prognathism, and frontal bossing are not consistent with T1DM. Moreover, T1DM is commonly associated with stunted growth rather than tall stature.

Methimazole is indicated for the treatment of Graves disease, a condition that may cause tall stature in adolescents and in which genetic predisposition (e.g., Graves disease in a parent) plays a strong role. Since broad hands and feet, prognathism, and frontal bossing are not features of Graves disease and further characteristic features are absent (e.g., tachycardia, diffuse goiter), this diagnosis is unlikely.

Leuprolide is a GnRH agonist indicated for the treatment of central precocious puberty. Common features of central precocious puberty include accelerated skeletal growth, early skeletal maturity, early development of secondary sexual features, and early onset of menarche. Because menarche has not yet occurred in this patient, she would be described as having delayed puberty rather than precocious puberty. Since this patient's skeletal maturity is age-appropriate and precocious puberty is unlikely to manifest with isolated accelerated growth, this diagnosis can be ruled out.

Caloric restriction is the primary measure used to manage overweight and obesity. While excess calorie intake in children may also result in greater height, this patient's broad hands and feet, prognathism, and frontal bossing should raise suspicion of a different pathology.

question_text: A 5-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of a 10-day history of intermittent fevers and painful swelling of the right ankle. He has not had trauma to the ankle. He has a history of sickle cell disease and had an episode of dactylitis of his left index finger 3 years ago. Current medications include hydroxyurea and acetaminophen as needed for ankle pain. His temperature is 38.0°C (100.4°F), pulse is 105/min, respirations are 14/min and blood pressure is 125/68 mm Hg. Examination shows a tender, swollen, and erythematous right ankle with point tenderness over the medial malleolus. X-ray of the right ankle demonstrates marked periosteal thickening and elevation, as well as a central sclerotic lesion with a lucent rim over the right medial malleolus. A bone biopsy culture confirms the diagnosis. Which of the following is the most likely causal organism?
content_preview: A 5-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of a 10-day history of intermittent fevers and painful swelling of the right ankle. He has not had trauma to the ankle. He has a history of sickle cell disease and had an episode of dactylitis of his left index finger 3 years ago. Current medications include hydroxyurea and acetaminophen as needed for ankle pain. His temperature is 38.0°C (100.4°F), pulse is 105/min, respirations are 14/min and blood pressure is 125/68 mm Hg. Examination shows a tender, swollen, and erythematous right ankle with point tenderness over the medial malleolus. X-ray of the right ankle demonstrates marked periosteal thickening and elevation, as well as a central sclerotic lesion with a lucent rim over the right medial malleolus. A bone biopsy culture confirms the diagnosis. Which of the following is the most likely causal organism?
hint: A history of fevers and bone point tenderness with an x-ray showing periosteal elevations and sclerotic changes is particularly concerning for osteomyelitis. Sickle cell disease (SCD) predisposes to infection with encapsulated bacteria because of the functional asplenia present in most patients by the age of 4.
learning_objective: Recognize osteomyelitis in sickle cell disease, and recall the common causal organism.

answers.explanation_why: Streptococcus pneumoniae, an encapsulated bacteria, is the most common cause of bacteremia, sepsis, and meningitis in patients with SCD. However, it is a less common cause of osteomyelitis.

E. coli and other gram-negative bacteria can cause osteomyelitis in neonates, children, and adults. This bacteria is frequently identified in patients with SCD that have osteomyelitis. However, another organism is more commonly found.
Group A Streptococcus is a common cause of osteomyelitis in infants and children (up to 8% of cases). However, this patient's history of SCD makes another organism more likely.

Salmonella enterica, an encapsulated bacteria, is the most likely cause of this patient's osteomyelitis. In the US and Europe, S. enterica is the most common pathogen in SCD-associated osteomyelitis due to the functional asplenia common to this population, induced by chronic splenic occlusions and infarctions.

Staphylococcus aureus is the most common cause of osteomyelitis in patients with SCD in Africa and the Middle East and accounts for the majority of acute osteomyelitis cases worldwide.

Pseudomonas aeruginosa osteomyelitis is seen most often in adult IV drug users. It is typically only identified in pediatric populations following puncture wounds to the foot, such as stepping on a nail. This patient has no history of acute trauma to his foot, making P. aeruginosa an unlikely cause.

Coccidioides immitis is the most common fungal cause of osteomyelitis in children and adults, as a complication of underlying coccidioidomycosis. However, these patients typically present with infection in multiple sites and commonly involve the vertebral bodies. Also, it is only seen in the Southwestern US, making this an unlikely choice.

question_text: A 3-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of recurrent nosebleeds and fatigue for the past 2 months. He also frequently complains his head hurts. The patient has met all motoric milestones for his age but does not like to run because his legs start to hurt if he does. He is at the 40^th percentile for both height and weight. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 125/min, respirations are 32/min, and blood pressure in the right arm is 130/85 mm Hg. A grade 2/6 systolic murmur is heard in the left paravertebral region. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following findings?
content_preview: A 3-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of recurrent nosebleeds and fatigue for the past 2 months. He also frequently complains his head hurts. The patient has met all motoric milestones for his age but does not like to run because his legs start to hurt if he does. He is at the 40th percentile for both height and weight. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 125/min, respirations are 32/min, and blood pressure in the right arm is 130/85 mm Hg. A grade 2/6 systolic murmur is heard in the left paravertebral region. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following findings?
hint: This patient's general fatigue, hypertension, low-grade systolic ejection murmur, lower-extremity claudication, headaches, and recurrent epistaxis together suggest coarctation of the aorta (CoA).
learning_objective: Recognize coarctation of the aorta, and recall its diagnostic findings.

answers.explanation_why: Notching of the ribs, an x-ray finding in patients with coarctation of the aorta, results from compensatory collateral blood flow involving the intercostal vessels. Those vessels may dilate to bypass the left ventricular outflow tract obstruction. Although this patient may eventually develop visible rib notching, it is generally a sign of chronic disease and usually does not become apparent in children before the age of 5 years.

images.title: Coarctation of the aorta
images.description: X-ray chest (PA view)Focal indentation of the distal aortic arch is seen at the location of aortic coarctation (illustration). An additional finding is inferior rib notching (Roesler sign; examples indicated by arrowheads), which is produced by dilated intercostal arteries.The figure-3 sign of coarctation (indicated by red line) is seen in this patient. It is produced by prestenotic dilatation of the aortic arch and left subclavian artery in combination with post-stenotic dilatation of the descending aorta. The presence of bilateral rib notching indicates that the coarctation is distal to the origin of both subclavian arteries.

answers.explanation_why: Interarm differences in tissue oxygenation and blood pressure can be a finding of coarctation of the aorta in the rare case that the narrowing is proximal to the left subclavian artery. In such patients, blood pressure in the right arm would be markedly higher than in the left arm and oxygen saturation would be lower in the left arm. However, coarctation of the aorta most commonly presents with differences in blood pressure between the upper and the lower extremities.

Congenital pulmonary valve stenosis is a characteristic feature of tetralogy of Fallot. A systolic ejection murmur can be present and is usually best heard at the left sternal border, rather than the left paravertebral region. Patients usually present with (mild) cyanosis and intermittent hypoxic episodes that improve with squatting, none of which are seen here. Coarctation of the aorta is characterized by an outflow obstruction of the left ventricle.

Left-axis deviation and increased R wave amplitude in V5–V6 on ECG are signs of left ventricular hypertrophy. While myocardial hypertrophy is one of the compensatory mechanisms to counter the aortic narrowing in patients with coarctation of the aorta, such as this 3-year-old boy, the changes in ECG vary with age and degree of stenosis, and it usually takes several years before the hypertrophy becomes apparent. In older children and adults, ECG may show signs of left ventricular hypertrophy in the left precordial leads (e.g., positive Sokolow-Lyon criteria).

In patients with CoA, delayed or even absent lower extremity pulses are expected distal to the stenotic portion of the aorta. Since the post-stenotic blood supply is limited, the resulting lower-extremity hypoxia becomes evident, especially during exertion, which is a strong sign of intermittent claudication, as in this patient.

Doppler echocardiography is the confirmatory test of choice and can identify the location and extent of the stenosis.

question_text: A 30-year-old man comes to the physician for evaluation of lump on his right testicle that he noticed 2 weeks ago while bathing. He has a history of bilateral cryptorchidism treated with orchidopexy at 8 months of age. Physical examination shows a firm, nontender nodule on the right testis that does not transilluminate. His serum alpha-fetoprotein, placental alkaline phosphatase, and beta-human chorionic gonadotropin concentration are all within the reference range. This patient's testicular tumor is most likely of which of the following types?
content_preview: A 30-year-old man comes to the physician for evaluation of lump on his right testicle that he noticed 2 weeks ago while bathing. He has a history of bilateral cryptorchidism treated with orchidopexy at 8 months of age. Physical examination shows a firm, nontender nodule on the right testis that does not transilluminate. His serum alpha-fetoprotein, placental alkaline phosphatase, and beta-human chorionic gonadotropin concentration are all within the reference range. This patient's testicular tumor is most likely of which of the following types?
hint: Men with a history of cryptorchidism are at increased risk for testicular germ cell tumors, even after cryptorchidism has been surgically repaired.
learning_objective: Recognize teratoma in a patient with a history of cryptorchidism.

answers.explanation_why:
Testicular germ cell tumors are divided into two groups: seminomas (most common) and nonseminoma tumors. Nonseminoma tumors include embryonal carcinomas, yolk sac tumors, testicular choriocarcinomas, teratomas, and tumors with mixed germ cell histology. Pure teratomas typically do not cause an elevation in testicular tumor markers (beta-hCG, AFP, PLAP), which is consistent with this patient's laboratory studies. Teratomas are more common in children but are usually benign in this patient group. In adult males, they are rare but more often malignant.

Unlike hydroceles, testicular tumors do not transilluminate on examination. Typically, testicular tumors should not be percutaneously biopsied because a biopsy can cause seeding of malignant cells in the scrotum.
Cryptorchidism is not a risk factor for non-germ cell tumors such as Sertoli cell tumors. Moreover, Sertoli cell tumors are very rare, accounting for < 1% of all testicular cancers in adults.

Cryptorchidism is not a risk factor for non-germ cell tumors such as Leydig cell tumors. Moreover, Leydig cell tumors are very rare, accounting for only approx. 2% of all testicular cancers in adults.

Yolk sac tumors are nonseminomatous germ cell tumors. While this patient's history of bilateral cryptorchidism puts him at increased risk of developing germ cell tumors, he is unlikely to develop a yolk sac tumor because it most commonly manifests before puberty. Moreover, yolk sac tumors are associated with an increased level of AFP, which is normal in this patient.

Testicular lymphoma is the most common testicular tumor in men > 60 years of age. It usually arises when non-Hodgkin lymphoma metastasizes to the testicles. This 30-year-old man is unlikely to have a testicular lymphoma, and cryptorchidism is not a risk factor for testicular lymphoma.

question_text: A 2-year-old boy with a history of recurrent respiratory infections is brought to the physician for a follow-up examination. His height and weight are both at the 20^th percentile. Crackles are heard in both lower lung fields. Cardiac auscultation shows a grade 3/6 holosystolic murmur over the left lower sternal border and a diastolic rumble heard best at the apex. If left untreated, this patient is most likely to develop which of the following?
content_preview: A 2-year-old boy with a history of recurrent respiratory infections is brought to the physician for a follow-up examination. His height and weight are both at the 20th percentile. Crackles are heard in both lower lung fields. Cardiac auscultation shows a grade 3/6 holosystolic murmur over the left lower sternal border and a diastolic rumble heard best at the apex. If left untreated, this patient is most likely to develop which of the following?
hint: The presence of a holosystolic murmur (indicating flow through the defect) and a diastolic rumble (increased flow through the mitral valve during diastole) suggests a ventricular septal defect (VSD), the most common type of congenital heart defect. VSDs are associated with frequent respiratory infections secondary to congestion of the pulmonary vessels.
learning_objective: Recognize ventricular septal defect (VSD), and recall its long-term complications.

answers.explanation_why: Congenital heart defects associated with an increased risk of myocardial ischemia are typically those that involve coronary artery abnormalities (e.g., anomalous course or origin, involving fistulas) or result in decreased coronary perfusion (e.g., in a large PDA, the retrograde blood flow to the left ventricle can decrease diastolic pressure in the proximal aorta and thereby decrease coronary perfusion). Although a long-standing, uncorrected VSD can also lead to decreased blood pressure, there is no evidence that it increases the risk of myocardial ischemia.

Acyanotic heart defects, such as VSDs, are not a known cause of increased platelet counts. A long-standing, uncorrected VSD will eventually result in Eisenmenger syndrome with subsequent shunt reversal. In this case, thrombocytopenia, not thrombocytosis may occur. Thrombocytopenia due to Eisenmenger syndrome is thought to result from megakaryocytes bypassing the pulmonary vasculature where they would normally be fragmented into platelets.

Secondary hypertension can result from congenital heart defects such as coarctation of the aorta. All aortic branches proximal to the coarctation receive increased blood flow, ultimately resulting in intimal-medial thickening and increased vascular stiffness. In a 2-year-old child, symptomatic coarctation would most likely present with chest pain, cold feet, and lower-extremity claudication on physical exertion, none of which are seen in this patient. Furthermore, auscultation would reveal a systolic ejection murmur over the left paravertebral region and/or a continuous murmur below the left clavicula and between the shoulder blades.

Aortic dissection is a dangerous complication of untreated coarctation of the aorta in adults. Chronic hypertension proximal to the area of coarctation increases intraluminal pressure and subsequently weakens the arterial wall, potentially resulting in aortic dissection. Symptomatic coarctation in a 2-year-old child would most likely present with chest pain, cold feet, and lower-extremity claudication on physical exertion, none of which are seen in this patient. Furthermore, auscultation would reveal a systolic ejection murmur over the left paravertebral region and/or a continuous murmur below the left clavicula and between the shoulder blades.

Digital clubbing is a sign of chronic hypoxemia, which is a complication of an untreated VSD. VSDs are acyanotic congenital heart defects that manifest as a left-to-right shunt. An untreated VSD can lead to chronic volume overload of the right ventricle (RV) and subsequently increased blood flow through the pulmonary vasculature. This increased flow causes irreversible remodeling of the small pulmonary vessels, leading to increased pulmonary vascular resistance and RV hypertrophy. RV pressure increases until it exceeds left ventricular (LV) pressure, at which point the shunt is reversed. This shunt reversal is known as Eisenmenger syndrome. Cyanosis and consequently, chronic tissue hypoxia, leads to the development of digital clubbing.

Chronic tissue hypoxia and megakaryocyte fragmentation are primary factors involved in the pathogenesis of digital clubbing. In Eisenmenger syndrome, blood can completely bypass the pulmonary vasculature, allowing whole megakaryocytes into the systemic circulation. Once these intact cells reach distal capillaries in the hands and feet, they impact and subsequently fragment. This fragmentation causes the release of platelet-derived growth factor and vascular endothelial growth factor, inducing angiogenesis and local mesenchymal growth and proliferation, which clinically manifests as digital clubbing.

images.title: Nail clubbing
images.description: There is enlargement of the distal phalanges, and the nail curvatures are increased.

answers.explanation_why: Chronic kidney disease (CKD) can result from a variety of conditions, including advanced left heart failure. In individuals with low cardiac output, advanced left heart failure may lead to decreased renal perfusion, decreased venous congestion, and eventually CKD. Chronic, untreated VSD, which is seen in this patient, causes constant volume overload of the right ventricle (RV) and subsequent RV damage. Advanced stages of RV failure manifest with hepatomegaly and peripheral edema.

question_text: A 4-year-old girl is brought to the physician for a painless lump on her neck. She has no history of serious illness and her vital signs are within normal limits. On examination, there is a firm, 2-cm swelling at the midline just below the level of the hyoid bone. The mass moves cranially when she is asked to protrude her tongue. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
content_preview: A 4-year-old girl is brought to the physician for a painless lump on her neck. She has no history of serious illness and her vital signs are within normal limits. On examination, there is a firm, 2-cm swelling at the midline just below the level of the hyoid bone. The mass moves cranially when she is asked to protrude her tongue. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
hint: This mass will also move cranially with swallowing.
learning_objective: Recognize a thyroglossal cyst.

answers.explanation_why: A thyroglossal cyst arises if the thyroglossal duct fails to obliterate completely during embryonal development. The cyst can develop anywhere along the path of the thyroglossal duct and manifests as a painless, firm, midline mass of the anterior neck. Like the thyroid gland, the thyroglossal cyst is enclosed within the pretracheal fascia, which is responsible for the upward movement of these structures during swallowing. In addition, a thyroglossal cyst moves upward with tongue protrusion because the fibrous remnants of the thyroglossal duct are connected to the base of the tongue.

A ranula is a mucocele arising from the sublingual gland that manifests as a translucent, dome-shaped, blue mass below the tongue. Although large lesions can cause swelling of the neck, this would occur lateral to the midline and would not move upwards with tongue protrusion or swallowing.

Laryngocele, a saccular dilatation of the laryngeal ventricle, can herniate through the thyrohyoid membrane and appear as a lateral neck swelling. The neck mass is typically a small, air-filled sac that increases in size with Valsalva maneuver.

A cystic hygroma is a congenital malformation of the lymphatic system in the neck. The neck mass is typically painless, soft, and compressible, and is located in the posterior triangle of the neck. Cystic hygroma is associated with fetal aneuploidy (e.g., Turner syndrome).

images.title: Cystic hygroma
images.description: Right lateral region of the neck(1) A massive, lobulated swelling (green overlay) is visible in the posterior triangle. This is the most common location of a cystic hygroma.(2) Patient after surgical excision of the hygroma (posterior triangle: blue overlay)

answers.explanation_why: Dermoid cysts are cystic teratomas that can arise anywhere in the body, including the neck. As a neck mass, they usually manifest at 10–20 years of age as a slow-growing mass in the submandibular or sublingual space.

Branchial cysts can arise if the 2^nd branchial cleft fails to obliterate completely. These neck masses are typically painless and firm, as in this patient, but located lateral to the midline and anterior to the sternocleidomastoid muscle. They do not move with protrusion of the tongue or swallowing.

question_text: One day after a 4700-g (10-lb 6-oz) male newborn is delivered to a 28-year-old primigravid woman, he has bluish discoloration of his lips and fingernails. Oxygen saturation on room air is 81%. Examination shows central cyanosis. A continuous machine-like murmur is heard over the left upper sternal border. A single S2 heart sound is present. Supplemental oxygen does not improve cyanosis. Echocardiography shows the pulmonary artery arising from the posterior left ventricle and aorta arising from the right ventricle with active blood flow between the right and left ventricles. Further evaluation of the mother is most likely to show which of the following?
content_preview: One day after a 4700-g (10-lb 6-oz) male newborn is delivered to a 28-year-old primigravid woman, he has bluish discoloration of his lips and fingernails. Oxygen saturation on room air is 81%. Examination shows central cyanosis. A continuous machine-like murmur is heard over the left upper sternal border. A single S2 heart sound is present. Supplemental oxygen does not improve cyanosis. Echocardiography shows the pulmonary artery arising from the posterior left ventricle and aorta arising from the right ventricle with active blood flow between the right and left ventricles. Further evaluation of the mother is most likely to show which of the following?
hint: Echocardiography showing a pulmonary artery arising from the left ventricle and aorta arising from the right ventricle confirms the diagnosis of transposition of the great arteries (TGA) which is an important cause of neonatal cyanosis that will not improve with supplemental oxygen. The continuous machine-like murmur indicates a coexistent patent ductus arteriosus, which is critical for life, as it allows mixing of oxygenated blood and its entry into the systemic circulation. Patients may also have coexistent arterial or ventricular septal defects that allow mixing of blood between the two circuits.
learning_objective: Recognize transposition of the great arteries, and recall the maternal condition associated with its development.

answers.explanation_why: Prenatal lithium intake is associated with Ebstein anomaly, which can have a wide range of clinical presentations, including congenital cyanosis from right-to-left shunting. Depending on the severity of the anomaly, the patient may have a holosystolic murmur (due to tricuspid regurgitation), as heard in this patient. However, echocardiography would show right-sided cardiomegaly with apical displacement of the tricuspid valve and tricuspid regurgitation, not the TGA seen in this patient.
Elevated serum TSH levels suggest hypothyroidism. Subclinical maternal hypothyroidism may increase the risk for future cognitive impairment, but it is not associated with TGA.

Prenatal alcohol consumption can cause fetal alcohol spectrum disorder. FASD can present with a wide range of cardiac abnormalities, including atrial septal defect, VSD, and great heart vessel defects. However, structural heart defects would also usually present with other more characteristic FASD findings, such as facial abnormalities (short palpebral fissures, thin vermillion border, smooth philtrum) and growth retardation.

Prenatal phenytoin intake is associated with fetal hydantoin syndrome. Although cases of congenital heart defects have been reported with maternal phenytoin use, transposition of the great arteries is rare. Furthermore, fetal hydantoin syndrome also presents with nail hypoplasia, hypoplasia of the digits, and abnormal facial features, which are all absent in this patient.

A positive rapid plasma reagin test suggests maternal syphilis, which can infect the infant in utero. Most cases of early congenital syphilis are asymptomatic at birth and do not develop symptoms until 5 weeks of life. If symptomatic at birth, findings include hepatosplenomegaly, jaundice, nasal discharge, generalized lymphadenopathy, skeletal abnormalities, and/or and pemphigus syphiliticus, none of which are present in this infant. Transposition of the great arteries is not associated with congenital syphilis.

TGA is a cyanotic heart condition that is associated with maternal diabetes, caused by abnormal rotation of the pulmonary artery and aorta during fetal development. Mothers with untreated diabetes will have elevated fasting blood glucose levels. Other potential neonatal complications from maternal diabetes include fetal macrosomia (seen in this patient), polycythemia, hypoglycemia, hypocalcemia, and neonatal respiratory distress syndrome.

images.title: Transposition of the great vessels (TGV)
images.description: TGV is a cyanotic congenital heart disease in which the pulmonary artery arises from the left ventricle and the aorta from the right ventricle, resulting in the formation of parallel circulatory systems. The left ventricle pumps oxygenated blood into the pulmonary circulation (red) and the right ventricle pumps deoxygenated blood into the aorta (blue), resulting in cyanosis.TGV is fatal unless a shunt between the two circulations is present (i.e., a patent ductus arteriosus or a patent foramen ovale) or a surgical intervention is performed in the neonatal period.
