question_text: A 2-year-old boy is brought to the office by his mother for a well-child examination. His mother is concerned because she cannot retract the foreskin of his penis while bathing him. He was born at term and has been healthy since. Pregnancy and delivery were uncomplicated. He has no family history of serious illness. He is physically active and can use 2-word sentences. His mother says that he likes doll play with his 6-year-old sister. His diet consists of solid foods and cow milk. His immunizations are up-to-date. He appears well. He is at the 70^th percentile for height and 60^th percentile for weight. Vital signs are within normal limits. On genital examination, his penis is of age-appropriate size and the foreskin is not retractable; both testes are palpable. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 2-year-old boy is brought to the office by his mother for a well-child examination. His mother is concerned because she cannot retract the foreskin of his penis while bathing him. He was born at term and has been healthy since. Pregnancy and delivery were uncomplicated. He has no family history of serious illness. He is physically active and can use 2-word sentences. His mother says that he likes doll play with his 6-year-old sister. His diet consists of solid foods and cow milk. His immunizations are up-to-date. He appears well. He is at the 70th percentile for height and 60th percentile for weight. Vital signs are within normal limits. On genital examination, his penis is of age-appropriate size and the foreskin is not retractable; both testes are palpable. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: A nonretractable foreskin in an otherwise healthy 2-year-old boy indicates full, physiologic phimosis.
learning_objective: Recognize physiologic phimosis in a child, and choose the most appropriate management.

answers.explanation_why: Surgical treatment, such as circumcision or vertical incision, is recommended in patients with phimosis who have not responded to conservative treatment. In boys aged < 5 years with physiologic phimosis, different management should be considered initially.

Topical bacitracin can be used in the treatment of balanitis or balanoposthitis, which can result in the development of secondary phimosis. This patient, however, has no signs of balanitis or balanoposthitis, such as pain, itching and irritation, or dysuria. His phimosis is most likely physiologic and requires different management.

Dorsal slit reduction can be used in patients with paraphimosis, which is characterized by an inability to return the retracted foreskin to its original position over the glans. This patient presents with nonretractable foreskin, which, in a young boy, suggests physiologic phimosis and requires different management.

answers.content: Perform forcible retraction of the foreskin
answers.explanation_why: Forcible foreskin retraction is contraindicated in patients with physiologic phimosis because it is painful, traumatic, and can lead to fibrosis, which is a risk factor for the development of pathologic phimosis.

Full phimosis in the absence of preputial scarring, infection, or inflammation, is considered physiologic in boys aged < 5 years and usually resolves spontaneously. Conservative measures such as gentle stretching exercises (to avoid trauma and consequent fibrosis) and topical corticosteroids can be considered to accelerate foreskin retractability. Patients and their parents should also be counseled on the importance of preputial hygiene for the prevention of infection. Surgery (i.e., circumcision or vertical incision) should be considered in patients who do not respond to conservative therapy.

Pathologic phimosis can result from trauma (e.g., forcible retraction of the foreskin in patients with physiologic phimosis) or infection (i.e., balanitis, balanoposthitis). In patients with pathologic phimosis, topical corticosteroids and gentle stretching exercises are also considered first-line treatment, and surgery should be considered for those who do not respond to conservative management.

question_text: A 3-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department by her mother because of fussiness and refusal to eat since this morning due to pain in her throat. Her mother reports that she has had a low-grade fever and mild cough for the past week. She has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. Her immunizations are up-to-date. Family history is remarkable for type 1 diabetes mellitus in the mother. The patient appears ill but is not in acute distress. Her temperature is 39.4°C (102.9°F), pulse is 131/min, respirations are 30/min, and blood pressure is 90/54 mm Hg. The patient cries when her neck is extended during the oropharyngeal examination. There is erythema of the tonsils and swelling of the posterior pharyngeal wall; the uvula is at the midline. Cervical lymph nodes are enlarged and mildly tender to palpation. A lateral x-ray of the neck is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
content_preview: A 3-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department by her mother because of fussiness and refusal to eat since this morning due to pain in her throat. Her mother reports that she has had a low-grade fever and mild cough for the past week. She has no history of serious illness and takes no medications. Her immunizations are up-to-date. Family history is remarkable for type 1 diabetes mellitus in the mother. The patient appears ill but is not in acute distress. Her temperature is 39.4°C (102.9°F), pulse is 131/min, respirations are 30/min, and blood pressure is 90/54 mm Hg. The patient cries when her neck is extended during the oropharyngeal examination. There is erythema of the tonsils and swelling of the posterior pharyngeal wall; the uvula is at the midline. Cervical lymph nodes are enlarged and mildly tender to palpation. A lateral x-ray of the neck is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
hint: The lateral neck x-ray shows widening of the space between the pharynx and the vertebral fascia.
learning_objective: Recognize a retropharyngeal abscess.

answers.explanation_why: Croup typically affects young children (6 months to 3 years of age) and can manifest with a prodromal phase of low-grade fever and rhinitis. However, affected individuals typically present with a seal-like barking cough, hoarseness, and inspiratory stridor. Furthermore, a lateral neck x-ray typically shows subglottic narrowing (steeple sign) instead of prevertebral soft tissue swelling.

images.title: Steeple sign
images.description: X-ray neck of a young child (AP view)The upper tracheal air column, which normally appears with a square-shouldered configuration, has assumed a conical shape (green overlay) reminiscent of a church steeple (steeple sign; cf. illustration).The steeple sign indicates subglottic airway narrowing and is most commonly seen in croup. However, it may also appear in other conditions (e.g., bacterial tracheitis, tumors). An accompanying lateral radiograph might additionally show inspiratory overdistention of the hypopharynx.

answers.explanation_why: Peritonsillar abscess is the most common deep neck infection in children and can also manifest with fever, throat pain, lethargy, cervical lymphadenopathy, and tonsillar erythema and swelling. However, the oropharyngeal exam typically shows a deviation of the uvula to the contralateral side due to tonsillar swelling. Prevertebral soft tissue swelling on x-ray would not be expected.

Diphtheria is caused by Corynebacterium diphtheriae infection and can manifest with fever, malaise, throat pain, pharyngeal erythema, and cervical lymphadenopathy. However, the hallmark of diphtheria is the presence of a gray-white pseudomembrane over the tonsils, posterior pharyngeal wall, and/or larynx. In addition, diphtheria is uncommon in vaccinated individuals, given that the DTaP vaccine is included in the standard immunization schedule for children < 7 years of age.

A retropharyngeal abscess (RPA) is a rare life-threatening polymicrobial infection (e.g., Staphylococcus spp., Streptococcus spp.) that typically affects young children (< 5 years of age). RPA is usually preceded by an upper respiratory tract infection and develops as a result of bacterial spread to the prevertebral space via lymphatics. In suspected cases with no signs of respiratory compromise, diagnosis is confirmed with contrast-enhanced CT scan. A lateral neck x-ray showing widening of the prevertebral space due to soft tissue swelling also supports the diagnosis.

Patients with RPA require hospital admission and empiric antibiotics that treat anaerobic bacteria (e.g., ampicillin-sulbactam, clindamycin). Patients with airway compromise (e.g., drooling, stridor, accessory muscle breathing, hypoxia) need to have their airways secured and immediate surgical drainage is indicated. Immediate abscess drainage is also required for patients with a large mass (> 2.5 cm) and/or symptoms that persist despite antibiotic therapy.

Epiglottitis typically develops as a result of Haemophilus influenzae type b (Hib) infection and can manifest in young children with fever, fussiness, and refusal to eat. However, patients with epiglottitis typically have a toxic appearance, with drooling and muffled voice due to inflammation and swelling of the epiglottis and surrounding supraglottic structures. Moreover, epiglottitis is uncommon in vaccinated individuals because the Hib vaccine is included in the standard immunization schedule for children < 15 months of age. Finally, a lateral neck x-ray typically shows a swollen epiglottis (thumbprint sign), rather than soft tissue swelling.

images.title: Deep neck infection
images.description: X-ray neck (lateral view) of a patient with a retropharyngeal abscessRetropharyngeal soft tissue swelling has produced widening (indicated by left-right arrows) of the prevertebral soft tissues.

question_text: An 11-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his parents because of a 2-month history of progressive swelling of his right upper arm. He has otherwise been healthy. Medical history is unremarkable and he takes no medications. Immunizations are up-to-date. He appears well-nourished and well-developed. He is at the 60^th percentile for height and weight. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows an immobile mass on the right proximal humerus that is nontender to palpation. Erythrocyte sedimentation rate is 10 mm/h and alkaline phosphatase is 35 U/L. An x-ray shows a 3-cm sessile bony protrusion with a cartilage cap on the proximal metaphysis of the right humerus. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
content_preview: An 11-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his parents because of a 2-month history of progressive swelling of his right upper arm. He has otherwise been healthy. Medical history is unremarkable and he takes no medications. Immunizations are up-to-date. He appears well-nourished and well-developed. He is at the 60th percentile for height and weight. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows an immobile mass on the right proximal humerus that is nontender to palpation. Erythrocyte sedimentation rate is 10 mm/h and alkaline phosphatase is 35 U/L. An x-ray shows a 3-cm sessile bony protrusion with a cartilage cap on the proximal metaphysis of the right humerus. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
hint: In an otherwise healthy patient with normal ESR and alkaline phosphatase levels, a painless bone mass indicates a benign bone tumor.
learning_objective: Recognize an osteochondroma.

answers.explanation_why: Chondrosarcoma can develop in male individuals and may involve the proximal metaphysis of the humerus. However, chondrosarcomas most commonly develop in individuals > 50 years of age and manifest with progressive pain that worsens at night, tender swelling of the affected area with erythema, pathologic fractures, and elevated inflammatory markers. Moreover, x-ray usually shows a lytic lesion with a “moth-eaten” appearance, intralesional calcifications, and endosteal scalloping.

images.title: Mixed density tumor left hemipelvis
images.description:
X-ray hips (AP view) of a patient with left hip pain, swelling, gait instability, and restriction of movementA mixed lytic (example indicated by blue overlay) and sclerotic (examples indicated by yellow overlay) lesion in the left hemipelvis is accompanied by a large soft tissue component (ST). Indistinct margins and areas of cortical destruction (arrowhead) suggest an aggressive lesion.Further evaluation confirmed the diagnosis of chondrosarcoma.

White dashed line: lesion margin

answers.explanation_why: Osteoid osteoma can develop in male individuals 4–25 years of age and may involve the proximal metaphysis of the humerus. However, affected individuals typically present with dull, constant pain that worsens at night. Moreover, x-ray most commonly shows a bony mass with a radiolucent core surrounded by perifocal sclerosis, rather than a sessile bony protrusion with a cartilage cap.

images.title: Osteoid osteoma
images.description: X-ray right hip (AP view) of a 12-year-old boyA small lucent nidus (hatched green overlay) in the medial proximal femur is accompanied by reactive sclerosis and cortical thickening (green overlay).The appearance is compatible with osteoid osteoma, although other conditions (e.g., intracortical abscess, stress fracture, osteoblastoma) can mimic osteoid osteoma and must be distinguished on the basis of the clinical presentation and additional imaging.

answers.explanation_why: Ewing sarcoma can develop in male individuals 10–20 years of age and may involve the humerus. However, the diaphysis is usually affected, not the metaphysis. In addition, affected individuals typically present with progressive localized pain that worsens at night, tender swelling of the affected area with erythema, B symptoms, and elevated inflammatory markers, none of which are seen here. Lastly, x-ray typically shows lytic bone lesions and periosteum with an “onion skin” appearance.

images.title: Permeative bone lesion
images.description:
X-ray knee and lower leg (lateral view) of a child with Ewing sarcomaA lytic permeative lesion (green overlay) in the proximal tibial diaphysis has a wide zone of transition. It is accompanied by lamellated periosteal reaction that results in an onion skin appearance (red overlay).

Illustration: comparison of radiographic patterns of bone destruction

answers.explanation_why: Osteosarcoma can develop in male individuals 10–30 years of age and may involve the proximal metaphysis of the humerus. However, affected individuals typically present with localized, progressive pain that worsens at night, tender swelling of the affected area with erythema, B symptoms, and elevated inflammatory markers, none of which is seen here. Lastly, x-ray usually shows a mixed osteolytic and osteosclerotic lesion with an aggressive periosteal reaction (sunburst appearance or Codman triangle).

images.title: Osteosarcoma
images.description: X-ray of the right femorotibial joint (AP view) of a 17-year-old male patientA sclerotic outgrowth of the bone (green overlay) surrounded by osteolytic destruction of medullary and cortical bone (red overlay) is visible on the medial metaphysis of the femur.The periosteum over the lesion is noncontinuous (dashed line), indicating rapid growth of the bone lesion.This appearance of a mixed osteosclerotic and osteolytic lesion in the metaphyses of long bones is characteristic of osteosarcoma.

answers.explanation_why:
Osteochondroma, which develops in the metaphysis of long bones (e.g., proximal humerus, distal femur), is the most common benign bone tumor. Osteochondromas have a peak incidence between 10 and 30 years of age and most commonly affect male individuals. While most affected individuals present with a painless palpable mass near a joint, they can also develop localized pain, limited range of motion, bone deformities, and pathologic fractures. Characteristic radiographic findings include a pedunculated or sessile bony protrusion with a cartilage cap.

Solitary osteochondromas, as seen here, have a very low chance of malignant transformation (approx. 1%) and usually require no further treatment. Regular monitoring may be indicated in patients with multiple osteochondromas, which have a higher chance of malignant transformation (approx. 5%). Surgical removal may be considered in patients who are symptomatic, develop pathologic fractures, or have growing tumors.

images.title: Osteochondroma of the humerus
images.description:
X-ray of the right upper armPatchy, calcified, mushroom-shaped exostosis on the surface of the humerus.
Displacement of the adjacent soft tissue (arrows) without infiltration (sharp demarcation).

answers.explanation_why: Chondroblastoma can develop in male individuals 10–20 years of age and may involve the proximal humerus. However, the epiphysis is usually affected, not the metaphysis, and affected individuals typically present with constant joint pain and swelling. Moreover, x-ray usually shows a well-defined osteolytic lesion with a sclerotic rim.

images.title: Chondroblastoma
images.description: X-ray of the right talocrural joint (a. AP view; b. lateral view)An oval osteolytic lesion is visible in the posterolateral part of the distal tibial epiphysis.This is the typical appearance of chondroblastoma.

question_text: A 12-month-old girl is brought to the physician because of insufficient weight gain and worsening constipation for the past 2 months. The father reports that since birth she has had infrequent bowel movements, but currently only has one bowel movement every 14 days and passes small, narrow stools. Treatment with prune juice has been unsuccessful. The girl was born at term by home birth; pregnancy was uncomplicated and the mother received adequate prenatal care. The girl did not undergo newborn screening. The father does not remember when she passed her first stool after birth. Until the introduction of solids at the age of 6 months, she had been exclusively breastfed. Now she eats three solid meals of a balanced diet and nurses twice daily. Her mother has celiac disease. The patient is at the 3^rd percentile for weight and the 10^th percentile for length. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows a distended abdomen. Bowel sounds are hypoactive. Digital rectal examination shows an empty ampulla. The remainder of the examination is unremarkable. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 12-month-old girl is brought to the physician because of insufficient weight gain and worsening constipation for the past 2 months. The father reports that since birth she has had infrequent bowel movements, but currently only has one bowel movement every 14 days and passes small, narrow stools. Treatment with prune juice has been unsuccessful. The girl was born at term by home birth; pregnancy was uncomplicated and the mother received adequate prenatal care. The girl did not undergo newborn screening. The father does not remember when she passed her first stool after birth. Until the introduction of solids at the age of 6 months, she had been exclusively breastfed. Now she eats three solid meals of a balanced diet and nurses twice daily. Her mother has celiac disease. The patient is at the 3rd percentile for weight and the 10th percentile for length. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows a distended abdomen. Bowel sounds are hypoactive. Digital rectal examination shows an empty ampulla. The remainder of the examination is unremarkable. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: Patients with this condition frequently present with delayed passage of meconium at birth.
learning_objective: Recognize Hirschsprung disease, and choose the most appropriate diagnostic test.

answers.explanation_why: Anorectal manometry is a useful screening test in children > 1 month of age with suspected Hirschsprung disease (HD). While most cases of HD manifest in the neonatal period with symptoms of distal intestinal obstruction (e.g., delayed passage of meconium, bilious vomiting), patients with mild disease (e.g., ultrashort-segment HD) may present later in childhood with growth faltering, chronic constipation with the passage of small diameter stools, and an empty ampulla on digital rectal examination. In a patient with HD, anorectal manometry shows an absent relaxation reflex of the internal anal sphincter after stretching of the rectum. The diagnosis is confirmed by a rectal biopsy that shows aganglionosis, increased acetylcholinesterase activity, and/or hyperplasia of parasympathetic fibers. Infants with HD usually require surgical correction (i.e., removal of the affected segment of the colon and attachment of the normal ganglionic intestinal ends). Those with mild disease may be treated conservatively with diet, stool softeners, and laxatives.

images.title: Etiopathogenesis of Hirschsprung disease
images.description: The affected colon (right) is missing both the Meissner and Auerbach nerve plexus.

answers.explanation_why: Pharmacotherapy with laxatives (e.g., lactulose) is used in infants with functional constipation who do not respond to nonpharmacologic measures such as prune juice. Functional constipation is the most common cause of constipation in infancy and childhood and may occur after the introduction of solids into the diet. However, infants with this condition typically have large stools rather than small, narrow stools, and rectal examination often shows a fecal mass in the rectal ampulla. Moreover, this patient has alarming signs (e.g., early onset of constipation, growth faltering, empty ampulla on rectal examination), which require further evaluation before initiating therapy.

Quantitative pilocarpine iontophoresis is the gold standard test for diagnosing cystic fibrosis (CF), which can manifest with constipation and growth faltering. This patient did not undergo newborn screening, which includes screening for CF, so an early diagnosis of this condition might have been missed. However, she has no other signs or symptoms suggestive of cystic fibrosis (e.g., persistent pulmonary infections, pancreatic insufficiency). Moreover, her history of small, narrow stools and rectal examination findings suggest a different diagnosis, for which another step in management is indicated.

A gluten-free diet is indicated for children with celiac disease, which can manifest with constipation and growth faltering in a 12-month-old child. The mother's history of celiac disease puts the patient at high risk for developing the condition. However, the history of small, narrow stools and rectal examination findings suggest a different diagnosis, for which another step in management is indicated.

Thyroid function tests are used to evaluate for acquired or congenital hypothyroidism, which can manifest with growth faltering and constipation. This patient did not undergo newborn screening, which includes the measurement of TSH levels, so an early diagnosis of congenital hypothyroidism may have been missed. However, during the first year of life, patients with congenital hypothyroidism typically also develop features such as lethargy, hoarse cry, puffed face, macroglossia, umbilical hernia, and hypotonia. Moreover, the passage of small, narrow stools and an empty ampulla on rectal examination is not associated with hypothyroidism.

question_text: A 10-month-old boy is brought to the physician by his mother because of a 1-week history of a painless bulge in the right groin. His mother says that the bulge is only intermittently visible and increases in size with coughing. He was born via cesarean delivery at 32 weeks' gestation because of premature rupture of membranes. He has no history of serious illness and receives no medications. He appears well. Growth and development are appropriate for age. He is at the 50^th percentile for length and weight. Temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 130/min, and respirations are 40/min. Physical examination shows a 2 x 2-cm nontender right inguinal mass that is manually reducible with gradual pressure. Ultrasonography of the groin in supine position shows widening of the deep inguinal ring. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

His mother says that the bulge is only intermittently visible and increases in size with coughing. He was born via cesarean delivery at 32 weeks' gestation because of premature rupture of membranes. He has no history of serious illness and receives no medications. He appears well. Growth and development are appropriate for age. He is at the 50th percentile for length and weight. Temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 130/min, and respirations are 40/min. Physical examination shows a 2 x 2-cm nontender right inguinal mass that is manually reducible with gradual pressure. Ultrasonography of the groin in supine position shows widening of the deep inguinal ring. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: An intermittent inguinal mass that increases in size with raised intraabdominal pressure is characteristic of an indirect inguinal hernia.
learning_objective: Recognize indirect inguinal hernia in a child, and choose the most appropriate referral.

answers.explanation_why: Immediate surgery is indicated in patients with strangulated hernia or incarcerated hernia that cannot be reduced manually. Children with incarcerated hernias usually appear ill and may present with signs of mechanical bowel obstruction (e.g., pain, nausea, vomiting). This patient has an uncomplicated inguinal hernia that is manually reducible and does not require immediate surgical repair.

Manual reduction can be a temporizing measure before definitive surgical repair of incarcerated inguinal hernias. While parental training on indications for obtaining medical care plays an essential role in the management of inguinal hernias in children, manual reduction should always be performed by a physician in a clinical setting! This procedure is contraindicated in patients with evidence of strangulation (e.g., erythema, warmth, or tenderness over the hernia) and extremely ill patients. Asymptomatic hernias, like the one seen here, do not require manual reduction.

Surgical repair is indicated in all children with inguinal hernia. In asymptomatic patients, timely surgery should be performed to avoid complications (e.g., incarcerated hernia). Emergency surgery is not required, but referral should be obtained promptly. While waiting for elective surgery, parental training on signs and symptoms of incarceration is important because an incarcerated or strangulated hernia requires immediate action.

Indirect inguinal hernias are most common among male infants and infants who are born prematurely, as they mostly result from incomplete obliteration of the processus vaginalis during fetal development. Some hernias, despite being present since birth, do not become symptomatic until adulthood.

answers.content: MRI of the abdomen and pelvis
answers.explanation_why: MRI of the abdomen and pelvis is indicated in patients with suspected inguinal hernia if ultrasonography findings are inconclusive. In this patient with characteristic findings (i.e., a nontender inguinal mass that increases in size with coughing and is manually reducible), a clinical diagnosis can be established, and additional imaging is therefore not needed.

Reassurance and follow-up are indicated in patients with communicating hydroceles, which may manifest with painless swelling, an increase in size with raised intraabdominal pressure, or manual reducibility. Hydroceles are typically located in the scrotum, and ultrasonography shows hypoechoic fluid. Reassurance and follow-up alone are not appropriate for an inguinal hernia.

question_text:
Patient Information
Age: 3 days
Sex assigned at birth: M
Race/Ethnicity: unspecified
Site of Care: office
History
Reason for Visit/Chief Concern: the patient is brought by his parents because they would like their child to be circumcised
History of Present Illness:

uneventful home birth at 39 weeks' gestation; Apgar scores 9 and 10 at 1 and 5 minutes, respectively 
infant received all routine newborn care 
parents noticed the patient's urine sprays downward when changing his diaper

Past Medical History:
unremarkable
Medications:
none
Allergies:
no known drug allergies
Family History:

mother age 41 years with type 2 diabetes mellitus 
father age 43 years and sister age 2 years: alive with no chronic conditions

Psychosocial History:

lives with parents and sister
father smokes at home

Physical Examination

Temp
Pulse
Resp
BP
O_2 Sat
Ht
Wt

36.9°C
(98.4°F)

148/min
45/min
64/41 mm Hg
–

(20 in)
3400 g
(7 lb 8 oz)
–

Appearance: no acute distress; no facial dysmorphia
Skin: no rashes
HEENT: no ocular abnormalities; oral mucosa pink and moist; thyroid gland is normal in size
Pulmonary: clear to auscultation
Cardiac: regular rhythm, normal S_1 and S_2, no murmurs

Abdominal: soft and nontender; liver edge palpated 2 cm below the costal margin; spleen is not palpable

Extremities: no edema or tenderness
Neurologic: alert; no abnormalities

Pelvic: normal penile length with moderate curvature; normal glans size; additional opening 3 mm below a blind-ending external urethral meatus on the ventral glans penis; incomplete closure of the foreskin, leaving the tip of the penis exposed; both testes are descended 

Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: Patient Information Age: 3 days Sex assigned at birth: M Race/Ethnicity: unspecified Site of Care: office History Reason for Visit/Chief Concern: the patient is brought by his parents because they would like their child to be circumcised History of Present Illness: uneventful home birth at 39 weeks' gestation; Apgar scores 9 and 10 at 1 and 5 minutes, respectively infant received all routine newborn care parents noticed the patient's urine sprays downward when changing his diaper Past Medical History: unremarkable Medications: none Allergies: no known drug allergies Family History: mother age 41 years with type 2 diabetes mellitus father age 43 years and sister age 2 years: alive with no chronic conditions Psychosocial History: lives with parents and sister father smokes at home Physical Examination Temp Pulse Resp BP O2 Sat Ht Wt BMI 36.9°C(98.4°F) 148/min 45/min 64/41 mm Hg – 51 cm(20 in) 3400 g(7 lb 8 oz) – Appearance: no acute distress; no facial dysmorphia Skin: no rashes HEENT: no ocular abnormalities; oral mucosa pink and moist; thyroid gland is normal in size Pulmonary: clear to auscultation Cardiac: regular rhythm, normal S1 and S2, no murmurs Abdominal: soft and nontender; liver edge palpated 2 cm below the costal margin; spleen is not palpable Extremities: no edema or tenderness Neurologic: alert; no abnormalities Pelvic: normal penile length with moderate curvature; normal glans size; additional opening 3 mm below a blind-ending external urethral meatus on the ventral glans penis; incomplete closure of the foreskin, leaving the tip of the penis exposed; both testes are descended Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: This patient's ectopic external urethral meatus, chordee (i.e., penile curvature), dorsal hood (i.e., incomplete closure of the foreskin), and normal penile length and glans size make standard hypospadias the most likely diagnosis.
learning_objective: Recognize standard hypospadias, and choose the most appropriate next step in management.

answers.explanation_why: Hypospadias is not a medical emergency that warrants urgent surgical correction. Furthermore, in patients with accompanying chordee, surgical straightening of the curvature is important for successful correction of hypospadias and is usually performed along with urethroplasty. Penile straightening ensures proper sexual function.

answers.content: Plan for surgical repair in 6 months
answers.explanation_why: Patients with hypospadias and significant deflection of the urinary stream should be treated operatively between 6–12 months of age. Surgical repair includes urethroplasty, to correct the direction of the urethra, and orthoplasty, to correct the curvature of the penis, which is essential for the successful treatment of hypospadias. Newborn circumcision is generally not recommended in patients with hypospadias because the foreskin might be needed for a skin flap during urethroplasty. Hypospadias is associated with increased maternal age, maternal diabetes mellitus, and prenatal exposure to smoking.

Preoperative hormonal therapy with testosterone can be used to stimulate penile growth in patients with hypospadias who have a microphallus (penile length < 2 standard deviations below the mean length for age). As this patient has standard hypospadias and a normal penis size, testosterone therapy is not indicated.

Elective circumcision is commonly performed during the neonatal period for social or religious purposes, but circumcision is generally not recommended in individuals with hypospadias because it can negatively affect outcomes. Medical indications for circumcision include refractory balanoposthitis, recurrent urinary tract infections, and pathological phimosis.

Karyotyping is not routinely indicated for a patient with hypospadias. It is only performed if the patient has congenital anomalies affecting multiple systems (e.g., cleft lip, congenital heart defect, imperforate anus), or if there are features that raise concern for a disorder of sex development such as severe hypospadias (e.g., urethral meatus displaced to the scrotum or perineum) and cryptorchidism. As this patient has isolated standard hypospadias, karyotyping is not required.

question_text:
Patient Information
Age: 11 years
Sex Assigned at Birth: M
Race/Ethnicity: unspecified
Site of Care: office
History
Reason for Visit/Chief Concern: “My son's left knee has a swelling.”
History of Present Illness:

patient brought to the office by his mother

3-month history of progressive swelling near the left knee
no limitation of daily activities; reports mild discomfort when engaging in sports
no history of fever, chills, or night sweats

Past Medical History:
unremarkable
Medications:
none
Vaccinations:
up-to-date
Allergies:
no known drug allergies
Family history:
mother age 45 years, father age 43 years, and brother age 5 years: alive with no chronic conditions
Psychosocial history:
attends 6^th grade; performs well in school
Physical Examination

Temp
Pulse
Resp
BP

Wt

(96.8 °F)

(4 ft 7 in)

(84 lb)

Appearance: mildly uncomfortable
Skin: no rashes
Pulmonary: clear to auscultation
Cardiac: regular rhythm; no murmurs
Abdominal: nondistended and nontender; liver and spleen cannot be palpated
Extremities: nontender hard immobile mass in the left distal thigh; skin overlying the mass is normal; no limb length discrepancy; no joint erythema, edema, or warmth; full range of motion; dorsalis pedis and posterior tibial pulses intact; no palpable mass elsewhere
Neurologic: fully oriented; no focal neurological deficits

Diagnostic Studies

Blood

 Hemoglobin
14 g/dL 

 Leukocyte count
7200/mm^3 with a normal differential

230,000/mm^3

10 mm/h

18 U/L

 Aspartate aminotransferase (AST)
20 U/L

 Alkaline phosphatase
35 U/L

left knee x-ray: 3-cm pedunculated juxtacortical bony protrusion with a hyperlucent cap on the distal metaphysis of the left femur; no periosteal reaction

Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
content_preview: Patient Information Age: 11 years Sex Assigned at Birth: M Race/Ethnicity: unspecified Site of Care: office History Reason for Visit/Chief Concern: “My son's left knee has a swelling.” History of Present Illness: patient brought to the office by his mother 3-month history of progressive swelling near the left knee no limitation of daily activities; reports mild discomfort when engaging in sports no history of fever, chills, or night sweats Past Medical History: unremarkable Medications: none Vaccinations: up-to-date Allergies: no known drug allergies Family history: mother age 45 years, father age 43 years, and brother age 5 years: alive with no chronic conditions Psychosocial history: attends 6th grade; performs well in school Physical Examination Temp Pulse Resp BP Ht Wt BMI 36°C(96.8 °F) 110/min 15/min 112/72 mm Hg 145 cm(4 ft 7 in)57th %ile 38 kg(84 lb)61st %ile 18.1 kg/m264th %ile Appearance: mildly uncomfortable Skin: no rashes Pulmonary: clear to auscultation Cardiac: regular rhythm; no murmurs Abdominal: nondistended and nontender; liver and spleen cannot be palpated Extremities: nontender hard immobile mass in the left distal thigh; skin overlying the mass is normal; no limb length discrepancy; no joint erythema, edema, or warmth; full range of motion; dorsalis pedis and posterior tibial pulses intact; no palpable mass elsewhere Neurologic: fully oriented; no focal neurological deficits Diagnostic Studies Blood Hemoglobin 14 g/dL Leukocyte count 7200/mm3 with a normal differential Platelet count 230,000/mm3 Erythrocyte sedimentation rate 10 mm/h Serum Ca2+ 9.3 mg/dL Phosphorus (inorganic) 3.6 mg/dL Creatinine 0.8 mg/dL Alanine aminotransferase (ALT) 18 U/L Aspartate aminotransferase (AST) 20 U/L Alkaline phosphatase 35 U/L left knee x-ray: 3-cm pedunculated juxtacortical bony protrusion with a hyperlucent cap on the distal metaphysis of the left femur; no periosteal reaction Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
hint: In an otherwise healthy patient with normal ESR and alkaline phosphatase levels, a painless bone mass indicates a benign bone tumor.
learning_objective: Recognize an osteochondroma.

answers.explanation_why: Osteochondroma, which develops as a juxtacortical (parosteal) mass near the metaphysis of long bones (e.g., humerus, femur), is the most common benign bone tumor. Osteochondromas have a peak incidence between 10 and 30 years of age. Most affected individuals present with a painless palpable mass near a joint. Rarely, patients may develop localized pain, limited range of motion, and pathologic fractures. Characteristic radiographic findings include a pedunculated or sessile bony protrusion with a cartilage cap. Solitary osteochondromas, as seen here, have a very low chance of malignant transformation (approx. 1%) and usually require no further treatment. Regular monitoring may be indicated in patients with multiple osteochondromas, which have a higher chance of malignant transformation (approx. 5%). Surgical removal may be considered in patients with pathologic fractures or growing tumors that impair activities of daily living.

images.title: Osteochondroma of the femur
images.description: X-ray of the femur of a child (AP view)A sessile bony outgrowth (green overlay) can be seen on the lateral metaphysis of the femur. The cartilage cap is irregular and shows arch-like calcifications.

answers.explanation_why: Osteoid osteoma can develop in individuals 4–25 years of age and may involve the metaphysis of long bones. However, affected individuals typically present with dull, constant pain that worsens at night. Moreover, x-ray most commonly shows a cortical bony mass with a radiolucent core surrounded by perifocal sclerosis, rather than a juxtacortical bony protrusion with a cartilage cap.

images.title: Osteoid osteoma
images.description: X-ray right hip (AP view) of a 12-year-old boyA small lucent nidus (hatched green overlay) in the medial proximal femur is accompanied by reactive sclerosis and cortical thickening (green overlay).The appearance is compatible with osteoid osteoma, although other conditions (e.g., intracortical abscess, stress fracture, osteoblastoma) can mimic osteoid osteoma and must be distinguished on the basis of the clinical presentation and additional imaging.

answers.explanation_why: Osteosarcoma can develop in individuals 10–30 years of age and may involve the metaphysis of long bones. However, affected individuals typically present with localized, progressive pain that worsens at night, tender swelling of the affected area with erythema, B symptoms, and elevated inflammatory markers. Moreover, x-ray usually shows a mixed osteolytic and osteosclerotic lesion with an aggressive periosteal reaction (sunburst appearance or Codman triangle).

images.title: Osteosarcoma
images.description: X-ray of the right femorotibial joint (AP view) of a 17-year-old male patientA sclerotic outgrowth of the bone (green overlay) surrounded by osteolytic destruction of medullary and cortical bone (red overlay) is visible on the medial metaphysis of the femur.The periosteum over the lesion is noncontinuous (dashed line), indicating rapid growth of the bone lesion.This appearance of a mixed osteosclerotic and osteolytic lesion in the metaphyses of long bones is characteristic of osteosarcoma.

answers.explanation_why: Chondroblastoma can develop in individuals 10–20 years of age and may involve long bones. However, the epiphysis is usually affected, not the metaphysis, and affected individuals typically present with constant joint pain and swelling. Moreover, x-ray usually shows a well-defined osteolytic lesion with a sclerotic rim.

images.title: Chondroblastoma
images.description: X-ray of the right talocrural joint (a. AP view; b. lateral view)An oval osteolytic lesion is visible in the posterolateral part of the distal tibial epiphysis.This is the typical appearance of chondroblastoma.

answers.explanation_why: Ewing sarcoma can develop in individuals 10–20 years of age and may involve long bones. However, the diaphysis is usually affected, not the metaphysis. In addition, affected individuals typically present with progressive localized pain that worsens at night, tender swelling of the affected area with erythema, B symptoms, and elevated inflammatory markers. Lastly, x-ray typically shows a central lytic bone lesion and a periosteal reaction with an “onion skin” appearance.

images.title: Permeative bone lesion
images.description:
X-ray knee and lower leg (lateral view) of a child with Ewing sarcomaA lytic permeative lesion (green overlay) in the proximal tibial diaphysis has a wide zone of transition. It is accompanied by lamellated periosteal reaction that results in an onion skin appearance (red overlay).

Illustration: comparison of radiographic patterns of bone destruction

answers.explanation_why: Chondrosarcoma may involve the metaphysis of long bones but most commonly develops in individuals > 50 years of age and manifests with progressive pain that worsens at night, tender swelling of the affected area with erythema and elevated inflammatory markers. Moreover, x-ray usually shows a lytic lesion with a “moth-eaten” appearance, intralesional calcifications, and endosteal scalloping.

images.title: Mixed density tumor left hemipelvis
images.description:
X-ray hips (AP view) of a patient with left hip pain, swelling, gait instability, and restriction of movementA mixed lytic (example indicated by blue overlay) and sclerotic (examples indicated by yellow overlay) lesion in the left hemipelvis is accompanied by a large soft tissue component (ST). Indistinct margins and areas of cortical destruction (arrowhead) suggest an aggressive lesion.Further evaluation confirmed the diagnosis of chondrosarcoma.

White dashed line: lesion margin

question_text:
A 2-month-old girl is brought to the pediatrician for a follow-up visit 2 weeks after undergoing a hepatoportoenterostomy for biliary atresia. Before surgery, she had persistent jaundice, pale stools, and poor weight gain. Her prenatal and birth history were unremarkable. She is breastfed exclusively. Her parents have no known medical conditions. She takes no medications. She appears alert and active. Her weight is at the 10^th percentile. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows scleral icterus and mild hepatomegaly. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Results of laboratory studies are shown:

Prothrombin time
12 seconds

Serum

 Albumin
3.7 g/dL

 Bilirubin

 Total

3.5 mg/dL

 Direct

2.8 mg/dL

 Aspartate aminotransferase
52 U/L

 Alanine aminotransferase
61 U/L

Her parents ask about additional steps to ensure optimal growth and development after surgery. Which of the following is the most appropriate recommendation for this patient?
content_preview: A 2-month-old girl is brought to the pediatrician for a follow-up visit 2 weeks after undergoing a hepatoportoenterostomy for biliary atresia. Before surgery, she had persistent jaundice, pale stools, and poor weight gain. Her prenatal and birth history were unremarkable. She is breastfed exclusively. Her parents have no known medical conditions. She takes no medications. She appears alert and active. Her weight is at the 10th percentile. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows scleral icterus and mild hepatomegaly. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Results of laboratory studies are shown: Prothrombin time 12 seconds Serum Albumin 3.7 g/dL Bilirubin Total 3.5 mg/dL Direct 2.8 mg/dL Aspartate aminotransferase 52 U/L Alanine aminotransferase 61 U/L Her parents ask about additional steps to ensure optimal growth and development after surgery. Which of the following is the most appropriate recommendation for this patient?
hint: Persistent cholestasis after hepatoportoenterostomy impairs micelle formation due to decreased bile salt levels, leading to fat malabsorption.
learning_objective: Recognize the need for fat-soluble vitamin supplementation in infants with biliary atresia.

answers.content: Restriction of dietary protein to prevent hepatic encephalopathy
answers.explanation_why: Protein restriction is only indicated in infants with biliary atresia who have evidence of severe hepatic dysfunction or overt hepatic encephalopathy, which is rare in individuals without advanced cirrhosis. Protein is crucial for growth and development in infants, and unnecessary restriction may worsen nutritional status and impair growth.

answers.content: Supplementation with vitamins A, D, E, and K
answers.explanation_why: Infants with biliary atresia, even after a hepatoportoenterostomy (Kasai procedure), remain at risk for cholestasis and impaired bile flow, as evidenced by persistent direct hyperbilirubinemia. Impaired bile flow causes fat malabsorption and impairs absorption of fat-soluble vitamins (A, D, E, and K), resulting in deficiencies. Supplementation with all four fat-soluble vitamins is essential to prevent deficiencies and to support normal growth and development.

Ursodeoxycholic acid is sometimes used to promote bile flow in pediatric liver conditions. However, this medication alone does not address all the nutritional and developmental needs of infants with persistent cholestasis. Another recommendation is more appropriate to support optimal growth and prevent complications in this patient.

answers.content: Increasing feeding frequency to promote weight gain
answers.explanation_why: Increasing feeding frequency or caloric density can help address poor weight gain in infants with chronic illnesses such as biliary atresia. However, in a patient with persistent cholestasis, simply increasing caloric intake does not address the underlying defect in bile-mediated absorption of certain essential nutrients.

While beneficial, breastmilk alone is insufficient for infants with persistent cholestasis because it causes poor absorption of other essential nutrients. Infants with ongoing cholestasis require more than just breastmilk to meet all of their nutritional needs, even if they are feeding well and gaining weight. While regular monitoring is appropriate, dietary modification is also necessary for this patient.

question_text: A 4-year-old boy is admitted to the pediatric intensive care unit following surgical repair of a ventricular septal defect. On postoperative day 2, the nurse notes that he is more irritable and less responsive than the day before. His temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), pulse is 210/min, respirations are 28/min, and blood pressure is 84/52 mm Hg. He appears pale and diaphoretic. Capillary refill is delayed at 4 seconds. Cardiac examination shows muffled heart sounds with no murmurs. Breath sounds are clear bilaterally. Electrocardiography shows a narrow complex tachycardia at 210 beats per minute with regular RR intervals and retrograde P waves visible as small negative deflections immediately after the QRS complexes in leads II, III, and aVF. There is no response to vagal maneuvers and adenosine. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
content_preview: A 4-year-old boy is admitted to the pediatric intensive care unit following surgical repair of a ventricular septal defect. On postoperative day 2, the nurse notes that he is more irritable and less responsive than the day before. His temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), pulse is 210/min, respirations are 28/min, and blood pressure is 84/52 mm Hg. He appears pale and diaphoretic. Capillary refill is delayed at 4 seconds. Cardiac examination shows muffled heart sounds with no murmurs. Breath sounds are clear bilaterally. Electrocardiography shows a narrow complex tachycardia at 210 beats per minute with regular RR intervals and retrograde P waves visible as small negative deflections immediately after the QRS complexes in leads II, III, and aVF. There is no response to vagal maneuvers and adenosine. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
hint: This type of arrhythmia is most commonly seen in young children after cardiac surgery.
learning_objective: Recognize junctional ectopic tachycardia.

answers.explanation_why: Although ventricular tachycardia can cause hemodynamic instability, it is characterized by wide QRS complexes and AV dissociation, not narrow complexes and retrograde P waves following the QRS complexes.

Although atrial flutter typically manifests with a regular, narrow-complex tachycardia, the rhythm is atrial (often ∼ 300/min) with characteristic flutter waves, most visible in the inferior leads. In addition, atrial flutter often responds to AV nodal blockade.

Although sinus tachycardia causes a regular, narrow-complex tachycardia, it typically manifests with normal P waves preceding each QRS complex and a physiological rate increase (rarely > 180–200/min in young children) that is often triggered by fever, pain, or hypovolemia.

Junctional ectopic tachycardia (JET) is a potentially life-threatening arrhythmia most often seen in young children after cardiac surgery, particularly repairs involving the ventricular septum or near the AV node. JET originates from an automatic focus in or near the AV junction, resulting in a narrow complex, rapid, and regular tachycardia. Typically, retrograde P waves are seen immediately after each QRS complex, most clearly as negative deflections in leads II, III, and aVF. JET is notably resistant to AV nodal blocking maneuvers such as vagal stimulation or adenosine, distinguishing it from reentrant supraventricular tachycardias. An abrupt onset, hemodynamic instability, and ECG findings in a patient with recent cardiac surgery are characteristic of JET, which requires urgent identification and specific antiarrhythmic therapy to prevent cardiovascular collapse.

images.title: Junctional tachycardia
images.description: 12-lead ECG (paper speed: 25 mm/s)- Regular rhythm- Heart rate: ∼ 130/min- P waves immediately follow the QRS complexes (examples indicated with green arrowheads) and are inverted in I, II, aVF, and V_4–V_6 (retrograde P waves; examples indicated with red arrowheads).- Cardiac axis borderline normal/right axis deviation (isoelectric in I, R > S in aVF)- Narrow QRS complexes (∼80 ms)- Persistent S waveA regular, narrow complex tachycardia with retrograde P waves is suggestive of junctional tachycardia.

answers.explanation_why: Atrioventricular nodal reentrant tachycardia (AVNRT) is a common cause of paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia in children and adults, typically resulting in a narrow-complex, regular tachycardia. Retrograde P waves may be seen, but AVNRT is a reentrant rhythm that relies on the AV node and is typically terminated by vagal maneuvers or adenosine.
